University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: WHan þat Aprill with his shoures swote
Þe drowth of Marche . hath ꝑper/parced to þe rote
And bathed eủer/rey vayne with soche vertu licour
Of which vertue engendred is þe floıı̄unr
¶ And Zepherus eke with his swete breth
Enspired hath in eủer/rey holt and heth
¶ The tenþir Croppis . and þe yonge son
Hath in þe Ram . half his cours y ron
¶ And smale fowles maken melody
That slapen al nyght wᵗith open ey
¶ So prikkith hem nature in her corage
Þat longith folke to go on pilgremage
¶ And Palmers for to seke strange strondes
To serue halowes . cowth in sondry londes
¶ And specially from euery scheres ende
Of Inglonde to Caunturbury they wende
¶ The holy blisful martir for to seke
Þat hem hath holpen when þei were seke
¶ So it befell þat seson on a day
In Southwerk att þe Tabard as I lay
¶ Redy to wende on my pilgremage
To Caunturbury wᵗith deuout Corage
¶ That nyght was comen into oure hostry
Well xxixᵗⁱ in oo companye
¶ Of dyuerse folk by auenture falle
In Felaschip and pilgremes were þei all
¶ And toward Caunturbury wolde þei ride
The Chaumbres and þe stables weren wide
¶ And wele were þei esed att þe best
And schortly when þe son went to rest
¶ So had I spoken to hem eủer/reychon
That I was of here felawschip anon
¶ And made foreward erly to arise
To take oure wey as I schal you deuyse
¶ But neủer/reþelas while I haue tyme ⁊and space
Or y into þis tale ferþer pace
¶ Me þinkith it accordyng were to resou
To tel you al the Condicyou
¶ Of eche of hem so as it semyth me
And which þei were ⁊and of what degre
¶ And eke of what array þei were Inne
And att a knyght þan wol y first begynne
¶ A knyght þer was / and þat a worþi man
That fro þe tyme þat he furst be gan
¶ To ryde out he loued Cheualrye
Trouth . honour . fredom . and Curtesye
¶ And þerto had he reden . no man so ferre
Ful worþi was he in his lordis werre
¶ As wel in Cristyndom . as in hethenes
And euer had honour . for his worþines
¶ At Alisaundre he was whan it was won
Ful oftyntymes had he þe borde be gon
Aboue al nacions in Spruse
In lettow had ha be / . and in ruse
No Cristyn man so ofte in his degre
In Garnaad eke at þe sege had he be
In Algarise . and redyn in Belmarye
Att lyaies had he be and att Satalye
When þei were won . ⁊and in þe grete see
Att many a noble aryue had he be
Att mortal batels . had he be Fyftene
And fowth for oure feith att Tramyssene
Wᵗithin þe listes . and ay slayn his foo
This ilke worþi knyght had ben also
Sumtyme wᵗith þe lorde Palatie
A yens a noþer hethen in Turkie /
And eủer/remore he had a soủer/reeyn price
And Thowgh he were worþi and wise
And of his port as meke as a mayde
He neuer yit no velany sayde
In al his life vnto no maner wight
He was a verry ꝑper/parfite gentil knyght
And for to tel you of his array
His hors was good but hym silf was not gay
Of Fustian he wered a Iepou
All by smotered wᵗith his habirgou
For he was late com fro his viage
And went to do his pilgremage
¶ Wᵗith hym þer was his son . a yong Squier
A louer . and a lusty bachelere
Wᵗith lokkis crul . as þei were leide in pres
Of xxᵗⁱ yeer . of age he was I gesse
Of his stature he was of euen lengthe
And wonþirly delyuer / ⁊and grete of strengthe
And he had be somtyme in Chyuache
In Flaunders . Artois . and in Picarde
And born hym wel . as of his litle space
In hope to stonde in his ladies grace
Embrowed was he . as it were a mede
And ful of fressh floures white and rede
Syngyng he was . or floityng al . þe day
He was as Fressh as is þe monyth of may
Schort was his gown . wᵗith sleves long ⁊and wide
Wel cowde he sitt a hors and faire ryde
He cowde eke songis make and well endite
Iuste . and daunce . portreve . and eke write
And so hote he loued þat by nyghtes tale
He slepte no more þen dede þe nyghtyngale
Curteys he was . lowly . and seruysable
And wel . couthe carfe to his lady at þe table
¶ A yeman had he and seruantes no moo
As att þat tyme . for hym liste to ride soo
He was al . Clad in a Cote and a hood of grene
A schefe of Pecok arowes bright and schene / /
Vnder his belt he bare ful thryftyly
Wel . cowde he dres his tacle and yomanly
His arowes drowped not wᵗith feders low
And in his honde he bare a myghty bow
A nott hede had he wᵗith a broun visage
Of wode crafte wel . cowde he al þe vsage
Vpon his arme . he bare a gay bracer
And by his side a swerd and a bokeler
And on þe oþer . side a gay daggere
Harneysed wel . and scharp as poynt of spere
A Xpofer on his brest of siluer schene
An horn he bare / . þe bawdrik was of grene
A foster he was sothly as I gesse
Ther was also a Nonne a Priores
Þat of here smyling was ful . symple ⁊and coy
Here grettest othe was but by Seynt loy
And sche was cleped . madame Eglentyne
Ful wel sche songe here seruyse deuyne
Entuned in here noose ful . semely
And frenssh sche spake ful fair and fetesly
After þe scole of Stratford of þe bow
For Frenssh of Parise was to her vnknow /
Att þe mete wel tawth was sche wᵗith all
Sche lete no morsel . fro here lippes fall
Ne wett here Fyngers in her sawse depe
Wel cowth sche cary a morsel ⁊and wel kepe
That no drope fell vpon here brest
In curtesie was sett ful moche here lest
Here ouer lippe . wiped sche so clene
Þat in here cup þer was no ferþing sene
Of grece / . and whan sche drunkyn had here drawth
Full semely . after here mete sche rawth
And sikirly sche was of grete disport
And ful plesable and ameable of port
And payned here to countirfete ful clere
Of Court for to be stately of manere
And for to be digne of reuerence
But for to speke of here conscience
Sche was so charitable and so pitous
Sche wolde wepe . if þat sche saw a mows
Cawth in a trappe . if it were deþe ⁊and bled
Of smale houndis had sche þat sche fedde
With rosted flessh . or mylk and wastel brede
But sore wept sche if any of hem were dede
Or if men smote hem . with yerde smert
And al was conscience and tendir hert
Ful semely here wympill pynchid was
Here nose tretise . here eyen gray as glas
Here mouth ful smal . and þ̉er/reto softe ⁊and rede
But sikirly sche had a fayer forhede
For hardely sche was not vnþer grow
It was almost . a span . brode as y trow /
Ful fetise was here cloke . as y was ware
Of smal coral aboute her arm sche bare
A peire of bedis . gawded al wᵗith grene
And þ̉er/re on hyng abroche of gold ful schene
On which was furst wretyn A crowned . A .
And after . Amor vincit omnia
A noþer . nonne wᵗith here had sche
Þat was here Chapeleyn and prestis thre
¶ Amonke þer was a seir for þe mastrye
An out rider . þat loued wele venerye
A manly man . to be an abbot able
Ful meny a deynte hors had he in his stable
And when he rode men myght his bridil here /
Gynglyng in a whistlyng wynde as clere
And eke as lowde as doth þe Chapel bell
Þer as his lorde was keper . of the sell
Þe rule of Seynt Maure . or of Seynt Benet
By cause it was olde and sumdele streyt
This ilke Munke . lete olde þingis pace
And helde after þe new wordles space
He gafe not of þat text a pulled hen
Þat seith þat hunters . be noon holy men
Ne þat a monke . whan he is recheles
Is likened to a fisshe þat is waterlees
Þis is to seyn a monke out of his cloistr
But þat text holde he not worth an oistr
And y seide his oppiniou was good
What schold he study ⁊and make hym silf wode /
Vpon a boke in Cloistre al day to power .
Or swynke wᵗith his hondes and labower . /
As Austyn biddith þen how schal þe wordil be sued
Lete Austyn haue his swynke to hym reserued
Therfor he was a pramisour a right
Greyhoundis had he þᵗat weren ful light
On prikyng and huntyng for þe hare
Was al his lust for . no þing wold he spare /
I saw his sleues purfiled at þe honde
Wᵗith grise / . and þat þe fynest in the londe
And for to fastyn his hood vnder his chyn
He had of golde wrowth a ful curious pyn
A love knot in þe gretter ende þer was
His heed was balled þat schone as any glas
And eke his face . as he had be anoynt
He was a lorde ful fatte and in good poynt
His eyen stepe were . and rollyng in his hede
Þat stremed as a fourneis of lede
His botes souple . his hors in grete state
Nowe Certeyn he was a fayer . prelate /
He was not pale . as it were a pyned gost
A fatt Swan loued he best of any rost
His palfrey was as broun as a bery
A frere þer was eke a wanton ⁊and a mery
A lymytour . and a ful . solempne man .
In þe ordres . iiij . is noon so wel þat can / .
So moche of Daliaunce and fair langage
He had made ful meny afair mariage
Of yong wemen . att his own Cost
Vnto his ordre he was a noble post
Ful wele biloued ⁊and ful famulier was he
Wᵗith Frankelyns on all in his Contre /
And wᵗith worþi wymmen of þe toun
For he had power of confessiou
And plesaunt was his absoluciou
He was an esy man . to yeue penᵃnce
Þer as he wiste to haue a good petaunce
For vnto a power ordre for to yeue
Is signe þat a man is wele I schryue
For if he gafe . he durst make auaunt
He wist wel þat a man is repentant
For many a man so herd is of hert
He may not wepe / þowgh he sore smert
Therfor in stede of penᵃnce and pᵃyers
Men most geve siluer to þe power freers
His typet was ay farsed ful of knyfes
And pynnes for to geue fair wyfes
And certenly he had a mery note .
Wel . cowþe he syng and pley on a rote
Of yeddynges he bare vttirly þe price
His nekke was white ; as flour delice /
Therto he was stronge as a Champiou
He knewe þe tauernes wel . in eủer/rey Toun
And euery hosteler and Tapstere
Better þan dede a lasur or a beggere
For vnto soche a worþi man as he
Accordith not as to his faculte
To haue wᵗith seke lasurs acqueyntance
It is not honest ; hit may not auᵃnce /
For to dele with soche poraile
But al wᵗith þe riche and sellers of vitaile
And ouer al þer as ꝓprofite schold arise
Curteis he was and lowly of seruise
Þer was no man no wher so vertuous
He was þe best begger in his hows .
For þowgh a wedow ; had not but a schoo
So plesaunt was his in Principio
Yit wolde he haue a ferþing or he went
His purches was better þan his rent
And rage he cowde ; as it had be a whelp
In loue dayes þer cowde he moche help
For þer he was not like a Cloisterer
Wᵗith a thredbare Cope as is a scolere
But he was like a master or a pope
Of dowble worstede ; was his semely cope
Rounde as eny belle out of þe pres
Somwhat le lisped for his wantones
To make his Englissh swete on his tonge
And in harpyng whan þat he had songe
His eyen twyncled in his heed a right
As doth þe sterres in þe frosty nyght
This worþi lymytour . was called huberd
A Marchaunt þer was wᵗith a forked berde
In motle and high on hors he sate
And on his heed a flaundrissh bever hatt
His botes clasped faire and fetously
His resons he spake ful solemply
Sownyng alwey þe encres of his wynnyng
He wolde þe see were kept for any thyng
Betwene Middelburgh and orwell
Wel . cowde he in eschaungis rentis sell
This worþi man ful wel his witt sett
Þer wist no wight þat he was in dett
So stedfastly dede he . wᵗith his goủer/renance
Wᵗith his bargenys and wᵗith his Cheuesaunce
For sothe he was a worþi man wᵗith all
But soth to sey y wot not what men hym call
¶ A Clerk þer was of Oxenford also
That vnto logyk had longe y goo
And lene was his hors . as it were a rake
And he was not right fatt y vnþer take
But loked holowe . and þerto sobirly
Ful . thredbare was his oủer/reest courtepy
For he had as yit gete hym no benefice
He was not wordly to haue an office
For hym was leuer to haue at his beddis hede
xxᵗⁱ bokis cladde in blak and rede
Of Aristotil . and of his Philosophie
Then riche robes . Fidel . oautrie
But al be it thowgh he were a Philosophre
Yit had he but litle gold in his Cofre
But al þat he from his frendis hent
On bokes and on lernyng he it spent
And besily gan for þe sowles pray
Of hem þat gafe hym where wᵗith to scolay
Of stody toke he most cure and hede
Not a worde spake he more þan was nede
And þat was seide in forme and in reủer/reence
And schort and quyk and ful of high sentence
Sownyng in moral vertue was his speche
Gladly wolde he lerne and gladly teche /
A Seriant of lawe þer was ware ⁊and wise
Þat ful ofte had ben at þe Parvise
Þat was ful riche of excellence
Discrete he was and of grete reủer/reence
He semed soche / . his worþis were so wise
Iustise had he ben ful ofte in assise /
Bothe by patent . and pleyn Commyssiou
For his science and his high renoun
Of Fees and Robis had he many oon
So grete a purchesar . was nowher noon
Al was Fe symple to hym in effecte
His purchasyng myght not be in suspecte
Noo wher as esy a man þer nas
And yet he semed besier þan he was
In termys had he cas and domes al
Þat fro þe tyme of kyng Willᵃm were fal
Þerto he cowde endite and make a thyng
Þer cowde no man pynche at his wrytyng
And euery statute cowde he pleyn by rote
He rode ful homely in a medle Cote
Girte wᵗith a girdil of silk wᵗith barres smale
Of his array tel y no lenger tale
¶ A Frankelyn was in the Company
White was his berde as is þe daisie
Of his complexion ; he was sangwyn
Wel loued he by þe morow a sop of wyn
To leue in deylite was euer his wone
For he was Epiourius own sone
þat helde oppinion þat pleyn delite
Was verrey felicite ꝑper/parfite
An howsoldere and þat a grete was he
The grettest oon of all his Contre
His brede his ale was alwey after oon
A better vyned man was no wher noon
Without bake mete was neuer his hous
Of Fissh and flessh . and þat so plenteuous
It xx snewed in his hous of mete and drynke
Of all deyntees þat any man cowþe thynke
After þe sondry sesons of the yere
So chaunged he his mete and his sopere
Ful many a fat ꝑper/partreche had he in mew
And many a breme and many a luce in stew
Woo was his Cook but if his sawse were
Poynant and scharp and redy al his gere /
His table dormaunt in his hall alwey .
Stode redy Coủer/reed all . þe longe day
Att þe Sessions þer was he lord and sire
Fu oftyn tyme he was knyght of þe schyre
And an hanlaas and a Gipsere al of silke
Hyng att his girdil as white as morow mylke
A Scherif had he be and a Comcter
Was no wher . soche a worþi Vauasour
¶ An haberdassher and a Carpenter .
A weuer . a dyer . and a Tapicer .
And þei were cloþed al . in oon lyuereye
Of a solempnyte and a grete Fraternyte
Ful fressh and newe . here gere piked was
Here knyfes were not Claped wᵗith bras //
But al wᵗith siluer . wrowth ful clene and well
Here girdeles and here powches euery dele
Wel semed eche of hem a fair burgeis
To sitt in þe yelde hal vpon þe hyȝe dois
Eueriche of hem / for þe wysdom þat he can
Was schapen to be an alderman
For catel . had þei I nowgh and rent
And eke here wifes wold it wele assent
And elles Certeyn þei weren to blame
Hit is ful fair to be clepid madame
And goo to Vigiles al . a fore
And haue a mantel rially bore
A Cook þei had wᵗith hem for þe nones
To boile þe Chekenys wᵗith þe marybones
And powder marchaunt tart and galyngale
Wel cowde he know a drawth of lōmndon ale /
He cowde . roste . sethe . boile . and frye .
Make mortrewes ; and wel bake a pye
But gret harme was it as thowth me
That on his schene a mormal had he
And blanmanger . made he with þe best
A Schipman þer was þat woned fer bi west
For owth þat y wote he was of dertmouth
He rode vpon a rouncy . as wel as he cowth
In a goun of faldyng vnto the kne
A dagger . hangyng wᵗith a lace had he
About his nek vnder his arm a doun
Þe hote somer had made his hew al broun
And Certenly he was a good felawe
Ful meny a drawth of wyn had he drawe
Fro Burdeux ward while þe chapmen dede slepe
Of nyce conscience toke he noo kepe
Yif þat he fowth and had þe hyer hond
By water he sent it hom . from eủer/rey lond
But he cowde reken wel ; of his crafte þe tydes
The stremes and þe strondes hym besides
His herborowe ; his mone ; and his lodes manage
Ther was noon suche from Hul to Cartage
Hardy he was and wise to vndertake
Wᵗith many a tempest had his berd be schake
He knew al þe hauenes as þei were
Fro Gutlond to þe cape of Fenestrere
And euery Crike . fro Britaigne in to Spayne
His barge was cleped the Mawdelene
Wᵗith vs þer was a doctour of Phesik .
In al þis wordil was noon hym like
To speke of Phisik and Surgerye
For he was grounded in Astronomye
He kepte his pacient a ful grete dell
In houres by his magik naturell
Wel cowþe he fortewne þe ascendent
Of his Images . for by his pacient
He knew þe cause of euery maladie
Wheder it were colde . hoot ; moiste . or . drye /
And wher of it ingendred ⁊and of what humour
He was a verrey parfite practisour .
Þe cause he knewe and of his harm þe rote
Anon he gafe to þe seke man his bote
Ful redy had he al his appoticaries
To sende hym dregges . and his lectuaries
For eche of hem made oþer for to wyn
Her Frenschip was not newe to begyn
Wel knew he the olde Esculapius
And Diastordies and eke Rufus .
Olde Ipocras and Galyen .
Serapion . Rasis and Auicen
Amerrois . damascien and Constantyn
Bernard . Gatisden and Gylbertyn
Of his diete mesurable was he
For he was of noo superfluyte
But of grete norisshyng and digestible
His stody was but litle in þe bible /
In sangwyn and in pers clad wᵗith all
Lyned wᵗith taffata . and Sendall
And yit he was but esy of dispence
For he kept þat he wan in þe pestilence
For golde in Phisik is acordial .
Þerfor he loued gold in especial .
A good wife þer was of beside bathe
But sche was somdele deef ⁊and þᵗat was scathe
Of Cloth makyng sche had soche an haunt
Þat sche passed hem of Ypres ⁊and of Gaunt
In al þe parissh wife was þer noon .
That to offryng abofe her schold goon .
And if þer dede c̉er/reteyn so wroth was sche
That sche was out of al Charite
Here kerchifs were of fyn ground
I durst swere þei weyed a pound
Þat on þe sonday were vpon here hede
Here hosen were of Fyne scarlete rede
Ful . streit tyed / and schoon moist and newe
Boold was here face . faire ⁊and reed of hewe
Sche was a worþi woman all here life
Husbondes att þe Chirch dore had sche Fife
Wᵗithout oþer Company in here youthe
But þer of nedith not as now to speke
And thryes had sche been at Ierusalem
Sche had passed many a strange streem
Att Rome had sche be . and att babiloyne
In Galice . at Seynt Iames and att Coleyne
Sche cowde in eche of wandryng by þe wey
Gaptothed was sche þe soth to sey .
Vpon an ambeler esily sche sate
Wel I wympeled and on here heed an hatt
As brode as it were a bokeler or a targe
A foot mantel about her hippes large
And on here feet a paire of spores scharp
In Felawschip cowþe sche lawhe and carp
The remedies of loue . sche cowþe ꝑper/par chance
For of al þat art sche knew þe olde daunce
A good man þer was of Religioun
Þat was a ꝑper/parsou of a power Toun
But riche he was of holy thowth and werk .
He was also a lerned man / and a good clerk .
That Cristes Gospel trewly wolde teche
His parisshones deuoutly wold he preche
Benygne he was and wonþer diligent
And in aduersite ful abidyng ⁊and pacient
For which he was preised oftyn sithes
Ful loth were hym to curs for his tythes
But raþer wolde hem yeue out of dowte
Vnto his power Parysshones abowte
Of his offryng and eke of his substance
He cowþe in litle thyng haue suffisance
Wide was his parissh and howses fer a sonder
But he lette not for reyn ne for thunder
In sekenes and in myschefe to visite
Þe forþest in his parissh moche and lite
Vpon his feet ; and in his hand a staf
Þis noble ensample to his schepe he yaf
Þat furst he wrowth and aftirward tawth
But of þe gospel he þoo worþes rawth
And þis figure he added eke þertoo
Þat if gold rusted what schold Iron doo
For if a prest be foule / on whom we trust
No wonder is thowgh a lewde man rust
And schame it is if a preste take kepe
A Schetyn schepherd and a clene schepe
Wel awth a Prest / ensample for to yeue
By his clennes how his schepe schold leue
He sett not his benefice to here
And lete his schepe acombred in þe mere
Ne renne to londou to Seynt powles
To seche hym a Chauntry þer for sowles
Or . be wᵗith a broþirhood with holde .
But dwel at home and kepe wel his folde
So þat þe wolf make it nowth myscary .
He was a Schepherd and not a mersonary
And þowgh he holy were and vertuous
He was not wᵗith synfull men dispitous
Ne of his speche daungerous ne digne
But in his speche discrete ⁊and benyge
To drawe folk to heuen bi fairnes
By good ensample þis was his besynes
But and he knew any ꝑper/parsou obstynate
Wheder he were of high or low estate
Hym wold he snybbe scharply for þe nones
A better Prest I trow nowher noon is
He waitith after no pompe ne reuerence
Ne made hym a spiced conscience
But Cristes lore and his apostelis xii .
He tawth ; but first he dede it hym selfe .
Wᵗith hym þer was a plowghman his broþer
That had ladde of dunge many a foþer
A trew swynker and a good was hee
Lyuyng in pees and ꝑper/parfite charite
God loued he best wᵗith al his hool hert
At al tymes þowgh he gamed or smert
And loue his nyghbour right as hym self
He wold thresshe and eke dike and delf
For Cristes sake ; for eủer/rey power wight
Wᵗithout hire if it lay in his myght
His tithes paide he ful fair and well
Boþe of his ꝓpropre swynk and of his catell
In a tabard he rode vpon a mare
Þer was also a Reve and a Millare
A Sompnour and a ꝑper/pardoner also
A Maunciple ⁊and my silf þer wer no moo
The Miller was a stout Carle for þe nonys
Ful bigge he was of body and of bonys
Þat preued wel for wher euer he cam
Att þe wrastlyng he wold haue þe Ram
He was schort scholdred brood ⁊and a thyk knarre
Ther was noo dore but he wold lifte of harre
Or breke it with a renne wᵗith his hede
His beerd as any sowe or fox was rede
And þerto brood as it were a spade
Vp on þe Coppe of his nose he hadde
A werte and þer vpon stode a tufte of heres
Rede as þe bristels of a sowe is eeres
His nose thrilles blake were and wide
A swerd and a bokeler he bare be his side
His mouth was as grete as a furneys
He was a Iangeler and a goliardeys
And þat was most syn and harlotries
Wele cowde he stele corn and tolle thryes
And yit he had a thom . of golde parde
A white Cote and a blew hood wered he
A bagge pipe cowde he wel blow ⁊and soun
And þer with al he browth vs out of toun
A gentil maunciple þer was of a Temple
Of which all Catours myght take ensample
For to be wise in byeng of vitaile
For wheþer he paide or toke be tayle
Ay wayted he so in his acaate
Þat he was ay befor and in good estate
Now is not þat of god a ful fayer grace
Þat soche a lewde manys witt schall pace
Þe wisdom of an hepe of lerned men
Þat masters haue had mo þan þries ten
Þat of law weren expert and Curious
Of which þer were . xii . in an hous
Worþi to be stewardis of rent and londe
Of any lorde þat is in Inglond
To make hym leve by his ꝓpropre good
In honour doutles . but if he were wood
Or lyve as scarsly as hym lust desire
And able to helpe al a schire
In many caas þat myght fal . or hap
And yit þis maunciple set þer alþer cap
The reve was a sklender colrikman
His berde was schaue as nygh as eủer/re he can
His here was bi his eres ful rounde schorn
His top was dokked like a prest byforn
Ful long were his legges and ful lene
Like a staf þer was no calf y sene
Wel cowde he kepe a garner and a byn
Þer was noon auditour cowde on hym wyn
Wel wiste he bi þe drowth ⁊and bi þe reyne
Þe yeldyng of his corn and of his greyne
His lordis scheep . his neete his dayrie
His swyn . his hors . his stoor ⁊and his pultrie
Was hoolly in þis Reves gouernance goủer/renyng
And by his Couenant he yafe þe rekenyng
Sith þat his lorde was xxᵗⁱ yeer of age
Þer cowde no man bryng hym in arrerage
Þer was no bailif herde ; ne oþir hyne
But he knew here sleyth ⁊and here couyne
Þei were a drad of hym as of þe deth
His wonnyng was faire vpon an heth
Wᵗith grene trees schadowed was his place
He Cowþe bettyr þan his lorde purchace
Ful riche he was stored preuyly
His lord he cowde plese ful subtelly
To yeue and lene hym . of his own good
And haue a þank and yit a goun and an hood
Þis Reue sate vpon a wel good stot
Al pomel gray and he hight Scot
Lerned he had in youth . a good mystere
He was a good wright and a Carpentere
A long surcote of pers a boue he hade
And by his side he bare a lusty blade
Of Northfolk was þis Reve of which y tell
Be sydes a Toun men clepe Baldeswell
Tukked he was as is a frere about
And euer he rode hynderest of þe rowt
A Sompnour was þer wᵗith vs in þat place
Þat had a fire reed Cherubyns face
Ful Sausfleme he was . wᵗith eyen narow
As hoot he was and lecherous as a sparow
Wᵗith scalled browes blake and piled berd
Of his visage Children were sore aferde
Þer was neyther litarge ; quyk syluer ne brymston
Borace Ceruse ne oyle of tartre noon
Ne oynement þat wel cowde clense and bite /
That hym myght helpe of his welkys white
Ne of þe knobbes sittyng in his chekys
Wel loued he garlyk Oynyons and lekys
And for to drynke strong wyn . as reed as blod
Þan wold he speke and crye as he were wood
And whan þat he wel . dronke had þe wyn
Than wolde he speke no worde but latyn
A few termes had he two or thre
That he had lerned out of som degre
No wonþir is he herd it al þe day
And eke ye knowe wel how þat a Iay
Can clepe watte . as wel as can þe pope
But who so cowde in oþer þinges hym grope
Than had he spended al . his Philosophie
Ay questio quid iuris wolde he crye /
He was a gentil harlot and a kynde
A better . felow schold men no wher fynde
He wolde suffre for a quarte of wyne
A good felowe to haue his Concubyne
Twelf monyth and excuse hym at þe full
Ful preuyly eke a fynche cowde he pull
And if he fonde owher a good felawe
He wolde teche hym to haue noon awe
In soche caas of þe archedekyns curs
But if a manys sowle hynge in his purs
For wᵗith his purs he scholde pyned be
Purs is þe archedekyns hell qd he
But wel I wote he leyeth right in dede
Of cursyng owth eủer/rey gilty man to drede
For curs woll sle / right as assoilyng savith
And also ware hym of a Significauit
In daunger hadde he . at his own gyse
Al þe yonge gerles of the Diocise .
And knew here Councel ⁊and was al here reed
A gerlonde he had sett vpon his heed
As grete as it were for an ale stake
A bokeler had he made hym of a cake /
With hym þer rode a gentil pardoner
Of Rouncevale his felaw ⁊and his compere
Þat streyth was come fro þe Court of Rome
Ful lowde he songe / come heder loue come to me
This Sumpnour bare to hym a styf burdou
Was neuer trump of half so grete a soun
Þis ꝑper/pardoner had heer as yelow as any wex
But smothe henge it as doth a strike of flex
By ounces hynge his lokkes þat he had
And þerwᵗith his scholders it ouersprad
But thyn . it lay by culpons oon by oon
And an hode for . iolite wered he noon
For it was trussed vp in his walet
Hym þowth he rode al of þe new Iet
And safe his hatte he rode all bare
With glaryng eyen as hath an hare /
A vernacle had he sewed on his cap
His walet lay beforn hym in his lapp
Fret ful of pardon come frōm Rome all hoot
Avois he had as smal as hath a goot
No berde he had ne neuer schold haue
As smoth it was . as it were new schaue
I trow he were a geldyng or a mare
But of his Crafte / fro Berwyk vnto ware
Ne was þer soche a noþer pardoner
For in his male he bare a fair pelow beer
Which as he seide þan / was oure lady veil
He seide he had eke a gobet of the seil
Þat Seynt Petre had when þat he went
Vpon þe See / þer Ihu Criste hym hent
He had a Cros of laton ful of stones
And in a glas he had many pigges bones
But wᵗith þise reliquis whan þat he fonde
A power Persou dwellyng vp londe
Vpon a day he gate hym more money
Than dede þe ꝑper/parsou in monethes twey
And þus wᵗith his feyned flaterye and iapes
He made þe ꝑper/parsou and þe peple his apes
But trewly to tel of hym att þe laste
He was in þe Chirche a noble Ecciaste
Wel cowde he rede a lesson or a story
But alder best he song an offretory
For wel he wist whan þat song was songe
He moste preche and wele file his tonge
To wyn syluer as he ful wel cowthe
Þerfor he song so mery and so lowthe /
¶ Now haue I tolde you sothly in a clause
Þe state þe array . the nombre and þe cause
Why þat assembled was al þis company
In Sowthwerk att þat gentil ostry
Þat hight þe Tabard fast by þe bell
But now it is tyme to you For to tell
How þat we bare vs þat ilke nyght
When we ware in þat ostry alight
And after wol y tel you of oure viage
And al þe remanent of oure pilgremage
But furst y pray you of youre curtesye
Þat ye arette it not to my velany
Þowgh þat y pleynle speke in þis matere
To tel you here worþis and here chere
Ne þowgh I speke not here worþis proprely
For þis ye knowe as wel as y
Who so schal tel a tale after a man
He moste reherse it as nygh as he can
Eủer/rey worde if it be in his Charge
Speke he neuer so rudely ne so large
Or els he mote tel his tale vntrew
Or feyne thyngis or fynde wordis new
He may not spare al þowgh it were his broder .
He most as wel sey oo worde as a noþir .
Criste spake hym self ful brode in holy writt
And wele ye wote no velany . is it
Eke plato seith who so can hym rede
Þe wordis most be Cousyn to þe dede
Also y pray you to for yeue it me
Þowgh y haue not set folk in here degre .
Here in þis tale as þei scholde stonde .
My witt is good schort ye may wel vnderstonde
Greet chere made oure oste to drynke vs eủer/reychon .
And to sowper sett we vs anon
He serued vs wᵗith vitals at þe beste
Strong was þe wyn / ⁊and wel to drynke vs leste
A semely man oure hoost was wᵗith all
For to be a marchal in an hall
A large man he was wᵗith eyen stepe
A fairer burgeis was þer noon in chepe
Bolde of his speche / wise ⁊and wel I tawth
And of manhode lakkyd hym right nawth
Eke he was þerto right a mery man
And after souper play he began
And spake of myrth among oþer thyng .
Whan þat we made had oure rekenyng .
He saide loo lordynges trewly
Ye be to me right welcome hertily
For be my trouth if y schal not lye
I sawe not þis yeer . so mery a company
Att ones in þis herborowgh as is now
Fayn wold y doo you myrth and y wiste how
And of a myrth y am right nowe be thowth
To doon you ease and it schal cost you nowth
Ye goo to Caunturbury god you spede
Þat blisful martir quite you youre mede
And wele y wote as ye goon by þe wey
Ye schapen you to talkyn and to pley
For trewly comfort / ne myrth is it noon .
To ride by þe wey as doumble as a stoon
And þerfor wolde y make you disport
As y seide erst and do you som comfort
And if you like al . by oon assent
To stonde þis tyme at my iuggement
And for to worke as y schal you sey
To morow when ye ride by þe wey
Nowe be my faders soule þat is deed
But ye be mery I wol yeue you my heed
Holde vp youre hondis wᵗithout more speche
Oure Councel was not long for to seche
Vs þowth it was not worth to make it uyce
And graunted hym wᵗithout more avise
And bade hym sey al his verdite as hym leste
Lordynges qd he now herkenyth for þe beste
But take it nowth y pray you att disdayn
Þis is þe poynt to speke it schort and pleyn
Þat eche of you to schort wᵗith youre wey
In þis viage schal telle tales twey
To Caunturbury warde y mene it soo
And homward he schal tel oþer twoo
Of auentures þat somtyme haue be fall
And which of you berith hym best of all
Þat is to say þat tellith in þis caas
Tales of moste sentence and solas
Schal haue a sowper at youre alder cost
Here in þis place sittyng by þe post
When þat ye comyn a yen from Caunturbury
And for to make you þe more mery
I wol my silf goodly wᵗith you ride
Right att myn own cost and be your gyde
And who so wol my iuggement wᵗithsey
Schal pay for al þat we spend by þe way
And if ye voche safe þat it be soo
Tel me anon wᵗithout wordis moo /
And I wol erly schape me þerfore
Þis was gᵃunted and oure othes swore
Wᵗithful glad hert and pᵃyde hym also
Þat he wolde voche safe so to doo
And þat he wolde be oure gouernour
And of oure tales Iugge and reportour .
And sett a sowper att a Certen price
And we wol ruled be at youre deuyce
In hye and lowe / and þus bi oon assent
We be accorded to youre Iuggement
And þer vpon þe wyne was fett anon
We dronkyn and went to reste eủer/reychoon
Wᵗithout any lenger tareyng
A morow when þat þe day gan spryng
Vp roos oure oost and was oure alder cok
And gadred vs to gedre on a flok
And forth we redyn a softe pace
Vnto þe watryng of Seynt Thomᵃs
And þer oure oost gan his bridel to areste
And seide lordes herkenyth if ye leste
Y know oure forward / if ye it recorde
Yf euensong and morow song accorde
Lete se now . how schal tel þe furst tale
As so mote y euer drynke wyne / or ale
Who so be rebel to my Iuggement
Schal pay for al þᵗat is by þe way spent
Now drawith Cutt or we fordir wyn
For he þat hath þe schortest schal be gyn
Ser knyght qd he my master and my lord
Now drawith Cut for þis is myn accord
Comyth nere qd he my lady Priores
And ye sere Clerk lete be your schamefastnes
Ne studieth not ; ley honde to eủer/rey man
And to drawe eủer/rey wight be gan
And schortly to tel as it was .
Were it by auenture sort or caas
Þe soth is / / þe Cut fel on þe knyght
Of which ful glad was eủer/rey wight
And tell he most his tale as it was resou
By forward and by Composicyou
As þat ye haue herde what nedith wordis moo
And when þis good man saw it was soo
As he þat wise was and obedient
To kepe þe forward bi his fre assent
And seide Furst y schal . begyn þe game
Welcome be þe Cutt in goddes name
Now lete vs ride and herkenyth what y sey
And wᵗith þat worde we redyn forth on oure wey
And he began wᵗith right a mery chere
His tale anon / and seide on þis manere //
¶ Iam que domos Patrias . scithice post aspera gentes Prelia . laurigero et cetera
(base) Here bigynneth / the knyghtes tale
(base) c incipit fabula Militis ;
(base) Iamque domos patria Scithice post asꝑper/para gentis laurigero etc Here bigynneth the knygtis tale
(base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) Incipit narracio
(base) ¶ Here bygynneth the knyghtes tale.
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge

div.l: (base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
(base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat

div.l: (base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
(base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
(base) ¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
(base) So shyneth / in his white Baner large
(base) That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
(base) And by his Baner / born was his penoun
(base) Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
(base) The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
(base) ¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
(base) And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
(base) Forth he rode with grete power and myght
(base) Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
(base) Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
(base) ¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng
(base) With Creoun / which that was of Thebes kyng
(base) He faught and slow hym manly / as a knyght
(base) In pleyn bataille / and putte the folk to flyght
(base) And by assaut he wan the Citee after
(base) And rente adoun / bothe wal / and sparre / and rafter
(base) And to the ladyes / he restored agayn
(base) The bones / of hir freendes / that were slayn
(base) To doon obsequies / as was tho the gyse
(base) But it weere al to long for to deuyse
(base) The grete clamour / and the waymentynge
(base) That the ladyes made / at the brennynge
(base) Of the bodies / and the grete honour
(base) That Theseus / the noble Conquerour
(base) Dooth to the ladys / whan they from hym wente
(base) But shortly / for to telle is myn entente
(base) ¶ Whan that this worthy duc this Theseus
(base) Hath Creoun slayn / and wonne Thebes thus
(base) Stille in that feeld / he took al nyght his reste
(base) And dide withal the contree / as hym leste
(base) ¶ To ransake in the taas / of bodies dede
(base) Hem for to strepe / of harneys / and of wede
(base) The pilours / diden bisynesse / and cure
(base) After the bataille / and disconfiture

div.l: (base) And so bifel / in the taas they founde
(base) Thurgh girt with many a greuous blody wownde
(base) Two yonge knyghtes / liggynge by and by
(base) Bothe in oon armes / wroght ful richely
(base) Of whiche two / Arcita highte that oon
(base) And that oother knyght highte Palamon
(base) Nat fully quyk / ne fully deed they weere
(base) But by hir Cote armures / and by hir geere
(base) The heraudes / knewe hem best in special
(base) As they that weren / of the blood roial
(base) Of Thebes / and of sustren two yborn
(base) Out of the taas / the pilours han hem torn
(base) And han hem caryed / softe vnto the tente
(base) Of Theseus / and he ful soone hem sente
(base) To Atthenes / to dwellen in prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / he nolde no raunsoun
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy duc / hath thus ydoon
(base) He took his oost / and hom he ryt anoon
(base) With laurer corouned / as a conquerour
(base) And there he lyueth / in ioye / and in honour
(base) Terme of his lyf / what nedeth wordes mo
(base) And in a tour / in angwissh and in wo
(base) Dwellen this Palamon / and eek Arcite
(base) For euere moore / ther may no gold hem quyte
(base) ¶ This passeth yeer by yeer / and day by day
(base) Til it fil ones / in a morwe of May
(base) That Emelye / that fairer was to seene
(base) Than is the lilie / vpon his stalke greene
(base) And fressher than the May / with floures newe
(base) For with the Rose colour stroof hir hewe
(base) I noot which was / the fairer of hem two
(base) Er it were day / as was hir wone to do
(base) She was arysen / and al redy dight
(base) For May wol haue / no slogardye a nyght
(base) The sesoun pryketh / euery gentil herte
(base) And maketh it out of his sleep to sterte
(base) And seith arys / and do thyn obseruance
(base) This maketh Emelye / haue remembrance
(base) To doon honour to May / and for to ryse
(base) Yclothed was she fressh / for to deuyse
(base) Hir yelow heer / was broyded in a tresse
(base) Bihynde hir bak a yerde long I gesse
(base) And in the gardyn / at the sonne vp riste
(base) She walketh vp and doun / and as hir liste
(base) She gadreth floures / party white and rede
(base) To make / a subtil gerland for hir hede
(base) And as an Aungel / heuenysshly she soong
(base) ¶ The grete tour / that was so thikke and strong
(base) Which of the Castel / was the chief dongeoun
(base) Ther as the knyghtes / weren in prisoun
(base) Of whiche I tolde yow / and tellen shal
(base) Was euene ioynant to the gardyn wal
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ther as this Emelye / hadde hir pleyyng
(base) Bright was the sonne / and cleer / in that mornyng
(base) And Palamon / this woful prisoner
(base) As was his wone / by leue of his Gailler
(base) Was risen / and romed in a chambre anheigh
(base) In which / he al the noble Citee seigh
(base) And eek the gardyn / ful of braunches greene
(base) Ther as / the fresshe Emelye the sheene
(base) Was in hir walk / and romed vp and down
(base) This sorweful prisoner / this Palamoun
(base) This wooful louere this Palamon
(base) Gooth in the chambre / romyng to and fro
(base) And to hymself / compleynyng of his wo
(base) That he was born / ful ofte he seyde allas
(base) And so bifel / by auenture / or cas
(base) That thurgh a wyndow / thikke of many a barre
(base) Of Iren greet and square as any sparre
(base) He caste his eye / vpon Emelya
(base) And therwithal he bleynte / and cryde . A .
(base) As thogh / he stongen weere / vnto the herte
(base) ¶ And with that cry / Arcite anoon vp sterte
(base) And seyde cosyn myn / what eyleth thee
(base) That art so pale / and deedly on to see
(base) Why cridestow / who hath thee doon offence
(base) For goddes loue / tak al in pacience
(base) Oure prison / for it may noon oother be
(base) Fortune / hath yeuen vs this aduersitee
(base) Som wikked aspect or disposicioun
(base) Of Saturne / by som constellacioun
(base) Hath yeuen vs this / althogh we hadde it sworn
(base) So stood the heuene / whan that we were born
(base) We mote endure it this is the short and playn
(base) This Palamoun answerde / and seyde agayn
(base) ¶ Cosyn for sothe / of this opinioun
(base) Thow hast a vayn ymaginacioun
(base) This prisoun / caused me noght to crye
(base) But I was hurt right now / thurgh out myn Iye
(base) In to myn herte / that wol my bane be
(base) The fairnesse / of that lady that I se
(base) Yond in the gardyn / romen to and fro
(base) Is cause / of al my cryyng and my wo
(base) I noot wher she be womman / or goddesse
(base) But Venus / is it soothly / as I gesse
(base) And therwithal / on knees down he fil
(base) And seyde / Venus if it be thy wil
(base) Yow in this gardyn / thus to transfigure
(base) Bifore me / sorweful wrecched creature
(base) Out of this prisoun / help that we may scape
(base) And if so be / my destynee be shape
(base) By eterne word / to dyen in prisoun
(base) Of oure lynage / haue som compassioun
(base) That is so lowe ybroght by tirannye
(base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite gan espye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Where as this lady / romed to and fro
(base) And with that sighte / hir beautee hurte hym so
(base) That if that Palamon / was wounded soore
(base) Arcite is hurt . as muche as he / or moore
(base) And with a syk / . he seyde pitously
(base) The fresshe beautee / sleeth me sodeynly
(base) Of hire / that rometh in the yonder place
(base) And but I haue / hir mercy / and hir grace
(base) That I may seen hire / at the leeste weye
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ This Palamon / whan he tho wordes herde
(base) Despitously / he loked / and answerde
(base) Wheither seistow this / in ernest or in pley
(base) ¶ Nay quod Arcite / in ernest by my fey
(base) God help me so / me list ful yuele pleye
(base) This Palamon / gan knytte his browes tweye
(base) ¶ It were to thee quod he / no greet honour
(base) For to be fals / ne for to be traytour
(base) To me / that am thy cosyn and thy brother
(base) Ysworn ful depe / and ech of vs til oother
(base) That neuere / for to dyen in the peyne
(base) Til that the deeth / departe shal vs tweyne
(base) Neither of vs / in loue to hyndre oother
(base) Ne in noon oother caas / my leeue brother
(base) But that thow sholdest trewely forthre me
(base) In euery caas / as I shal forthren thee
(base) This was thyn ooth / and myn also certeyn
(base) I woot right wel / thow darst it nat withseyn
(base) Thus artow of my conseil / out of doute
(base) And now / thow woldest falsly been aboute
(base) To loue my lady / whom I loue and serue
(base) And euere shal / til that myn herte sterue
(base) Now certes false Arcite / thow shalt nat so
(base) I loued hire first and tolde thee my wo
(base) As to my conseil / and my brother sworn
(base) To forthre me / as I haue told biforn
(base) For which / thow art ybounden / as a knyght
(base) To helpe me / if it laye in thy myght
(base) Or ellis artow fals / I dar wel sayn
(base) This Arcite / ful proudly spak agayn
(base) ¶ Thow shalt quod he / be rather fals than I
(base) And thow art fals / I telle thee outrely
(base) For paramour / I loued hire first er thow
(base) What wiltow seyn / thow woost nat yet now
(base) Wheither she be a womman / or goddesse
(base) Thyn is / affeccioun of holynesse
(base) And myn is loue / as to a creature
(base) For which / I tolde thee myn auenture
(base) As to my cosyn / and my brother sworn
(base) I pose / that thow louedest hire biforn
(base) Wostow nat wel / the olde clerkes sawe
(base) That who shal / yeue a louere any lawe
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Quis / legem det amantibz
(base) Loue is a gretter lawe / by my pan
(base) Than may be yeue / to any erthely man
(base) And therfore / posityf lawe / and swich decree
(base) Is broke alday for loue / in ech degree
(base) A man moot nedes loue / maugree his heed
(base) He may nat fleen it / thogh he sholde be deed
(base) Al be she mayde / wydwe / or ellis wyf
(base) And eek it is nat likly / al thy lyf
(base) To stonden in hir grace / namoore shal I
(base) For wel thow woost thy self verraily
(base) That thow and I / been dampned to prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / vs gayneth no raunsoun
(base) We stryue / as dide the houndes / for the boon
(base) They foghte alday / and yet hir part was noon
(base) Ther cam a kyte / whil that they were so wrothe
(base) That bar awey the boon / bitwix hem bothe
(base) And therfore / at the kynges court my brother
(base) Ech man for hymself / ther is noon oother
(base) Loue if thee lest . for I loue / and ay shal
(base) And soothly / leue brother this is al
(base) Heere in this prisoun / moote we endure
(base) And euerich of vs / take his auenture
(base) ¶ Greet was the stryf / and long bitwix hem tweye
(base) If that I hadde leyser for to seye
(base) But to theffect it happed on a day
(base) To telle it yow / as shortly as I may
(base) A worthy duc . that highte Parotheus
(base) That felawe was / vnto Duc Theseus
(base) Syn thilke day / that they were children lyte
(base) Was come to Atthenes / his felawe to visite
(base) And for to pleye / as he was wont to do
(base) For in this world / he loued no man so
(base) And he loued hym / as tendrely agayn
(base) So wel they loued / as olde bookes sayn
(base) That whan that oon was deed / soothly to telle
(base) His felawe wente / and soghte hym down in helle
(base) But of that storie / list me noght to write
(base) Duc Parotheus / loued wel Arcite
(base) And hadde hym knowe at Thebes / yeer by yere
(base) And finally / at requeste and prayere
(base) Of Parotheus / withouten any raunsoun
(base) Duc Theseus / hym leet out of prisoun
(base) Frely to goon / wher that hym liste oueral
(base) In swich a gyse / as I yow tellen shal
(base) This was the forward / pleynly for tendite
(base) Bitwixe Theseus / and hym Arcite
(base) That if so weere that Arcite weere yfounde
(base) Euere in his lyf by day / or nyght or stounde
(base) In any contree / of this Theseus
(base) And he weere caught . it was acorded thus
(base) That with a swerd / he sholde lese his heed
(base) Ther nas noon oother / remedye ne reed
(base) But taketh his leue / and homward he hym spedde
(base) Lat hym be war / his nekke lyth to wedde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Hit were a gret thing to telle and to wite
(base) ¶ How greet a sorwe / suffreth now Arcite
(base) The deeth he feeleth / thurgh his herte smyte
(base) He wepeth / wayleth / cryeth pitously
(base) To sleen hymself he wayteth pryuely
(base) He seyde allas / the day that I was born
(base) Now is my prisoun / worse than biforn
(base) Now is me shape / eternally to dwelle
(base) Noght in purgatorie / but in helle
(base) Allas / that euere knew I Parotheus
(base) For ellis / hadde I dwelled with Theseus
(base) Yfettred in his prisoun eueremo
(base) Thanne hadde I been in blisse / and nat in wo
(base) Oonly the sighte of hire / whom that I serue
(base) Thogh that I neuere / hir grace may disserue
(base) Wolde haue suffised / right ynogh for me
(base) ¶ O deere cosyn / Palamon / quod he
(base) Thyn is the victorie / of this auenture
(base) Ful blisfully / in prisoun maystow dure
(base) In prison ; / nay certes / but in paradys
(base) Wel hath Fortune / yturned thee / the dys
(base) That hast the sighte of hire / and I thabsence
(base) For possible is / syn thow hast hire presence
(base) And art a knyght a worthy and an able
(base) That by som caas / syn Fortune is chaungeable
(base) Thow mayst to thy desir / som tyme atteyne
(base) But I / that am exiled and bareyne
(base) Of alle grace / and in so greet despeyr
(base) That ther nys Erthe / water / fyr / ne Eyr
(base) Ne creature / that of hem maked is
(base) That may me helpe / or do confort in this
(base) Wel oghte I sterue / in wanhope / and distresse
(base) Farwel my lyf / my lust and my gladnesse
(base) ¶ Allas / why pleynen folk so / in cōmmune
(base) On purueiance of god / or of Fortune
(base) That yeueth hem ful ofte / in many a gyse
(base) Wel bettre / than they kan hem self deuyse
(base) ¶ Som man desireth / for to haue richesse
(base) That cause is ofte / of his moerdre / or gret siknesse
(base) And som man wolde / out of his prison fayn
(base) That in his hous / is of his meynee slayn
(base) Infinite harmes / been in this matere
(base) We woot nat what thyng that we prayen heere
(base) We fare as he / that dronke is as a Mous
(base) A dronke man woot wel / he hath an hous
(base) But he noot which the righte wey is thider
(base) And to a dronke man / . the wey is slider
(base) And certes / in this world / so faren we
(base) We seken faste / after felicitee
(base) But we goon wrong ful ofte trewely
(base) Thus may we seyn alle / and nameliche I
(base) That wende / and hadde a greet opinioun
(base) That if I myghte / scapen fro prisoun
(base) Thanne hadde I been in ioye / and parfit heele
(base) Ther now / I am exiled fro my wele
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Syn that / I may nat seen yow Emelie
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys no remedie
(base) ¶ Vpon that oother syde Palamon
(base) Whan that he wiste / Arcite was agon
(base) Swich sorwe he maketh / that the grete tour
(base) Resowneth / of his yowlyng and clamour
(base) The pure fettres / of his shynes grete
(base) Were / of his bittre salte teeris wete
(base) Allas quod he / Arcita cosyn myn
(base) Of al oure stryf / god woot the fruyt is thyn
(base) Thow walkest now / in Thebes at thy large
(base) And of my wo / thow yeuest litel charge
(base) Thow mayst syn thou hast wisdom / and manhede
(base) Assemblen / al the folk of oure kynrede
(base) And make a werre / so sharp / on this Citee
(base) That by som auenture / or som tretee
(base) Thow mayst haue hire / to lady and to wyf
(base) For whom / that I moste nedes lese my lyf
(base) For as by wey / of possibilitee
(base) Sith thow art at thy large / of prisoun free
(base) And art a lord / greet is thyn auantage
(base) Moore than is myn / that sterue here in a cage
(base) For I moot wepe / and waille whil I lyue
(base) With al the wo / that prison may me yeue
(base) And eek wᵗith peyne / that loue me yeueth also
(base) That doubleth / al my torment and my wo
(base) Ther with / the fyr of Ialousie vp sterte
(base) With Inne his brest and hente hym by the herte
(base) So woodly / that he lyk was to byholde
(base) The Boxtree / or the Asshen dede / and colde
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he / o crewel goddes / that gouerne
(base) This world / with byndyng of youre word eterne
(base) And writen / in the table of Atthamaıı̄unt
(base) Youre parlement . and youre eterne graıı̄unt
(base) What is man kynde / moore vnto yow holde
(base) Than is the sheep / that rowketh in the folde
(base) For slayn is man / right as another beest
(base) And dwelleth eek in prison and arrest
(base) And hath siknesse / and greet aduersitee
(base) And ofte tymes / giltlees pardee
(base) ¶ What gouernance / is in this prescience
(base) That giltlees / tormenteth Innocence
(base) And yet encreeceth this / al my penance
(base) That man is bounden / to his obseruance
(base) For goddes sake / to letten of his wille
(base) Ther as a beest may al his lust fulfille
(base) And whan a beest is deed / it hath no peyne
(base) But man after his deeth / moot wepe and pleyne
(base) Thogh in this world / he haue care and wo
(base) Withouten doute / it moot stonden so
(base) The answere of this / lete I to diuynys
(base) But wel I woot that in this world / greet pyne is
(base) ¶ Allas / I se a serpent or a theef /
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That many a trewe man / hath doon mescheef
(base) Goon at his large / and where hym lust may turne
(base) But I moot been in prison / thurgh Saturne
(base) And eek thurgh Iuno / Ialous / and eek wood
(base) That hath destroyed / wel neigh al the blood
(base) Of Thebes / with his waste walles wyde
(base) And Venus / sleeth me / on that oother syde
(base) For Ialousie / and feere / of hym Arcite
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynte / of Palamon alite
(base) And lete hym / in his prisoun stille dwelle
(base) And of Arcita / forth I wol yow telle
(base) ¶ The Somer / and the nyghtes longe
(base) Encreecen / double wise / the peynes stronge
(base) Bothe of the louere / and the prisoner
(base) I noot which hath / the sorwefuller myster
(base) For soothly for to seyn / this Palamon
(base) Perpetuelly / is dampned to prisoun
(base) In cheynes / and in fettres / to been deed
(base) And Arcite / is exiled / vpon his heed
(base) For eueremo / as out of that contree
(base) Ne neueremo / ne shal his lady see
(base) ¶ Yow loueris / axe I now / this questioun
(base) Who hath the worse / Arcite / or Palamoun
(base) That oon may seen his lady / day by day
(base) But in prisoun / moot he dwelle alway
(base) That oother / where hym list may ride or go
(base) But seen his lady / shal he neuere mo
(base) Now demeth as yow list ye that kan
(base) For I wol telle forth / as I bigan
(base) ¶ Explicit prima pars ~
(base) ¶ Sequitur pars secunda ~
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite / to Thebes comen was
(base) Ful ofte a day / he swelte / and seyde allas
(base) For seen his lady / shal he neuere mo
(base) And shortly / to concluden al his wo
(base) So muchel sorwe / hadde neuere creature
(base) That is or shal / whil that the world may dure
(base) ¶ His sleep / his mete / his drynke / is hym biraft
(base) That leene he weex / and drye as is a shaft
(base) Hise eyen holwe / and grisly to biholde
(base) His hewe falow / and pale as asshen colde
(base) And solitarie he was / and euere alloone
(base) And waillynge al the nyght . makynge his moone
(base) And if he herde / soong or Instrument
(base) Thanne wolde he wepe / he myghte nat be stent
(base) So feble eek were his spiritz / and so lowe
(base) And chaunged so / that no man koude knowe
(base) His speche / nor his voys / thogh men it herde
(base) And in his gere / for al the world he ferde
(base) Nat oonly / lyk the loueris maladye
(base) Of Hereos / but rather lyk Manye
(base) Engendred / of humour malencolyk
(base) Biforn his Celle fantastyk
(base) And shortly / turned was / al vp so down
(base) Bothe habit and eek disposicioun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Of hym / this woful louere daun Arcite
(base) ¶ What sholde I al day / of his wo endite
(base) Whanne he endured hadde / a yeer / or two
(base) This cruel torment and this peyne and wo
(base) At Thebes in his contree / as I seyde
(base) Vpon a nyght in sleep / as he hym leyde
(base) Hym thoughte / how that the wynged god Mercurye
(base) Biforn hym stood / and bad hym to be murye
(base) His slepy yerde / in honde he bar vprighte
(base) An hat he wered / vpon his herys brighte
(base) Arrayed was this god / as he took keep
(base) As he was / whan that Argus took his sleep
(base) And seyde hym thus / to Atthenes shaltow wende
(base) Ther is thee shapen / of thy wo an ende

(base) And made a signe / wher by that he took

(base) ¶ The thridde hour in equal / that Palamon

(base) And to the temple of Diane / gan hye
(base) Hir maydens / that she thider with hire ladde

(base) The hornes ful of Mede / as was the gyse

(base) ¶ Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
(base) This Emelye / with herte debonaire
(base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general

(base) ¶ Hir brighte heer was kembed / vntressed al
(base) A corone / of a grene ook cerial

(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere

(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
(base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf
(base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye
(base) And for to walken / in the wodes wilde
(base) And noght to been a wyf / and be with childe
(base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man

div.l: (base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
(base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
(base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle
(base) Syn thow art mayde / and kepere of vs alle
(base) My maydenhode thow kepe / and wel conserue
(base) And whil I lyue / a mayde I wol thee serue
(base) ¶ The fyres brenne / vpon the Auter cleere
(base) Whil Emelie / is thus in hir prayere
(base) But sodeynly / she seigh a sighte queynte
(base) For right anon / oon of the fyres queynte
(base) And quyked agayn / and after that anon
(base) That oother fyr was queynt and al agon
(base) And as it queynte / it made a whistlynge
(base) As doon thise weete brondes / in hir brennynge
(base) And at the brondes ende / out ran anoon
(base) As it were / blody dropes many oon
(base) For which / so soore agast was Emelye
(base) That she was wel neigh mad / and gan to crye
(base) For she ne wiste / what it signyfied
(base) But oonly for the feere / thus hath she cryed
(base) And weep / that it was pitee for to heere
(base) ¶ And therwithal / Diane gan appeere
(base) With bowe in honde / right as an hunteresse
(base) And seyde doghter / stynt thyn heuynesse
(base) Among the goddes hye / it is affermed
(base) And by eterne word / writen and confermed
(base) Thou shalt be wedded / vnto oon of tho
(base) That han for thee / so muche care and wo

(base) Fare wel / for I ne may no lenger dwelle
(base) The fires / whiche that on myn Auter brenne
(base) Shul thee declaren / er that thow go henne
(base) Thyn auenture of loue / as in this cas
(base) And with that word / the Arwes in the Caas
(base) Of the goddesse / clateren faste and rynge
(base) And forth she wente / and made a vanysshynge
(base) For which / this Emelye astoned was
(base) And seyde / what amounteth this allas
(base) I putte me / in thy proteccioun
(base) Diane / and in thy disposicioun
(base) And hoom she gooth anoon / the nexte weye
(base) This is theffect ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ The nexte houre of Mars / folwynge this
(base) Arcite / vnto the temple walked is
(base) Of fierse Mars / to doon his sacrifise
(base) With alle the rytes / of his payen wise

div.l: (base) With pitous herte / and heigh deuocioun
(base) Right thus to Mars / he seyde his orisoun
(base) ¶ O stronge god / that in the regnes colde
(base) Of Trace / honoured art and lord yholde
(base) And hast in euery regne / and euery lond
(base) Of armes / al the brydel in thyn hond
(base) And hem fortunest as thee list deuyse
(base) Accepte of me / my pitous sacrifise
(base) If so be / that my youthe may disserue
(base) And that my myght be worthy for to serue
(base) Thy godhede / that I may be oon of thyne
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to rewe vpon my pyne
(base) For thilke peyne / and thilke hote fyr
(base) In which / thow whilom brendest for desir
(base) Whan that thow vsedest the beautee
(base) Of faire yonge / fresshe Venus free
(base) And haddest hire / in armes at thy wille
(base) Although thee ones / on a tyme mysfille
(base) Whan Vulcanus / hadde caught thee in his laas
(base) And foond thee lyggyng by his wyf allas
(base) For thilke sorwe / that was in thyn herte
(base) Haue routhe as wel / vpon my peynes smerte
(base) I am yong / and vnkonnyng as thow woost /
(base) And as I trowe / with loue offended moost
(base) That euere was / any lyues creature
(base) For she that dooth me / al this wo endure
(base) Ne reccheth neuere / wher I synke or fleete
(base) And wel I woot er she me mercy heete
(base) I moot with strengthe / wynne hire in the place
(base) And wel I woot withouten help and grace
(base) Of thee / ne may my strengthe noght auaille
(base) Thanne help me lord / tomorwe in my bataille
(base) For thilke fyr / that whilom brende thee
(base) As wel as thilke fyr / now brenneth me
(base) And do that I tomorwe / may haue victorie
(base) Myn be the trauaille / and thyn be the glorie
(base) Thy souereyn temple / wol I moost honouren
(base) Of any place / and alwey moost labouren
(base) In thy plesaunce / and in thy craftes stronge
(base) And in thy temple / I wol my baner honge
(base) And alle the armes / of my compaignye
(base) And euere mo / vn til that day I dye
(base) Eterne fyr / I wol bifore thee fynde
(base) And eek to this auow / I wol me bynde
(base) My berd / myn heer / that hangeth long adown
(base) That neuere yet ne felte offensioun
(base) Of Rasour / nor of Shere / I wol thee yiue
(base) And been thy trewe seruant whil I lyue
(base) Now lord haue routhe / vpon my sorwes soore
(base) Yif me the victorie / I axe thee namoore
(base) ¶ The prayere stynt of Arcita the stronge
(base) The rynges / on the temple dore that honge
(base) And eek the dores / clatereden ful faste
(base) Of which Arcita / som what hym agaste
(base) The fires brende / vpon the Auter brighte
(base) That it gan al the temple for to lighte

div.l: (base) A swete smel / anoon the ground vp yaf
(base) And Arcita / anoon his hand vp haf
(base) And moore encens / in to the fyr he caste
(base) With othere rytes mo / and at the laste
(base) ¶ The statue of Mars / bigan his hauberk rynge
(base) And with that sown / he herde a murmurynge
(base) Ful lowe and dym / and seyde thus / victorie
(base) For which / he yaf to Mars / honour and glorie
(base) ¶ And thus with ioye / and hope / wel to fare
(base) Arcite anoon / vnto his In is fare
(base) As fayn as fowel / is of the brighte sonne
(base) ¶ And right anoon / swich stryf ther is bigonne
(base) For thilke grauntyng in the heuene aboue
(base) Bitwixe Venus / the goddesse of loue
(base) And Mars / the sterne god armipotente
(base) That Iuppiter / was bisy it to stente
(base) Til that the pale / Saturnus the colde
(base) That knew so manye / of auentures olde
(base) Foond in his olde experience / an art
(base) That he ful soone / hath plesed euery part
(base) As sooth is seyd / elde hath greet auantage
(base) In elde / is bothe wisdom and vsage
(base) Men may the olde at renne / and nat atrede
(base) Saturne anoon / to stynten stryf and drede
(base) Al be it that it is agayn his kynde
(base) Of al this stryf he kan remedie fynde
(base) ¶ My deere doghter Venus / quod Saturne
(base) My cours / that hath so wyde for to turne
(base) Hath moore power / than woot any man
(base) Myn is the drenchyng in the See so wan
(base) Myn is the prison / in the derke cote
(base) Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by the throte
(base) The murmur / and the cherles rebellynge
(base) The groynyng and the pryuee empoysonynge
(base) I do vengeance / and pleyn correccioun
(base) Whil I dwelle / in the signe of the leoun
(base) Myn is the ruyne / of the heighe halles
(base) The fallyng of the toures / and of the walles
(base) Vpon the Mynour / or the Carpenter
(base) I slow Sampson / shakyng the piler
(base) And myne be / the maladies colde
(base) The derke tresons / and the castes olde
(base) My lookyng is the fader of pestilence
(base) Now weep namoore / I shal doon diligence
(base) That Palamon / that is thyn owene knyght
(base) Shal haue his lady / as thow hast hym hight
(base) Thogh Mars shal helpe his knyght yet nathelees
(base) Bitwixe yow / ther moot be som tyme pees
(base) Al be ye noght of o complexioun
(base) That causeth al day / swich diuisioun
(base) I am thyn Aiel / redy at thy wille
(base) Weep now namoore / I wol thy lust fulfille
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynten / of the goddes aboue
(base) Of Mars / and of Venus / goddesse of loue
(base) And telle yow / as pleynly as I kan
(base) The grete effect. for which that I bigan
(base) ¶ Explicit tercia pars ~
(base) ¶ Sequitʳ pars quarta ~
(base) ¶ Greet was the feeste / in Atthenes that day

div.l: (base) And eek the lusty sesoun / of that May
(base) Made euery wight to been in swich plesaunce
(base) That al that monday / Iusten they and daunce
(base) And spenden it in Venus heigh seruyse
(base) And by the cause / that they sholde ryse
(base) Erly / for to seen the grete sight
(base) Vnto hir reste / wente they at nyght
(base) And on the morwe / whan the day gan sprynge
(base) Of hors and harneys / noyse and claterynge
(base) Ther was in hostelryes / al aboute
(base) And to the paleys / rood ther many a route
(base) Of lordes / vpon steedes and palfreys
(base) Ther maist thow seen / deuysynge of harneys
(base) So vnkouth / and so ryche / and wroght so weel
(base) Of Goldsmythrye / of Broudyng and of steel
(base) The sheldes brighte / testers / and trappures
(base) Gold hewen helmes / hauberkes / cote armures
(base) Lordes in parementz / on hir coursers
(base) Knyghtes of retenue / and eek Squyers

(base) Gyggynge of sheeldes / with layners lasynge
(base) Ther as nede is / they were no thyng ydel
(base) The fomy steedes / on the golden brydel
(base) Gnawynge / and faste the Armurers also
(base) With fyle and hamer / prykyng to and fro
(base) Yemen on foote / and communes many oon
(base) With shorte staues / thikke as they may goon
(base) Pipes / trompes / Nakers / Claryounes
(base) That in the bataille / blowen blody sownes
(base) The paleys ful of peples / vp and down
(base) Heer thre / ther ten / holdynge hir questioun
(base) Deuynynge / of thise Thebans knyghtes two
(base) Somme seyde thus / somme seyden it shal be so
(base) Somme helden with hym / with the blake berd
(base) Somme with the balled / somme with the thikke herd
(base) Somme seyde / he looked grym / and he wolde fighte
(base) He hath a Sparth / of twenty pound of wighte
(base) Thus was the halle / ful of deuynynge
(base) Longe after / that the sonne gan to sprynge
(base) ¶ The grete Theseus / that of his sleep awaked
(base) With mynstralcye / and noyse that was maked
(base) Held yet the chambres / of his paleys ryche
(base) Til that the Theban knyghtes / bothe yliche
(base) Honoured /. weren in to the Paleys fet
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / is at a wyndow set
(base) Arrayed / right as he weere a god in Trone
(base) The peple preeseth / thiderward ful soone
(base) Hym for to seen / and doon heigh reuerence
(base) And eek / to herkne his heste / and his sentence
(base) ¶ An heraud on a Scaffold / made an .oo.
(base) Til al the noyse / of the peple was ydo
(base) And whan he say the peple / of noyse al stille
(base) Thus shewed he / the myghty dukes wille
(base) ¶ The lord hath / of his heighe discrecioun
(base) Considred / that it were destruccioun

div.l: (base) To gentil blood / to fighten in the gyse
(base) Of mortal bataille / now in this emprise
(base) Wher fore / to shapen / that they shal noght dye
(base) He wole / his firste purpos modifie
(base) ¶ No man therfore / vpon peyne / of los of lyf
(base) No manere shot ne polax / ne short knyf
(base) In to the lystes sende / or thider brynge
(base) Ne short swerd for to stoke / with point bitynge
(base) No man ne drawe / ne bere it by his syde
(base) Ne no man / shal vnto his felawe ryde

(base) Foyne if hym list on foote / hymself to were
(base) Ne noman so hardy this ordenaunce forto breke
(base) And he that is at meschief / shal be take
(base) And noght slayn / but be broght vnto the stake
(base) That shal been ordeyned / on eyther syde

(base) On outher syde / or ellis sleen his make
(base) No lenger / shal the tourneying laste
(base) God spede yow / go forth and ley on faste
(base) With long swerd / and with mace / fighteth your fille
(base) Go now youre wey / this is the lordes wille
(base) ¶ The voys of peple / touched the heuene
(base) So loude cryde they / with loude steuene
(base) God saue swich a lord / that is so good
(base) He wilneth / no destruccioun of blood
(base) ¶ Vp goon the trompes / and the melodye
(base) And to the lystes / ryt the compaignye
(base) By ordinance / thurgh out the Citee large
(base) Hanged with clooth of gold / and noght with sarge
(base) ¶ Ful lyk a lord / this noble duc gan ryde
(base) Thise two Thebans / vpon eyther syde
(base) And after rood the queene / and Emelye
(base) And after that another compaignye
(base) Of oon and oother / after hir degree
(base) And after hem of comunes aft̉er/re here degre
(base) And thus they passen / thurgh out the Citee
(base) And to the lystes / coome they bityme
(base) It nas nat of the day / yet fully pryme
(base) ¶ Whan set was Theseus / ful ryche and hye
(base) Ypolita the queene / and Emelye
(base) And othere ladyes / in degrees aboute
(base) Vnto the setes / preeseth al the route
(base) And westward / thurgh the gates vnder Marte
(base) Arcite / and eek the hundred of his parte
(base) With baner reed / is entred right anon
(base) ¶ And in that selue moment Palamoun
(base) Is vnder Venus Estward in the place
(base) With baner whit / and hardy cheere and face
(base) In al the world / to seken vp and down
(base) So euene / withouten variacioun
(base) Ther nere / swiche compaignyes tweye
(base) For ther was noon so wys / that koude seye
(base) That any hadde / of oother auantage
(base) Of worthynesse / ne of estaat ne age
(base) So euene were they chosen for to gesse
(base) And in two renges / faire they hem dresse
(base) ¶ Whan that hir names / rad were euerichon
(base) That in hir nombre / gyle were ther noon

div.l: (base) Tho were the gates shet and cryd was loude
(base) Do now youre deuoir / yonge knyghtes proude
(base) ¶ The heraudes / lefte hir prikyng vp and down
(base) Now ryngen trompes loude / and Clarioun
(base) Ther is namoore to seyn / but West and Est
(base) In goon the speres / ful sadly in the arest
(base) In gooth the sharpe spore / in to the syde
(base) Ther seen men / who kan Iuste / and who kan ryde
(base) Ther shyueren shaftes / vpon sheeldes thikke
(base) He feeleth / thurgh the herte spoon the prykke
(base) Vp spryngeth speres / twenty foot on highte
(base) Out goon the swerdes / as the siluer brighte
(base) The helmes they tohewen / and to shrede

(base) With myghty maces / the bones they tobreste
(base) He thurgh the thikkest of the throng gan threste
(base) Ther stomblen steedes stronge / and doun gooth al

(base) He thurgh the body is hurt and sithen ytake

(base) Another / lad is on that oother syde
(base) ¶ And som tyme / dooth hem Theseus to reste
(base) Hem to refresshe / and drynken if hem leste
(base) Ful ofte a day / haue thise Thebans two
(base) Togydre ymet and wroght his felawe wo
(base) Vnhorsed hath ech oother / of hem tweye
(base) Ther nas no tygre / in the vale of Galgopheye
(base) Whan that hir whelp is stole / whan it is lyte
(base) So cruel on the hunte / as is Arcite
(base) For Ialous herte / vpon this Palamon
(base) Ne in Belmarye / ther nys so fel leoun
(base) That hunted is / or for his hunger wood
(base) Ne of his praye / desireth so the blood
(base) As Palamon / to sleen his foo Arcite
(base) The Ialous strokes / on hir helmes byte
(base) Out renneth blood / on bothe hir sydes rede
(base) ¶ Som tyme an ende ther is / of euery dede
(base) For er the sonne / vnto the reste wente
(base) The stronge kyng Emetrius / gan hente
(base) This Palamon / as he faught with Arcite
(base) And made his swerd / depe in his flessh to byte
(base) And by the force of twenty / is he take
(base) Vnyolden / and ydrawen to the stake
(base) And in the rescous / of this Palamoun
(base) The stronge kyng lygurge / is born adoun
(base) And kyng Emetrius / for al his strengthe
(base) Is born out of his Sadel / a swerdes lengthe
(base) So hitte hym Palamon / er he were take
(base) But al for noght he was broght to the stake
(base) His hardy herte / myghte hym helpe naught
(base) He moste abyde / whan that he was caught
(base) By force / and eek by composicioun
(base) ¶ Who sorweth now / but woful Palamoun

div.l: (base) That moot namoore / goon agayn to fighte
(base) And whan that Theseus / hadde seen this sighte
(base) Vnto the folk / that foghten thus echon
(base) Ne non schal lenger to his felaw gon
(base) He cryde / hoo namoore / for it is doon
(base) I wol be trewe Iuge / and nat partye
(base) Arcite of Thebes / shal haue Emelye

(base) Anon ther is a noyse of peple bigonne

(base) ¶ What kan now faire Venus / doon aboue

(base) But wepeth so / for wantyng of hir wille
(base) Til that hir teerys / in the lystes fille
(base) She seyde / I am ashamed doutelees
(base) ¶ Saturnus seyde / doghter hoold thy pees
(base) Mars hath his wyl / his knyght hath al his boone
(base) And by myn heed / thow shalt been esed soone
(base) ¶ The trompours / with the loude Mynstralcye
(base) The heraudes / that ful loude yelle and crye

(base) But herkneth me / and stynteth noyse alite

(base) ¶ This fierse Arcite / hath of his helm ydon

(base) Þay folwe alle þe fauour of fortune

(base) And leep asyde / and foundred as he leep
(base) And er that Arcite / may taken keep

(base) As blak he lay / as any col / or crowe

(base) With herte soor / to Theseus Paleys
