So stant Custaunce ⁊and lokith here abaute /
¶O quenes louyng in prosperite
Duches and ye ladies eủer/reychoıı̄un
Haueth som rewth of here adủer/resite
An Emꝑper/paroures doughter stant alone
Sche hath no wight / to whom to make here mone
O blood riall þat stondest in þis drede
Fer been þi frendis att þi grete nede
¶This Alla kyng hath suche cōmpassioıı̄un
As gentil herte is / fulfilled of pite
That fro his Eyen ran þe water doun
Nowe hastily doo feche a book qd hee
And if þis knyght wol swere / howeþatsche
This woman slough ȝit wol we vs avise
Whom þat we woll þat schal be oure Iustise
¶A Breton book wretyn with Euangyles
Was Fett and on þis book he swore anon
Sche gilty was / and in the mene whiles //
An hande hym smote vpon the necke boon
Þat doun he fell attones as a stoon
And boþe his Eyen brast out of his face
In sight of euery body in that place /
¶Avois was herde in genall audience
And seide þou hast desclaundred giltles
The doughter of holy Chirche in hye psence
Þus hast þou doon ȝit holde y my pees
Of þis mvaile agaste was all the prees
As mased folke þei stonden eủer/reychoıı̄un
For drede of wreche / safe Custaunce aloon
¶Grete was þe drede / ⁊and eke þe repentaunce
Of hem þat hadde wronge suspecyoıı̄un
Vpon this sely Innocent Custaunce
And for this myracle in Conclusioıı̄un
And by Custaunces mediacyoıı̄un
Þe kyng ⁊and many Anoþer in þat place
Conuerted were / thankyd be goddis gᵃce
¶This fals knyght was sleyn for his vntreuth
By Iuggement of kyng Alla hastily
⁊and yit Custaunce had of his deth greet piteruthpite ruth
And aftir this Ihus of his mercy
Made Alla wedden Solemply
Þis holy mayde / þᵗat is so bright ⁊and schene
⁊and þus hath Criste made Custaunce A quene
¶But who was wofull if y schal not lie
Of þis weddyng but donegild ⁊and noo moo
The kynges moþer full of Tyrannye
Here thowgh here cursed hert brak atwoo
Sche wolde not here son had doon soo
Hire thowth a despite þᵗat he schold take
So straunge A Creature vnto his make
¶Me liste not of þe Chaff ne of þe stree
Maken so longe atale / as of þe Corn
What scholde y tell of the rialte
At þe mariage / or which Cours goth biforn
Who bloweth in a trumpe or in an horn
Þe fruyt of euery tale is for to seye /
Þei eten : drunken : daunce / songe / ⁊and pleye /
¶They goon to bedde as it was skil ⁊and right
For þough þat wifes be ful holy thynges
They moste take in pacience at nyght
Suche man necessaries / as be plesynges
To folk þat haue wedded hem with rynges
And ley a litle here holynes a side
As for þe tyme / it may no better be tyde
¶On here he bigate A knave Childe anon
And to A Bisshop / and to his Constable eke
He toke his wife to kepe when he was goon
To Scotlond warde his Foomen for to seke
Now faire Custaunce þat is so humble ⁊and meke
So longe is go wᵗith Childe till that stille
Sche holdith here Chambre abidyng Cristes wille /
¶The tyme is some a knave Childe sche bere
Mauricius att þe Fontston þei hym calle
This Constable doth forth come a Messangere /
And wroot to the kyng þat Clepid was alle
Howe þat þis blisfull tidyng is befall //
And oþir thynges spedefull for to sey
He takith his lre ⁊and forth he goth his wey
¶The messangere to doon his Auᵃntage
Vnto þe kynges moþer ridith swithe
And salueth here ful faire in his langage
Madame qd hee ye may be glad ⁊and blithe
And thanke god C thowsand sithe
My lady þe quene hath Childe wᵗithout dout //
To ioy and blis to all his regne about
¶Loo here þe letters sealled of þis thyng
Þat y mote bere / in al the hast y may
If ye woll Awth to youre sone þe kyng
I am youre seruᵃnt ⁊and wolde nyght ⁊and day
Donegild annswerd as now at þis tymenay
But here all nyght y woll þou take þi reste
To morow wol y sey þe // what me liste
¶This Messangere dranke sadly ale ⁊and wyne
And stolen were his letters pⁱriuyle
Out of his box as he slepte as a swyne
And Counterfeted was full subtily
Anoþer letter wrought ful synfully
Vnto þe kyng directe of this matere
Fro þe Constable as ye schal after here
¶The lre spak the Quene delyủer/reed was
Of so horrible and feendly Creature
That in þe Castel noon so hardy was
Þat any while durst ther in endure
The moþer was an Elfe by auenture
Y come be Charmes and by sorcery /
And eủer/rey wight hated here cōmpany
¶Woo was þe kyng when he þis lre had seen
But to no wight he tolde his sorowes sore
But of his own hand he wrote a yen
Welcome þe sonde of Criste for eủer/remore
To me þat nowe am lerned in his lore
Lorde welcome be þi lust ⁊and þi plesaunce
My lust y put all in thyn ordenᵃnce
¶Kepith þis Childe / albe it foule or faire
And eke my wife / vnto myn home comyng
Criste when hym liste may send me an heire
More agreable þan þis to my likyng
Þis letter he sealed pⁱriuyly wepyng
Which to þe Messanger / was take sone
And forth he goth þer is no more to done
¶O messanger fulfilled of drunkenes
Strong is þi breth / þi lymes faltren ay
And þou bewreyest all sikyrnes
Þi mynde is lorn // þᵘ Iangelist like a Iay
Þi face is turned into a newe array
Þer drunkenes reyneth in any rowte
Þer is no counsell hid wᵗithout dowte
¶O donegild y haue noon Englissh digne
Vnto þi malice / and to þi Tyrannye
And þerfor vnto þe fend y þe resigne
Lete hym endite of thy traitorye
Fy mannyssh Fy / oo by god y lie
Fy feendliche spirite for y dare well tell
Þowgh þou here walk // þi spirite is in hell
¶This Messangere comyth fro þe kyng ageyn
And att his moders Courte he alight
And sche was of þis Messangere ful fayn
And plesed hym in al þat euer sche myght
He dranke and wel his girdel vnder pight
He slepith and he snorteth in his gyse
All nyght till þe Sonne gan arise
¶Efte weren þe letters stolen eủer/reychoıı̄un
And Counterfeted letters in þis wise
The kyng cōmmaundith his Constable anon
Vpon peyne of hangyng and hie Iuyse
That he scholde suffre in noo wise
Custaunce in his regne for to abide
After iijᵉ daies and a qᵃrter of a tyde
¶But in þe same schip / as he here fonde
Hire ⁊and hire yong sone and all here gere
He schulde put here / ⁊and croude here fro þe lond
And Charge here þat / neuer efte sche c come þere
O my Custaunce well may þi goste haue fere
And slepyng in þi dreme be in penaunce
Whanne Donegild caste all þis ordenᵃnce
¶This Messanger on morowe when þᵗat he wolde
Vnto þe Castell holdith the next way
And to the Constable he þe letter toke
And when þat he þis pitous letter sey
Ful ofte he seide allas and wele awey
Lorde Criste qd he howe may þis wordle endure
Soo full of synne is many a /Creature
¶O myghty god / if it be thy will
Sith þou art rightful Iugge how may it be
That þou woldest suffre Innocentis to spill
And wicked folk to regne in ꝓprosperite
Allas good Custaunce so woo is me for þe
Þat y mote be thy Turmentour / or elles die
On schameful deth þer is no more to seye /
¶They wepen boþe olde ⁊and yong in þat place
When the kyng þis cursede letter sent
And Custaunce wᵗith a dedely pale chere
Þe iiijth day toward þe schip / sche went
But nathales sche takith in good entent
The wil of Criste / and knelyng on þe strond
Sche sayde lorde / ay welcome be þi sond
¶He þat me kepte fro þe fals blame
While y was in þe londe among yowe
He can me kepe fro harme ⁊and eke fro schame
In the salte see / al þough y se not howe
As strong as eủer/re he was / yhit is he nowe
In hym trust y // and in his modere dere
Þat is to me my saile and eke my stere /
¶Hire lityl Childe lay wepyng in here arm
And knelyng pitously // to hym sche saide
Pees litle son y wol to the noon harm
Wᵗith þat here keuerchief oủer/re hire heed sche leyde
And oủer/re his litle eyen sche it breyde
And in here arme sche lulled it ful faste
And vnto heuen vp here Eye sche caste /
¶Moþir qd sche ⁊and mayde bright Marie
Soth is it þat thrugh womans eggement
Mankynde was lorn // ⁊and dampned ay to die
For which þi Childe was on þe cros rent
Thy blisfull eyen sawe all his turment þen is þer no cōmpa
Then is þer noo cōmparisoıı̄un by twene
Þi woo / and any woo / þat man may sustene
¶Thowe saugh þi childe slayn to fore þi eyen
And yhit now levith my litle Childe ꝑper/parfay
Nowe lady bright to whom al woful crien
Þou glorie of womanhode / þou fair may
Þou haven of refuyte / bright ster of day
Rewe on my Childe / þat of þi gentilnes
Rewest on eủer/rey rufull in distres //
¶O litle Childe allas what is þi gilte
Þat neủer/re wroughtest syn as yhit ꝑper/parde
Why woll þi harde faþer haueþe spilte
O mercy dere Constable quod sche
As lete my litle Childe dwel here wᵗith þe
And if þou darest not save hym fro blame
So kys hym ones in his faders name
¶Þerwᵗith sche loked bacward vnto þe lond
And seide farewell husband rutheles
And vp sche risith and walketh doun þe strond
Toward the Schip here folowed al þe prees
And eủer/re sche pᵃyde hire childe to holde his pees
And takith here leve and wᵗith an holy entent
Sche blisseth here and into Schip sche went
¶Vitailed was þe schip it was no drede
Habundantly for here ful longe space
And oþer necessaries þat schulde nede
Sche had y nowe / heried bi goddes grace
For wynde ⁊and weder Allmyghty god pʳchace
And bryng here home / y can no better sey
But in þe see / sche dryveth forth here wey
¶Alla þe kyng comith home / sone aftir þis
Vnto his Castell of the which y tolde
And askyth wher his wife ⁊and his childe is
The Constable gan about his herte colde
And pleynle all the maner he hym tolde
As ye haue herde / y can tel you noo betir
⁊and schewed þe kyng his Seall ⁊and eke his lettir
¶And seyde lorde as ye c̄etcomaunded me
Vpon peyne of deth so haue y doo Certeyn
This messanger turmentyd was til hee
Moste beknowe / And tell platt and pleyn
Fro nyght to nyght in what place he had leyn
And þus by witt and subtill enqueryng
Imagened was by whom þis harmdede spryng
¶The hande was knowe þat þe lettre wroot
And all the venym of this cursed dede
But in what wise Certenly I noot
Þe effect is þis þat Alla out of drede
His moþer slough þat men may pleynle rede
For þat sche Traytour was to hire legeaunce
Þus ended olde Donegild wᵗith myschaunce
¶The sorow þat þis Alla nyght and day
Maketh for his wife and his Childe Also
Þer is no tunge that it telle may
But now y wol to Custaunce goo
Þat fletith in þe See / in peyne and woo
V yeer and more as liked Cristes sonde
Or þat here schip aꝑper/parched vnto londe //
¶Vnder an hethen Castell att þe laste
Of which þe name in my text y nefynde
Custaunce and eke here Childe þe See vp caste
All myghty god þat saved all man kynde
Haue on Custaunce ⁊and on here Childe som mynde
That fallen is in hethen londe Est sone
In poynt to spill as y schal tel you sone
¶Doun frōm þe Castell comyth þ̉er/re many A wight
To gawren on þis Schip and on Custaunce
But schortly fro þe Castel on A nyght
Þe lordis Steward god yeue hym myschaunce
A thefe þat had reneyed oure Creaunce
Came into þe Schip alone ⁊and seide he scholde
Here lemman be wheþer sche wolde or nolde
¶Wo was þe wrecched woman begon
Here Childe cride / ⁊and sche cride spitously
But blisful Marie halp here right anon
For wᵗith the struglyng wele ⁊and myghtyly
The Thefe fell oủer/re / þe borde all sodenly
And in þe See he dreynt for Veniaunce
And þus hath Criste vnwēmmed kept Custaunce
¶O foule luste of lechery loo thyn ende
Not only þat þou feyntest manys mynde
But verily þou wolt his body schende
Þe ende of þi werk // or of þi lustes blynde
Is cōmpleynyng // how many oon may men fynde
Þat not for þe werk somtyme but forþᵉ entent
To doon þis Synne ben eyver slayn or schent
¶How may þis weyke woman haue þe strenght
Hire to defende agayn this renegat
O golias vnmesurable of lenght
How myght Dauid make þe so mat
So yong // and of Armure so desolat
Howe durst he loke on þi dredful face
Wel may men seen it was but goddes gᵃce
¶Who yafe Iudith Corage and hardynes
To sle hym Olyfernusin his tent
And to delyuer out of wrecchidnes
The peple of god I sey for þis entent
Þat right as god Spirit of Vigoᵘur sent
To hem / ⁊and saved hem out of myschaunce
So sent he myght and vigour to Custaunce
¶Forth goth here schip þrough out þe narow mouth
Of Ivbaldare and Cepte dryvyng all wey
Somtyme Weste ⁊and somtyme north ⁊and sowth
And Somtyme East ful many a wery day
Till Cristes moþer blissed be sche ay
Hath schapen þrugh here endles goodnes
To make an ende of all here hevynes
¶Now lete vs stynte of Custaunce but a throwe
And speke we of the Romayn Emꝑper/paroure
Þat out of Surrie hath bi lres knowe
The slawghter of Cristen folkys ⁊and dyshonoᵘure
Done to his doughter be a fals Traytoure
Imene þe Cursed wicked Sowdanes
Þat att þe feste lete sle more and les
¶For which þis Emꝑper/paroure hath sent anon
His Senatour with royall ordenᵃnce
And oþir lordis god woot many oon
On Surreyenes to take veniaunce
Þei bren slee and bryng hem to meschaunce
Full many Aday but schortly þis is þe ende
Homward to Rome þei schapen hem to wende
¶This Senatoᵘur repairith with victorie
To Romeward saillyng full rially
⁊and mett þe schipp dryvyng as seith þe story
In which Custaunce sate full pitously
Nothyng knowe he what sche was // ne why
Sche was in soche Aray / ne sche nolde sey
Of here estate þough sche scholde dey
¶He bryngith here to Rome ⁊and to his wyf
He yafe hire and here yong son also
And wᵗith þe Senatoᵘur : sche lad hire lyf
Þus can oure lady bryng out of woo
Woful Custaunce ⁊and many oþer moo
And long tyme dwelled sche in þᵗat place
In holy werkes eủer/re as was hire grace
¶The Senatours wyfe hire Aunte was
But for al þat sche knewe hire neủer/re þᵉ more
I woll no lenger tarie in this cas
But to kyng Alla of which y spake yore
Þat wepith for his wife ⁊and sigheth sore
I wol retourne : and lete y wol Custaunce
Vnder þe Senatours goủer/renaunce
¶Kyng Alla which þᵗat hath his moþer slayn
Vpon a day fell in suche repentaunce
Þat if y schortly tellen schall ⁊and playn
To Rome he comyth to resceyue his penᵃnce
And to put hym in the popes ordenᵃnce
In hie ⁊and lowe ⁊and Ihu Criste besouth
For yeue hym his wicked workis þᵗat he wrouth
¶The fame Anon þrough out þe Toun is born
Howe Alla kyng schal come in pilgremage
By herbegours þat wenten hym biforn
For which þe Senatoᵘur as it was vsage
Rood hym agayn // And many of his linage
As well to schewe his hie magnificence
As to doon any kyng A reuerence //
¶Grete chere makith þis noble Senatoᵘur //
To kyng Alla : and he to hym Also
Eủer/reych of hem doth oþer grete honoᵘur
And so bifell þat wᵗithin Aday or twoo
Þis Senatour is to kyng Alla goo
To feste // ⁊and schortly if y schall not ley
Custaunces son went in his Companye
¶Som men wold sey / þᵗat at þe request of Custaunce
This Senatour hath lad þis Childe to feste
I may not tell euery Circumstaunce
Be as be may / he was þer at þe leste
But soth is it // þat at his moders heste
Byfore Alla duryng þe metes space
The Childe loked in þe kynges face
¶This Alla kyng hath of þis childe grete wonder
And to the Senatour he seide anon
Whoos is þis faire childe þat stant yonder
I not qd he bi god and by seynt Iohn
A moþer he hath // but faþer hath he noon
Þat y of woot but schortly in a stounde
He tolde Alla howe þe Childe wasfounde
¶But god woot qd þis Senatour Also
So vertuous a lever in all my lyfe
Ne sawe y neủer/ree as sche is // ne herde of mo
Of woordly women / mayde ne wyfe
I dare wel sayn / hire had leủer/re a knyfe
Þrugh out þe brest / þan be awoman wicke
Þer is no man cowde bryng hire to þat pricke
¶Now was þis childe as like vnto Custaunce
As possible is A Creature for to be
Þis Alla hath þe face in remembraunce
Of dame Custaunce ⁊and þeron mused he
If þat þe Childes moþer were awth sche
Þat is his wyfe / and pⁱriuyly he sighth
And spedde hym fro þe table þat he myght
¶ꝐPer/Pararfey thouth he þe fantesy is in my heed
I augh to deme of skilfull iuggement
Þat in the salt see / my wife is deed
And aftirward he made his Argument
What woot y if Crist haue hire hedir sent
My wife by see / as well as he hire lent
To my Contre / fro þennes þat sche went
¶And aftirnoon hoom wᵗith the Senatour
Goth Alla to see þis wonder Chaunce
Þis Senatour doth Alla grete honour
And hastily he sent aftir Custaunce
But trustith wel hire list not to daunce
When þat sche wiste wherfor was þᵗat sonde
Vnneth vpon hire feet // sche myght stonde
¶When Alla saw his wife fair he hire grette
And wepte þat it was ruthe to se
For att þe furst look he on hire sette
He knew wel verily þat it was sche
⁊and sche for sorowe as domb stant as a tree
So was hire hert shet in here distres
When sche remembrid his vnkyndenes
¶Twies sche swowned in his own sight
He wepith / and hym excusith pitously
Nowe god qd he / and his halowes bright
So wisly on my soule haue mercy
Þat of youre harme as giltles am y
As is Maurice my son : like to youre face
Elles þe fende fecche me out of þis place
¶Long was þe sobbyng and þe bitter peyne
Er þat here woful hertis myght sese
Grete was þe pite : for to here hem pleyne
Þrugh which pleyntes : gan hire woo encrece
I pray you all my labour to relece
I may not tell here woo vntil to morowe
I am so wery for to speke of sorowe
¶But finally when þe soth is wiste
Þat Alla giltles was of here woo
I trow an hundred tymes been þei kiste
⁊and suche Ablis is þer betwen hem twoo
Þat saue þe ioy þat lastith euermoo
Þeris noon like that any Creature
Hath seen or schal while þe wordle may dure /
¶Tho prayde sche hire husbond mekely
In relees of here longe pitous peyne /
Þat he wolde pᵃy hire fader specially
Þat of his mageste he wolde enclyne
To vouch safe / som day wᵗith hym to dyne
Sche prayde hym eke : he wolde be no wey
Vnto hire fader : no worde of hire sey
¶Som men wold seyn how þᵗat þe Childe Maurice
Doth this message vnto the Emꝑper/paroure
But as y gesse : Alla was not so nyce
To hym þat was of so soleyn honoure
As he þat is of Cristen folk þe floure
Sente any Childe / but it is bett to deme
He went hym silf / ⁊and so it may wel seme
¶This Emꝑper/paroure hath graunted gentilly
To come to dyner as he hym besowght
And well rede y he loked besily
Vpon þe Childe / ⁊and on his doughter thought
Alla goth to hys Inne / and as hym owght
Arrayde for þis feste in euery wise
As fer forth as his Connyng may suffice
¶The morowe cam / ⁊and Alla gan hym dresse
And eke his wyfe þe Emꝑper/parour to mete
And forth þei ride / in ioy ⁊and in gladnesse
And when sche sawe : hire fader in þe strete
Sche lighteth doun ⁊and fallith to his fete
Faþir qd sche youre yong Childe Custaunce
Is nowe ful clene out of youre remembraunce
¶I am youre doughter Custaunce qd sche
That somtyme ye sent vnto Surrye
It am y faþer / þat in the salte See
Was put alone and dampned for to dye
Nowe good faþer mercy y you crie
Sende me no more vnto noon hethenes
But thankyth my lorde here of his kyndnes
¶Whoo can þe pitous ioye tellen all
Betwix hem thre / sithe þei be þusmette
But of my tale make an ende y schall
Þe day goth faste y woll no lenger lette
Thise glad folk to dyner þei hem sette
In ioy and blis att mete lete y hem dwell
A thowsand fold moremore meryermore meryer þan I can tell
¶This Childe Maurice was synne Emꝑper/paroure
Made by the Pope / and leued Cristynly
To Cristes Chirche he dede grete honoure
But y lete all þis story passe by
Of Custaunce is my tale specially
In þe olde Romayn gestes may men fynde
Maurices life / y bere it not in mynde
¶This kyng Alla when he his tyme seye
Wᵗith þis Custaunce : his holy wife so swete
To Inglond been y come / þe right weye
Wher as þey leve in ioy and in quyete
But litle while it lastith : y you behete
Ioy of þis wordle // for tyme woll not abide
Fro day to nyght it chaungith as þe tyde /
¶Who leved euer in suche delite oo day
Þat hym ne moved oþer constience //
Or ire or talent of some kynnes affray

Nowe wol y tel of my seconde husbond
I sey I had in herte grete despite
Þat he of any other hadde delyte
But he was quytt bi god ⁊and by seynt Iohn Ioce
I made hym of the same woode a croce
Not of my body in noo fowle manere
But certenly I made folk suche chere
Þat in his own grese I made hym Frie
For Angre and for verry gelousye
By god in erthe I was his purgatorye
For which I hope / his soule be in glorye /
For god it woot he sate ful ofte and song
When þat his scho / ful bitterly hym wrong
Þer was no wight safe god ⁊and he þat wiste
In many a wise howe sore y hym twiste
He dide whan I came fro Ierusalem
⁊and lieth in his gᵃue vnder þe rode bem
Al is his toumbe not so Curious
As was þe sepulcre of hym darious
Which þat appeles wrought subtely
It is but waste to bury hym pciously
Lete hym fare wel / god yeue his soule good rest
He is now in his graue and deed in his Chest
Nowe of my iijde husbond wol I tel
God lete his soule neủer/re come in hel
And yit was he to me þe most schrewe
Þat feele I now on my ribbes al a rewe
And eủer/re schal vnto myn endyng day
But in oure bedd he was ful Fressh ⁊and gay
And þer wᵗith also wele cowde he me glose
Wan þat he wolde haue my beal chose /
Þat þough he had me bete on eủer/rey boon
He cowde wyn a yen my love anon
I /trowe I loued hym best for þat he
Was of his love so daungerous vnto me
We wymen haue / if I schal not lie
In this mater a queynt fantasie
Wayte what þing we may not lightly haue
Þer after wol we crie alday and crave
Forbede vs a /thyng and þat desire we
Prese on vs fast and þen wol we /flee
Wᵗith daunger vtter we al oure Chaffare
Grete pres at market makith dere ware
And to grete chepe is holden a litle prise
Þis knoweth eủer/rey woman wel // þat is wise
My iiijth husbond god his soule bles
Which I toke for love ⁊and for noo ricches
He somtyme was a Clerk of Oxenford
And had lefte scole ⁊and went at home to bord
Wᵗith my gossyp dwellyng in oure Toun
God haue hire sowle hire name was alsou
Sche knew myn hert and eke my puyte
Better þan oure parissh prest so mote I the
To hire be wreyed I my Councel al
For had myn husbond pissed on a wal
Or don a thyng that schold haue cost his lyfe
To hire and to a noþer worthy wyfe /
And to my nece which þat I loued wel
I wolde haue tolde his councel eủer/rey del
And so I dede ful ofte / god it woot
Þat made his face ful ofte reed ⁊and hoot
For verrey schame ⁊and blamed hym silf þᵗat he
Hadde tolde to me so grete a preuyte
And so bifel / þat ones in a lente
So ofte tyme I to my gossip wente
For eủer/re yhit I loued to be gay
⁊and forto walke in march april ⁊and May
Fro hous to hous to hire sundry tales
Þat Iankyn Clerk ⁊and my gossip dame ales
And I my silf vnto the Feldes went
Myn husbond was at londou al þat lent
I hadde þe bettir leysur for to pley
And for to see / and eke for to sey
Of lusty folk // what wist I wher my gᵃce
Schapen was for to be // or in what place
Þerfor y made my visitacyons
To vigiles and too ꝓprocessyons
To pchyngis eke / ⁊and to þise pilgremages
To pleyes of myracles ⁊and to mariages
And wered vpon /me my gay scarlet gites
Þise wormes / þise mowthes ne þise mytes
Vpon myn apparaile / frete þei neủer/re a dele
And wost þou why / for þei were vsed wele /
Now wol I tel forth what happed me
I sey þat in þe feldes walked wee /
Til trewly we hadde suche daliaunce
Þis Clerk and I what of my purveyaunce
I spake to hym and seide how þat he
If I were a wedowe / he schold wedde me
For Certes I sey it for noon avowaunce
Yhit was I neuer wᵗithout purveyaunce
Of mariage / ne of othir thynkys eke
I holde a mowses hert // not worth a /leke
That hath but oon hole for to stirte too
And if þat faile þen is al I doo
I bare hym an hond he had enchaunted me
My dame tawgh me that subtilite
And eke I seid I mett of hym al nyght
He wolde haue sleyn me / as I lay vpright
And al my bedde / was ful of verray blood
But yhit I hope ye schul doo me good
For blood betokenyth gold as was me tawght
And al was fals I dremed of it right nawght
But as I folowed ay my dames loore
As wel of þat as of oþir thyngis more
And nowe sere lete me see / what schold I seyn
A ha . by god I haue my tale agayn
When þat my iiijth husbond was on bere
I wepte algate and made sory chere /
As wyfes mote for it is þe vsage
And with a keủer/rechyf I coủer/reed my visage
And for I was purveyed of a make
I wepte ful smal I vndertake
To Chirch was my husbond born a morowe
Wᵗith neighbours þat wᵗith hym made sorowe
And Iankyn oure Clerk was oon of tho
As helpe me god when I sawe hym goo
Aftir þe beere me thought he had a peire
Of legges ⁊and of feet so clene ⁊and so /faire
Þat al my hert I yafe vnto his holde
He was I trowe of xxti wynter olde
And I was xl if y schal sey þe soth
But yit I had alwey a coltysh toth
Gaptoted I was ⁊and þat be came me wele /
I hadde the preynt of Seynt Ven9 seale
As helpe me god I was a lusty oon
And faire ⁊and riche ⁊and yong ⁊and welbe goon
And trewly as myn husbonde tolde me
I had þe best quonyam þat myght be
For Certes I am ful veneryen //
In /felyng and myn herte is marcyen /
Ven9 me yafe my luste and my likerousnes
And Mars yafe me my sturdy hardynes
Myn ascendent was taure / ⁊and mars þ̉er/rein
Alas . alas that euer love was syn
I folowed ay myn inclynacyou
By vertue of my Constellacyou
Þat made me I cowde not / with drawe
My Chambre of venus frōm a good felawe
Ȝhit haue I mars mark vpon my face
And also in a nother preve place
For god so wisly be my saluacyou
I leved neuer by noo discrecyou
But euer Folowed myn appetite
Alwere he long schort blak or white
I toke noo kepe so þat he lyked me
How pouer he was / ne eke of what degre
What scholde I sey but att þe monthes ende
This ioly Clerk Iankyn þat was so hende
Hath wedded me with grete solempnyte
And to hym yafe I al the londe and Fee
Þat euer was me yeven þer bifore
But aftirward me repentid ful sore
He nolde suffre no thyng of my liste
By god he smote me onys wᵗith his feste
On þe /Cheke for I rent out of his book a lefe
Þat of þat strook myn ere wax al defe
Stibourne I was as is a lyones
And of my tunge a very Iangeleres
And walke y wold as y had doon beforn
Fro hous to hous al þough he had it sworn
For whicche he oft tymes wolde preche
And me of olde Romayns gestes teche
How Symplici9 gallus lefte his wyfe
And hire forsook certeyn for al his lyfe
Nowgh but for openheed he hire say
Lokyng out at his dore vpon a day
A noþer Romayn tolde he me by name
Þat for his wyfe was at a somer game
Wᵗithout his wetyng he forsoke hire eke
And þen wolde he vpon his bible seke
Þat ilke proverbe of Ecc̄etcliaste
Wher he cōmmaundith ⁊and biddith faste
Men scholde not suffre hire wyfes to roile about
Than wolde he sey thus with out dout
¶ Who so þat buyldith his hous al of salwes
And prickith his blynd hors oủer/re þe falwes
And suffrith his yong wife to seke halwes
Is worþi to be hangyd on the galwes
But al for nowght I sett not at an hawe
Of al his ꝓproủer/rebes ne of his olde sawe
Ne I wolde not of hym corrected bee
I hate hym þat of my vices tellith me
And so god woot do mo of vs than I
Þis made hym wᵗith me wood al vttirly
I nolde hym forbere in noo caas
Now wol y sey you soth by Seynt Thomas
Why þat I rent out of his book a leef
For which he smote me so / þat I am deef
He had a book þat gladly nyght and day
For his disporte he wolde rede alway
He clepid it Valerie and Theofaste
At which book he lowgh alwey ful faste
And eke þer was a Clerk somtyme at Rome
A Cardenal þat hight Seynt Ierome
Þat made a book ageyn Iouynyan
In which book eke þer was Terculian
Crispus Trotula and helowys
þat was abbes not ferre fro paris
And eke the ꝑper/parables of Salamon
Ouydes art and bokes many oon
And al þise were bounde in oo volume
And eủer/rey nyght and day was his Custume
When he hadde leysur and vacacyou
From other wordyly ocupacyou
To rede on þis book of wicked wyfes
He knew of hem mo legendes ⁊and lyfes
Than be of good wyfes in the byble
For trustith wel it is vnpossyble
Þat any Clerk wol speke of good wyfes
But if it be of holy Seyntes lyves
Ne of noon oþer women neủer/re the moo
Who peynted the lyou tel me who
By god if wemen had wretyn stories
As Clerkis haue wᵗithin here oratories
Þei wolde haue write of men more wickydnes
Than al the mark of adam cowde redres
The Children of M̉er/recurie and of venus
Ben in hire workyng ful contrᵃyus
M̉er/recurie louyth wisdom and science
And venus loueth riot and dispence
And for here dyvers disposicyou
Eche fallith in oþers exaltacyou
And þus god woot M̉er/recurye is desolat
In pisses when venus is exaltat
And venus fallith þ̉er/re mcurie is reised
Þerfor wemen of no clerke be pysed
The Clerk when he is olde ⁊and may not do
Of venus workis not worth his olde scho
Þen sittith he doun ⁊and writith in his dotage
That wemen konne not kepe here mariage
But now to purpos why þat I tolde the
That y was bete for a booke parde
Vpon a nyght Iankyn þat was oure sire
Radde on his book / as he sate bi þe fire
Of Eve furst þat for here wickydnes
Was al mankynde brouth to wrecchidnes
For which Ihu Crist hym silf was sleyn
Þat bowthe vs wᵗith his herte blode agayn
Lo here expres of wemen may ye fynde
Þat wemen were þe losse of al mankynde
Tho radde he me howe Sampson lost his heres
Slepyng // his lemman kyt it wᵗith here scheres
Þrough which tresou loste he boþe his eyen
Þo radde he to me if þat I schal not leyen
Of Ercules and of Dyanyre
Þat causyd hym to set hy self a Fire
No thyng for gate he the sorow ⁊and þe woo
That Socrates had wᵗith his wyfes two /
How Exantipa caste pisse vpon his heed
Þis sely man sate stille as he were deed
He wipte his eyen no more durst he seyn
But er þat þe thondir stynt þ̉er/re comyth a reyn
Of Phisipha þat was the Quene of Crete
For schrewdnes hym þought þe tale swete /
Fye speke no more it is a grisly thyng
Of hire orrible luste and hire lykyng
Of Clitermistra for here lecherye
Þat falsly made hire husbond for to die
He radde it with ful good deuocyou
He tolde me eke for what occasyou
Ampheorax at Thebes loste his lyfe
Myn husbond had a legende of his wyfe
Eriphilem that for an ouche of golde
Hath puyly vnto the grekes tolde
Wher þat here husbond hidde hym in a place
For which he had att Thebes a sory grace
Of lyuia tolde he me and of lucye
Þei boþe made here husbondis for to die
Þat oon for love / þat oþer was for hate
Lyuia here husbond vpon an even late
Empoysened hath / For sche was his Foo
Lucyna lykerous loued hire husbond soo
For þat he scholde alwey vpon hire thynk
Sche yafe hym suche a maner love drynk
Þat he was deed or it were a morowe
And thus algates husbondes haue moche sorowe
Then tolde he me howe that Latymeus
Compleyned vnto his felowe arrius
Þat in his gardyn growed suche a tree
On which he seyde how þat his wifes thre
Hanged hem self for hertis dispitous
O leve Brothir seide this arrius
Yef me a plante of that ilke thre
And in my gardyn planted schal it be
Of latter date of wyfes hath he red
Þat som haue slayn here husbondis in here bed
And lete here lecchour dight hire al þe nyght
When the Corps lay deed in the floor vpright
And some haue drevyn nayles in here brayn
Whils þat þei slepte ⁊and þus þey haue hem slayn
Some haue yeve hem poysou in here drynke
He spake more harme þan hert may thynke
And þer with al / he knewe of moo ꝓprouerbes
þan in þis wordle growe gras or herbes
Better it is qd he to haue an habitacoıı̄un
Wᵗith a lyou or with a fowle Dragou
Þan with a woman / vsyng for to chyde
Better is qd he hie in þe roof to abide
Þan wᵗith an angry wyfe doun in þe hous
Þei been so wicked and so cōmtrarious
They haten þat here husbondꝭes louen ay
He seyde a woman caste hire schame away
Whan sche caste of here smok / ⁊and forþer moo
A Faire woman but sche be chaste alsoo
Is like a goldryng on a Sowes nose
Who wolde leeve or who wolde suppose
The woo þat was in myn hert ⁊and pyne /
And when I saw he wolde neủer/re Fyne
To rede on þis cursed book al nyght
And sodenly . iij . leves haue I plight
Out of his book / right as he radde ⁊and eke
I wᵗith my Fiste so toke hym on þe Cheke
Þat in oure fire he fel bakward doun
And he vp stirte / as doth a wood lyou
And wᵗith his feste / he smote me on þe heed
That in the floor I lay as I were deed
And when he sawe / howe stil þat I lay
He was agast / and wolde haue fled a way
Til att þe laste out of my swon I breyde
O hast þou slayn me fals thefe I seyde
And for my lande þus hast þou murthered me
Or I be deed y hit wolle I kysse the
And nere he cam / and knelyd fair a doun
And saide Dere Suster alysou
As helpe me god I wol þe neuer smyte
Þat I haue doon / it is þi silf to wyte
For yeve it me / and þat I the beseche
And yhit eftsones I hitt hym on þe cheke
And seyde / thefe þus moche am I awreke
Nowe wol I die / I may no lenger speke //
But at þe laste with moche care and woo
We felle acorded betwen vs selfe twoo
He yafe me al the bridel / in myn honde
To haue þe goủer/renaunce of hous ⁊and londe
And of his tonge and his hond also
⁊and made hym bren his book anon right þoo
And when þat I hadde gotyn vnto me
By maistrye al the Soủer/reaynte
And þat he seid / myn own trew wyfe
Do as þe luste the terme of al þi lyfe
Kepe thyn honour ⁊and eke myn estate
And after þat day we had neủer/re debate
God helpe me soo I was to hym as kynde
As any wyfe fro Denmark into Inde
And al so trewe / ⁊and so was he to me
I pᵃy to god þat sittith in mageste
So blis his sowle for his mcy dere
Now wol y seye my tale if ye wol here
¶ The Frere lough when he had herd al þis
Now dame qd he so haue y ioy or blis
This is a longe pamble of a tale
And when þe Sompnoᵘur herde þe Frere gale
Loo qd þe Sompnour for goddes armes two
A Frere wol entremete hym euer moo
Loo gode men a Flie and eke a Frere
Wol falle in eủer/rey disshe ⁊and matere /
What devel spekest þou of pambulacou
What amble or trotte or pisse or go syt adoun
Thow lettest oure disport in this manere
Ye wolt þou so Sompnoᵘur qd the Frere /
Nowe be my feith I schal or þat I goo /
Tel of a Sompnoᵘur / suche atale or twoo
Þat al þe folk schal laughe in þis place
Nowe elles Frere I be schrewe þi face
Qd þis Sompnour / and I beschrew me
But if I telle tales two or thre /
Of Freres er þat I come att Sydyngboᵘurne /
That I schal make þin hert for to moᵘurne
For wel I woot thy pacience is goon
Oure oost Cride pees and þat anon
And seid lete þe woman tel hire tale
Ye fare as folk þat drunkyn be of ale
Dame tel forth youre tale ⁊and þat is best
Al redy Sire qd sche right as yoᵘur lest
If I haue licence of this worþi frere
Yis dame qd he / tel forth ⁊and I schal you here //
Hic finitur prologus vxoris de Bathe //Et incipit fabula eiusdem uxoris //

div.l: (base) That of thy lyf yet hastow no suretee
(base) I graunte thee lyf if thow kanst tellen me
(base) What thyng is it that wommen moost desiren
(base) Be war and keep thy nekke boon from Iren
(base) And if thow kanst nat tellen me anon
(base) Yet wol I yeue thee leue for to gon
(base) A twelf monthe and a day to seche and lere
(base) An answere suffisant in this matere
(base) And seuretee wol I han er that thow pace
(base) Thy body for to yelden in this place
(base) Wo was this knyght and sorwefully he siketh
(base) But what he may nat doon al as hym liketh
(base) And atte laste he chees hym for to wende
(base) And come agayn right at the yeres ende
(base) With swich answere as god wolde hym purueye
(base) And taketh his leue and wendeth forth his weye
(base) He seketh euery hous and euery place
(base) Where as he hopeth for to fynde grace
(base) To lerne what thyng wommen loue moost
(base) But he ne koude arryuen in no coost
(base) Where as he myghte fynde in this matere
(base) Two creatures acordyng in feere
(base) Somme seyden wommen louen best richesse
(base) Somme seyde honour somme seyde Iolifnesse
(base) Somme riche array somme lust abedde
(base) And ofte tyme to be widwe and wedde
(base) Somme seyde that oure herte is moost esed
(base) Whan that we been yflatered and yplesed
(base) He gooth ful ny the sothe I wol nat lye
(base) A man shal wynne vs best with flaterye
(base) And with attendaunce and with bisynesse
(base) Been we ylymed bothe moore and lesse
(base) And somme seyn that we louen best
(base) For to be free and do right as vs lest
(base) And that no man repreue vs of oure vice
(base) But seye that we be wise and no thyng nyce
(base) For trewely ther is noon of vs alle
(base) If any wight wolde clawe vs on the galle
(base) That we nyl kike for he seith vs sooth
(base) Assay and he shal fynde it that so dooth
(base) For be we neuer so vicious with Inne
(base) We wol be holden wise and clene of synne
(base) And somme seyn that greet delit han we
(base) For to be holden stable and eek secree
(base) And in o purpos stedefastly to dwelle
(base) And nat biwreye thyng that men vs telle
(base) But that tale is nat worth a Rake stele
(base) Pardee we wommen konne no thyng hele
(base) Witnesse on Mida wol ye heere the tale
(base) Ouyde amonges othere thynges smale
(base) Seyde Mida hadde vnder his longe herys
(base) Growynge vpon his heed two Asses erys
(base) The which vice he hidde as he best myghte
(base) Ful sotilly from euery mannes sighte
(base) That saue his wyf ther wiste of it na mo
(base) He loued hire moost and trusted hire also
(base) He preyed hire that to no creature
(base) She sholde tellen of his disfigure
(base) She swoor hym nay for al this world to wynne
(base) She nolde do that vileynye or syn

div.l: (base) To make hir housbonde han so foul a name
(base) She nolde nat telle it for hir owene shame
(base) For repuyng of hem and foule shame
(base) But nathelees hir thoughte that she dyde
(base) That she so longe sholde a conseil hyde
(base) Hir thoughte it swal so soore aboute hir herte
(base) That nedely som word hir moste asterte
(base) And sith she dorste nat telle it to no man
(base) Doun to a Marys faste by she ran
(base) Til she cam there hir herte was a fyre
(base) And as a Bitore bombleth in the Myre

Loo pite renneth sone in gentil hert
Here may ye se / how excellent Fraunchise
In woman is whan þei hem narowe avise
Som tiraunt is as þer be many oon
Þat hath an hert as herd as any stoon
Which wold haue lete hym sterue in þᵉ place
Wele rather þen haue graunted hy hire gᵃce
And hym reioisen in here cruel pride
And recke not to been an homycide
This gentil May fulfilled of pite
Right of here hond a lre made she
In which she gᵃunted hym hir verrey gᵃce
Þer lakkith nowght only but day ⁊and space
Þer þat she myght / vnto his luste suffise
For it schal be right as ye wol devise
And when she saw her tyme vpon a day
To visite þis Damyan . goth þis May
And softly þis lre doun sche threst
Vnder his pelew rede it if hym lest
Sche takith hym bi þe hond ⁊and hard hy twist
So secrely that no man it wist
And bade hym be al hole ⁊and forth she went
To Ianuar when þat he for here sent
Vp risith Damyan / the next morowe
Al passid is his sekenes and his sorowe
He kembith hym / ꝓproyneth and piketh
He doth al þat his lady lust and likith
And eke to Ianuar he goth as lowe
As euer dede a dogge for the bowe
He is so plesaunt to euery man
For craft is al / who so þᵗat do it can
Þat eủer/rey wight is fayn to speke hym good
And fully in his ladies grace he stode
Thus lete I Damyan about his nede
And in my tale forth I wol ꝓprocede
Some Clerkis holden / that Felicite
Stondith in delite / and þ̉er/refor Certeyn he
This noble Ianuar with al his myght
In honest wise as longith to a knyght
Shope hym to leve ful deliciously
His howsyng is araid as honestly
To his degre was made / as a kyngis
Amonge other of his honest thyngis
He made a gardeyn / walled al wᵗith stoon
A Fairer gardyn woot I no wher noon
For out of doute I verraily suppose
Þat he þᵗat wrote þe Romaunce of þe rose
Ne cowth of it þe beaute wel devise
Ne Priapus myght not suffise
Þough he be god of gardeyns / for to tel
Þe beaute of þat gardyn and þe wel
That stode vnder a laurer alwey grene
Ful ofte tyme Pluto and his Quene
Proserpina and alle hire fairie
Disporten hem and maken melodie
About þᵗat wel / and daunced as men tolde
This noble knyght Ianuar the olde
Suche delite hath in it to walke ⁊and pley
Þat he wold suffre no wight to bere þᵉ key
But he hym silf / for of þe smal wyket
He bare alwey of syluer a Clikett
Wᵗith which whem hym list / he it vnshet
And when he wolde pay / his wifes dett
In somer sesou thedir wolde he goo
And May his wife ⁊and no wight but þei two
And thyngꝭes which þᵗat were not doon abedde
He in þe gardyn ꝑper/parformed hem and spedde
And in þis wise / Ful many a mery day
Leveth þis Ianuar and þis Fressh May
But wordly ioy may not alwey endure
To Ianuar ne to noo Creature
O soden hap / o þᵘ fortune vnstable
Like to þe Scorpion so deceyuable
Þat flaterist wᵗith þin hede / when þᵗat þᵘ wolt styng
Thy taile is deth / þrugh thyn envemenyng
O brotil ioy / o swete venym queynt
O Monstr / þat so sothly canst peynt
Thy yeftes vnder hewe of stedfastnes
That þou deceyvest / boþe more and les
Why hast þou Ianuar thus deceyued
Þᵗat haddest hym for þi ful frend receyued
And now þou hast / birafte hym boþe his Eyen
For sorow of which he desirith to dien
Alas this noble Ianuar the Fre
In myddis his luste and his ꝓprosperite
Is woxen blynde and al þᵗat so sodenly
He wepith and wailith pitously
And þer with al þe fire of Ielously
List þat his wife schold fal in some foly
So brent his hert / þat he wolde feyn
Þat som man boþe hy and here had slayn
For neyþer after his deth / ne his lif
Ne wolde he þᵗat she were no loue ne wyf
But eủer/re lyve as a wedow in cloþes blake
And mourne / as þe turtil / þᵗat lost hath hire make
But at þe laste after a monyth or twey
His sorow gan to swage / soth to sey
For whan he wist / it myght noon oþer be
He paciently toke his aduersite
Safe out of dout he may not forgoon
That he was Ielous eủer/remore in oon
Which Ielousy it was so Outrageous
Þat neyder in hal / ne in noon oþ̉er/re hous
Ne in noon oþer place neuer the moo
He nolde suffre here for to ride ne goo
But yif þat he had hond on here alwey
For which ful ofte / wepith fressh May

l.seg: And to his purpos of no suche matere

div.l: That louyth Damyan so benygnely
That she mote oþer dye sodenly
Or els sche mote haue hym at here lest
Sche waiteth when here hert wold brest
Vpon þat oþer side this Damyan
By comen is the sorowfullest man
That eủer/re was for neiþ̉er/re nyght / ne day
Ne myght he speke a word to Fressh May
As to his purpos of noo suche matere
But if þat Ianuar moste it here
Þat had oon hande vpon here eủer/re / moo
But naþeles bi writyng to and fro
And pve signes wist he what she ment
And sche knew eke / þe fyne of his entent
¶ O Ianuar what myght it þe availe
Þough þou myghtest se as fer as schippes saile
For as good it is / blynde deceyued be
As be deceyued whan a man may se
Loo Argus which had an hundred eyen
For al þᵗat eủer/re he cowde power and prien
Yhit was he blynt / as god woot so be mo
That wenen wysly þat it be not soo
Passe ouer is an ease y sey no more
Þis Fressh May þᵗat I speke of bifore
In warm wex / hath emprinted þᵉ cliket
That Ianuar bare / of þe smal wyket
By which to his gardyn ofte he went
And Damyan þat knew al here entent
Þe Clyket / Countrefeted previly
Þ̉er/re is no more to say but hastily
Som wonder bi þis cliket shal be tide
Which ye schul here if ye wol abide
¶ O noble Ouide ful soth seist þᵘ god wote /
What sleight is it / þough it be long ⁊and hote
Þat loue nyl fynde it out in some manere
By Piramus and Tesbe may ye here
Þough þei were kept / ful long ⁊and streyte oủer/re al
They be accorded rownyng þrugh a wal
Þer no wight couth haue founde such a sleight
But nowe to oure purpos / / Er that dayes viij
Were passed er þat monyth of Iuyl bifel
That Ianuar hath cawth so grete a wel
Þrough eggyng of his wyf / hym for to pley
In his gardyn / and no wight but they twey
That on a morowe / vnto þis May seith he
Rise vp my wife / my love / my lady Fre
The Turtles vois is herde my wif so swete
The wynter is goon wᵗith al his reynes wete
Com forth nowe wᵗith þin eyen Columbyne
With thy brestest / whiter þan I can devyne
The gardyn is closed alle about
Comforth my swete spouse for out of dout /
Þou hast me wounded in myn hert O wif
No spot ne know I in the / in al my lif
Comforth and lete vs take oure disport
I chese you for May wif and my comfort
Suche olde lewde wordes vsed he
On Damyan a signe þan made she
That he schold go bifore wᵗith þe Cliket
This Damyan þan hath opened þe wiket
And in he sterte and þat in such manere
Þat no wight myght hym se neyþ̉er/re here
And stille he sate vnder a bussh anon
This Ianuar as blynd as any stoon
Wᵗith Mayus in his hond and no wight moo
In to this Fresshe gardyn is I goo
And Clapte to þe wiket sodenly
Now wife qd he / here is but ye ⁊and I
Ye ar the Creature þᵗat I best loue
For bi þat lord þᵗat sittith in heuen aboue
Leuer I hadde to die on a knyfe
Then þe offende offendetv trew dere wife
For goddis sake thynk how I þᵉ Chese
Not for no Couetise doutlese
But only for þe loue I had to the
And þough þᵗat I be olde ⁊and may not se
Beth to me trew ⁊and I wol tel yow why
Thre thyngꝭes c̉er/retes shal ye wyn þ̉er/reby
First loue of Crist / and to yoᵘur self honoᵘur
And al myn heritage boþe Toun ⁊and Toure
I yeue it yow / makith Chartres as you leste
Þis shal be doon to morow er þe sonne reste
So wisly god my soule brynge to blis
I pᵃy you First / in couenᵃnt / ye me kys
And þough I be Ielous wite me nought
Ye be so depe enprented in my thought
That whan I considre youre beaute
And þ̉er/rewᵗithal / the vnlikly age of me / /
I may not Certes þough I scholde deie
Forbere to been out of youre Companeie
For verrey loue this is with out dout
Now kys me wife and lete vs rome about
This Fressh May / when she þise wordꝭes herde
Benygnely to Ianuar anon aunswerde
But furst and foreward she bigan to wepe
I haue qd she god woot / a soule to kepe
Als wele as ye / and also myn honoure
And of my wifehood þilke tendir flour
Which þat I haue assured in yoᵘur hond
When þᵗat þe prest to you : my body bond
Wherfor I wolle aunswere in þis mane
By þe leue of yow / þᵗat beth my lord dere
I pray to god þat neủer/re dawe the day
Þat I ne sterue / as foule as a woman may
Yif euer y do vnto my kynne þat shame
Or els if þat I empeire so my name
That I be fals and yif I do þat lak
Do stripe me / and put me in a sak
And inþe next ryủer/re do me drenche
I am a gentilwoman and no wenche
Why speke ye þus but men be eủer/re vntrewe
And wemen haue of you ay repfe newe
And wᵗith þat word / sche saigh where Damyan
Sate in a busshe / and Cough sche bi gan
And wᵗith here Fynger a signe made sche
Þat Damyan scholde Clymbe vpon atre
Þat charged was wᵗith fruyte ⁊and vp he went
For verraily he knowe al here entent
And eủer/rey signe þat sche cowth make
Wel better þan Ianuar here own make
For in a lre sche had tolde hym al
Of this mater how he worke schal
And þus I lete hym sit vpon þis pery
And Ianuar and May romyng ful mery
Bright was þe day / and blew þe firmament
Phebus hath of gold his stremes doun sent
That gladen eủer/rey floure / wᵗith here warmnesse
He was þat tyme in Gemynis as I gesse
But litle from his declynaciou
Of Cancer Iouis Exaltaciou
And so bifel in þᵗat bright morow tide
That in þat gardyn in þe forþ̉er/re side
Pluto that is kyng of fairie
And many a lady in his Companye
Folowyng his wife / þe quene ꝓproserpyna
Which þat he Rauysshed out of Cythea
While þᵗat sche gadered floures in þe mede
In Claudian ye may the stories rede
Howe in his grisly Cart he her Fette
This kyng of fairie doun hym sette
Vpon a bench of turves / fressh ⁊and grene
And right anon / þus seide he to his quene
Now wif qd he þer may no wight sey nay
The Ful experience so pvith it eủer/rey day
The tresou which þᵗat wymen doth to man
X hundred thowsand wel tel I can
Notable / of yoᵘur vntrouth and brotilnes
O noble Salamou ricchest of ricches
Fulfilled of Sapience / ⁊and of wordly glory
Ful worþi been thy wordis to memory
To eủer/rey wight þat witte ⁊and reson can
Þus pisith he ȝhit þe bounte of man
A mong a Mˢ men / ȝhit fonde I oon
But of wemen al / ȝhit fonde I noon
Þus seith þis kyng þat knowith yoᵘur wickidnes
And Ihu filius Sirac / as I gesse
Ne spekith of yow but selde reủer/reence
A wilde fire / and corrupte pestilence
So fal vpon yoᵘur bodies ȝhit to nyght
Ne se ye not this honourable knyght
Bi cause allas þat he is blynde and olde
His own man shal make hym Cokold
Loo wher he sittith þᵉ lechour / in the tree
Now schal I gᵃunt of my mageste
Vnto this olde blynde worþi knyght
Þat he shal haue a yen his Eyen sight
And when þᵗat his wif / / wold do hym velany
Than schal he knowe al here harlotry
Bothe in repref of here / and oþer moo
Ye ser qd ꝓproserpyna / / wole ye soo
Now be my moþers soule / Sire I yow swere
Þat I schal yeve here sufficiant answere
And alle wemen after for here sake
Þat þough they be in any gilt take
Wᵗith face bolde / þei shal hem silf excuse
And bere hem doun / þᵗat wold hem acuse
For lak of aunswere noon of hem shal dien
Al had a man seyn / / a þing wᵗith his Eyen
Ȝhit shul we wemen visage it hardily
And wepe and swere / / and chide subtely
So þat ye men shal be as lewde as gees
What reckith me of youre auctorites
I wote wel þat þis Iew / / þis Salamou
Fonde of vs wyfes Foles many oon
But þough þat he / fond no good woman
Ȝhit hath þer founden / many a noþ̉er/re man
Women ful trewe / ful good and vertuous
Witnes of hem / þat dwel in Cristes hous
With martredom / þei ꝓproved here cōmstance
Þe Romayns gestes eke make remembrᵃunce
Of many a verrey trewe wyfe also
But sere be not wroth / / al be it soo
Þough þat he seid he fond no trew woman
I pᵃy yowe take this sentence / of þat man
He ment thus / / that in soủer/reaigne bounte
Nis noon but god neyther he ne sche
Ey for verray god that is but oon
What make ye so moche of Salamou
What that he made a temple goddis hous
What þough he were riche and glorious
So made he eke a Temple of fals goddis
Who myght do a thyng þat more forbode is
Parde as feire as ye / his name emplastre
He was a lecchour and an Idolastre
And in his elde he verrey god forsoke
And yif þat god ne had / / as seith þe boke
Spared hym for his faders sake : he scholde
Haue loste his regne rather þen he wolde
I sett not off alle the velanye
Þat he of wemen wrote a butt̉er/refleie
I am a woman nedes moste I speke
Or els swelle til myn hert breke
For soth he seid þat we be Iangeresses
As euer hole mote I bouke my tresses
I schal not spare for no Curtesie
To speke hym harm / þᵗat wold vs velanye
¶ Dame qd this Pluto be no lenger wroth
I yeve it vp / / but sith I swore myn oth
Þat I wolde gᵃunt hym his sight ageyn
My worde shal stond I warne yow certeyn
I am a kyng / it sittith me not to lie
And I qd sche a Quene of fairie
Hire aunswer shal sche haue I vndertake
Lete vs no mo wordis here of make
For soth I wol no lenger yow contrᵃie
Now lete vs turne a yen to Ianuar
¶ Þat in þe gardyn wᵗith his Faire May
Syngith merier then the Popyngay
Yowe loue I best and schal ⁊and oþer noon
So long about the aleyes he is goon
Til Tilw he was comyn a yen the perie
Wher as Damyan sittith ful merie
An high among the Fressh leues grene
Þis Fressh May þᵗat is so bright and schene
Gan for to sigh and seid allas my side
Now Sere qd she for owth þᵗat may betide
I most haue oon / of þe peres þat I see
Or I mote die so sore longith mee
To eten of the smale Peris grene
Help for hire loue / þat is heuen Quene
I telle yow wel a woman in my plite
May haue to Fruyt so grete an appetite
Þat she may dien : but she it haue
Alas qd he þat I haue here no knave
That couth Clymbe / alas alas qd he
For I am blynde / ye ser no force qd she
But wold ye vouch safe for goddis sake
The perie wᵗithyn yoᵘur armes for to take
For wele I woot / þat ye mystrust me
Then sholde I Clymbe / wele I nough qd she
So I my foot may sett vpon youre bak
Certes qd he þerof shal be no lak
Might I yow help wᵗith myn hert blode
He stouped doun ⁊and sche vp his bak stode
And cauth here bi a twist and vp she goth
Ladies I pray yow þᵗat ye be not wroth
I can not glose : I am a rude man
And sodenly anon this Damyan
Gan pulle vp þe smok / ⁊and in he throng
And when þat Pluto saw þis grete wrong
To Ianuar he yafe anon his sight
Þat he myght se as wel as eủer/re he myght
And when þat he had cawth his sight ageyn
Ne was þer neủer/re man of sight so feyn
But on his wife his þought was eủer/re mo
Vpon Vponhis Eyen þe tre he cast his Eyen two
And saugh þat Damyan / his wife had dressed
In suche maner it may not be expressed
But yif I wolde speke vncurtesly
And vp he yafe a roryng and a cry
As doth þe moþ̉er/re / whan þe Child schal die
Out helpe alas harowe / he gan to crie
O strong lady store / what dost thowe
And she aunswerd sere / what eylith yowe
Haue pacience and resou in youre mynde
I haue yow holpen / of youre Eyen blynde
Vp parel of my soule / I shal not lyen
As me was taught / to helen wᵗith youre Eyen
Was no thyng better / for to make you see
Þen strougle wᵗith a man vpon a tree /
God woot I dede it / in ful good entent
Strougle qd he / ye algate yn it went
God yeve yow / boþe on shames deth to dien
He swyued þe I sawe it wᵗith myn Eyen
And els be I honged bi the hals
Sire þen is qd she / my medicyne fals
For certeyn yif that ye myght see
Ye wolde not sey þise wordis vnto me
Ye haue some glemeryng and no ꝑper/parfite sight
I se qd he as wel as euer I myght
Thanked be god / / with myn Eyen twoo
And be my trouth me thought he dede þe soo
The maze þe maze good Ser qd sche
Þis þank haue I / for I haue made yow see
Allas quod she / þat euer I was so kynde
Now dame qd he / lete al passe out of mynde
Come a doun my leef / and if I haue mysseide
God help me so / as I am evil a paide
But be my faders soule I wend haue seyn
Howe þat þis Damyan / had bi the layn
And þat þi smok had been vpon þi brest
Ye sere qd she / ye may sey as youre lest
But ser a man þat wakith out of his slepe
He may not so sodeynly take kepe
Vpon a thyng ne se it so parfitely
Til þat he be awaked verraily
Right so a man þᵗat long hath blynd be
Ne may not sodeynly so wel see
First whan his sight is come new agayn
As he þat hath a day seen I sayn
Þ̉er/refor beth ware For by heuen kyng
Ful many a man wenyth to se a thyng
And ȝhit it is al a noþ̉er/re þing þen it semeth
He þat mys conceyueth mys demyth
And wᵗith þᵗat word she lepe doun fro þe tre
This Ianuar who is gladde but he
He kisseth here and Clippith here ful fulfast oft
And on here wombe he strikith here ful soft
And to tohere his paleis / home he hath here led
Now good men I pᵃy you / al beth glad
Thus endith here my tale of Ianuar
God blis vs al and oure lady Seynt Marie

Hic desinit Fabula mercatoris
Et incipit prologus fabule armigeri left
Ex goddes mcy / seide oure hoste tho
Now such a wife / I pᵃy god kepe me Fro
Loo such sleightes and subtilites
In wemen been / for ay as besy as bees
Been þei / / vs sely men for to deceyue
And from þe soth eủer/re woll they weyue
Bi this Marchauntꝭes tale it ꝓproveth wele
But doutles as trewe as any stele
I haue a wyfe / þough she pouer be /
But of here tong a labbyng schrew is sche
And ȝhit sche hath an hepe of vices moo
Þerof no force lete alle such thyngꝭes goo
But wote ye what / in Councell be it seide
Me rewith sore that I am to hire teide
For and I / scholde rekyn eủer/rey vice
Which þᵗat she hath / / I wis I were to nyce
And cause why / it scholde reported be
And tolde to here / of some of þis mayne
Of whom it nedith not to declare
Syn wemen kon outter such chaffare
And eke my witt suffiseth not þerto
To tellen all / wherfor my tale is doo
Squier come nere / / yif it yoᵘur will be
And sey somwhat of loue / for c̉er/retes ye
Konne þer on as moche as any man
Nay Ser qd he but such thyng as I can
Wᵗith hertly wille / For I wol not be rebell
A geyn youre lust / / a tale I woll you tell
Haue me excused / / if I speke amys
My will is good and lo my tale is þis / /

div.l: ¶ In feith Squier ye haue you well I quytte
And gently I preise well youre wytte
Qd þe Frankleyn / consideryng yoᵘur youthe
So felyngly ye speke Sire I alowe the
As to my dome þer is noon þat is here
Of Eloquence þat shall / be youre pere
Ȝif þat ye leve / god yeve you good chaunce
And in vertue sende you Contynuaunce
For of youre speche I haue grete deynte
I haue a Sone and bi the Trinite
I hadde leuer . þen . xxᵗ i worth londe
Þough it right now / were Falle in my honde
He were a man : of suche discrecyou
As that ye been Fie on Possessiou
But yif a man be vertuous with all
I haue my Sone snybbed ⁊and ȝhit shall
For he to vertu lustith not to entende
But for to pley at dise and dispende
And lese all þat he hath : is his vsage
And he had leuer talke wᵗith a page
Then to Comune wᵗith any gentill wight
Wher he myght lerne gentilnes a right
¶ Straw for gentilnes qd oure hoost
What Frankleyn ꝑper/parde well þou wost
Þat eche of you / mote tell att þe leest
A tale or two / or breken his behest
Þat know I well Ser qd the Frankeleyn
I pray you haue not me in disdeyn
Though to þis man I speke a worde or two
Tell on þi tale with oute wordis moo
Gladly Ser hoost qd he / / I woll obeie
Vnto youre will / now herkenyth what I seye
I woll you not contrary in noo wise
As Ferre as þat my wittes woll suffise
I pray to god þᵗat it may please you
Then wote I wele þat it is good I now / /

(base) That with his swerd he wolde smyte softe
(base) And with that word aswowne doun she fil
(base) ¶ Hir fader with ful sorweful herte and wil

div.l: (base) Hir heed of smoot and by the top it hente
(base) And to the Iuge he gan it to presente
(base) As he sat yet in doom in Consistorie
(base) ¶ And whan the Iuge it saw as seith the storie
(base) He bad to take hym and anhange hym faste
(base) But right anon a thousand peple In thraste
(base) To saue the knyght for routhe and for pitee
(base) For knowen was the false Iniquitee
(base) ¶ The peple anon hadde suspect in this thyng
(base) By manere of the cherles chalangyng
(base) That it was by the assent of Apius
(base) They wisten wel that he was lecherus
(base) For which vnto this Apius they gon
(base) And caste hym in a prison right anon
(base) Ther as he slow hymself and Claudius
(base) That seruant was vnto this Apius
(base) Was demed for to hange vpon a tree
(base) But that Virginius of his pitee
(base) So preyde for hym that he was exiled
(base) And ellis certes he hadde been bigyled
(base) The remenant were anhanged moore and lesse
(base) That were consentant of this cursednesse
(base) ¶ Heere may men seen how synne hath his merite
(base) Beth war for no man woot whom god wol smyte
(base) In no degree ne in which manere wise
(base) The worm of conscience may agrise
(base) Of wikked lyf thogh it so pryuee be
(base) That no man woot ther of but god and he
(base) For be he lewed man or ellis lered
(base) He noot how soone that he shal been afered
(base) Therfore I rede yow this conseil take
(base) Forsaketh synne er synne yow forsake
(base) ¶ Here endeth the Phisiciens tale
(base) ¶The myry talkyng of the hoost to the Phisicien and the Pardoner
(base) Et Incipit Prologus de la Pardoner cum fabula sua .
(base) Oure hoost gan to swere / as he were wood
(base) Harrow quod he / by nayles and by blood
(base) This was a fals cherl / and a fals Iustise
(base) As shameful deeth / as herte may deuyse
(base) Come to thise Iuges / and hir Aduocatz
(base) So falle vpon his body and his bones
(base) Algate this sely mayde / is slayn allas
(base) Þe deuyl I bekenne him al at ones
(base) Allas / to deere boghte she beautee
(base) Wherfore I seye alday / that men may se
(base) That yiftes of Fortune / and of nature
(base) Been cause of deeth / to many a creature
(base) Her beaute was her deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) Of bothe yiftes / that I speke of now
(base) But her of wil I not ꝓprocede as now
(base) Hir beaute was hir deþ I dar wel sayn
(base) Men han ful ofte / moore for harm than prow
(base) Hir beaute was hir deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) ¶ But trewely / myn owene maister deere
(base) This is a pitous tale / for to heere
(base) But nathelees passe ouer is no fors
(base) I pray to god / so saue thy gentil cors
(base) And eek thyne vrynals / and thy Iurdones
(base) Thyn Ypocras / and eek thy galyones
(base) And euery boyste / ful of thy letuarie
(base) God blesse hem / and oure lady Seinte Marie
(base) So mote I then / thow art a propre man
(base) And lyk a prelat / by Seint Ronyan

div.l: (base) Seyde I nat wel / I kan nat speke in terme
(base) But wel I woot thow doost myn herte to erme
(base) That I almoost haue caught a Cardynacle
(base) By corpus bones / but if I haue triacle
(base) Or ellis a draghte / of moyste and corny ale
(base) Or but I heere anon / a murye tale
(base) Myn herte is lost for pitee of this mayde
(base) ¶ Thow beel amy / thow Pardoner he sayde
(base) Tel vs som myrthe / or Iapes right anon
(base) ¶ It shal be doon quod he / by Seint Ronyon
(base) But first quod he / heere at this ale stake
(base) I wol bothe drynke / and eten of a Cake
(base) ¶ And right anon / thise gentils gonne to crye
(base) Nay lat hym telle vs / of no ribawdye
(base) Tel vs som moral thyng / that we may leere
(base) Som wit / and thanne wol we gladly heere
(base) ¶ Gladly quod he and seide as ye shal here
(base) But in the cuppe wol I me bithinke
(base) ¶ I graunte ywis quod he / but I moot thynke
(base) Vpon som honeste thyng whil that I drynke
(base) Here endeth the reheytyng of our hoost
(base) Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
Radix omi / malorum est Cupiditas : ad Thimoid v / ᵒ / /
Lordynges qd he / in Chirches whan I pche
In peyne me to haue an haunte in speche /
And rynge out as / rounde as doth a bell
For I can all bi roote that I tell
First I ꝓpronounce whennes þat I come
And þen myn own bulles / shew I al ⁊and some
Oure liege Lordꝭes seall vpon my patent
I shewe firste my body too warent
Þat no man be so bolde Prest ne Clerk
Me to distrouble of Cristꝭes holy werk
And aft̉er/re þat þen tell I forth my tales
Of Popes bulles / and of Cardenalles
Of Patriarkes and of Bisshopes I shewe
And in latyn speke I wordes fewe
To saffron . with my predicaciou
In euery village / and in eủer/rey Toun
This is my tyme ⁊and shall / / ⁊and eủer/re was
Radix omnium malorum est / Cupiditas /
Then shew I forth / my long Cristal stones
I crammed full of clowtes and of bones
Reliques been þei / as wenen they ecchon
Then haue I in laton a sholder boon
Which þat was of an holy Iewes shape
Good men I sey take of my wordis kepe /
Ȝif that this boon be wasshen in a welle
Ȝif Cow / or Calf or Oxe / or Shepe swelle /
Þat any worme hath ete / or stonge
Take water of þat well / ⁊and wassh his tonge
And it shall be hoole / anon / and furþirmore
Of pokkes and of Scabbes / ⁊and eủer/rey soore
Shall eủer/rey shepe be hole / þat of þis well
Drynkith a draught / take kepe what I tell
Ȝif þat þe good man / þᵗat þe bestis owith
Woll eủer/rey weke / or þᵗat þe Cok hym crowith
Fastyng drynke of þis well a draught
As thilke holy Iewe / oure Elders taught
His bestis and his stoore shall multiplie
And Seres also it helith Ielowsie
For þough a man be fall / in Ielous rage /
Lete make wᵗith this water his potage /
And neuer more shal he his wif mystrust
Though he the soth of here defaute wist /
All had she taken prestꝭes two or thre
Here is a mēmton eke þat ye may see
He þᵗat his hond wol put in þis metayn
He shall haue multiplieng of his grayn
When he hath sowen / be it whete or otes
So þat he offre pens or els grotes
Good men ⁊and wemen . oo þing warne I yow
Ȝif any wight be in this Chirche now
That hath do synne / so orrible þat he
Dare not for shame / of it shreven . be
Or any woman be she yong or olde /
Þat hath made here husbond Cocolde
Such folk shal haue no power ne gᵃce
To offre to my reliques in this place
And who so fyndith hy out of such blame /
They woll come vp / and offre on goddꝭes name
And I assoile hem bi the auctorite
Which þat bi bulle / gᵃunted / was to me
¶ By this gaude haue I won yere bi yere
An . C . marke syn I was pardonere
I stonde like / a Clerk in my pulpitt
And whan þe lewde peple doun is sett
I pche so / as ye haue herde bifore
And tell an hundred fals Iapes more /
Þen peyne I me to strecche forth the nek
And East and weste / vpon þe Peple I bek
As doth a dove sittyng on a Berne
Myn hondꝭes ⁊and my tonge goon so yerne
That it is ioye / to see my besynes
Of auarice / and / of such cursidnes
Is all my pchyng for to make hem fre
To yeue her pens and namely vnto me -
For myn entent is not but for to wynne
And no thyng for correcciou of synne
I rek neuer / whan þat þei been buried
Þough here soules goo a blakburied
For Certes many a predicacion
Comyth ofte of evill entenciou
Some for plesaunce of folk ⁊and flaterie
To been avaunced bi Ipocrisie
And some for vayn glory ⁊and som for hate
For whan I dare noon oþer weies debate
Þen woll I styng hym wᵗith my tonge smert
In pchyng / / so þat he shall not astert
To been defamed falsly / ȝif that he
Haue trespased to my broþ̉er/ren / or to me
For þough I telle not his ꝓpropre name
Men shal well know / þᵗat it is þe same
Bi signes and bi other Circumstaunces
Þus quite I folk þat doth vs displesaunces
Þus spitte I / out my venym vnder hewe
Of holynes to seme hooly and trewe
But shortly myn entent / I woll devise
I pche of no thyng but of Covetise
Therfor / my tyme is ȝhit / / ⁊and eủer/re was
Radix omnium malorum est Cupiditas / /
Thus can I pche agayn þe same vice
Which þat I vse / and þat is auarice
But þough my silf be gilty in þat syn
Ȝhit can I make / oþer folke to wyn
From auarice and sone hem to repent
But þat is not my principall entent
I pche noo thyng but for Covetise
Of this mater it owght I now suffise /
Then tell I hem ensamples many oon
Of olde stories longe tyme agoon
For lewde Peple louen tales olde
Such þing can þei wele report ⁊and holde
What trow ye / þat whils I may pche
And wynne gold ⁊and sylủer/re / for I teche
Þat I woll leve in poủer/rete wilfully
Nay nay I thought it neủer/re trewly
For I woll pche and begge in sondry / londes
I woll not doo / no labour wᵗith myn hondes
Ne make Basketis and lyve þer by
Bi cause I woll not beggen I delly
I woll noon of þe apostels Countrefeet
I woll haue money / woll / Chese / ⁊and wheet
All were it yeuen of the pourest page
Or of þe pourest Wedowe in a village
Al þoıı̄ungh / here Children shold st̉er/reve for famyn
Nay I woll drynke the licour of the wyn
And haue a Ioly wenche / in eủer/rey Toun
But herkenyth lordynges in Conclusiou
Youre likyng is þat I shal tell a tale
Now haue I dronke a draught / of corny ale
By god I hope I shall you tell a thyng
Þat shal be reson / been at youre likyng
For þough my silf be a full vicious man
A morall tale ȝhit I yowe tell can
Which I am wont to pche / for to wynne
Now holde yoᵘur pees my tale I woll begynne
¶ In Flaundres whilom was a Compenye
Of yong folk that haunted Folie
As ryot : hasard / Stewes and Taủer/renes
Where as wᵗith harpes / lutes and giternes
Þei daunce ⁊and pleyen / at dice boþe day ⁊and nyght
And ete also and drunken ouer here myght
Þrugh which þei doon the devell sacrifice
Wᵗith yn þat devels Temple / in cursed wyse
By superfluyte / abhomynable
Here oþes been so grete ⁊and so dampnable
That it is grisly for to here hem swere
Oure blissed lordes boþi they to tere
Hem þought þᵗat þe Iewes rent hy not I nough
And eche of hem / of others synne lough
And right anon / þen come Tumbesteres
Fetise and smale / and yong Frutesteres
Syngers wᵗith harpes / Bawdes : wafereres
Which been the verrey devels officeres
To kyndell and blowe / the fire of lecherie
That is annexed vnto Glotenye
The holy wrytt take I to my witnes
That lechery is in wyne / ⁊and drunkenes
Loo howe þat drunken loth vnkyndly
Lay be his dougthtres two vnwetyngly
So dronke he was / he nyst what he wrought
Herodes / who so wele the stories sought
Whan he of wyne / was replete at his fest
Right at his own table / he yaf his hest
To sle Iohn þe baptist full giltles
Senek seith a good worde doutles
He seith he can no difference fynde
Bitwix a man þat is out of his mynde
And a man / which þat is dronklewe
But þat woodnes / fallen in a shrewe
ꝐPer/Parseuerith lenger then doth dronkenes
O glotenye / / full of Cursidnes
O cause furst / of oure Confusiou
O originall / of oure dampnaciou
Til Crist had bought vs wᵗith his blood ageyn
Loo howe dere shortly for to seyn
A bought was þilk cursed velenye
Corrupte was al þis wordle / for glotenye
Adam oure faþer and his wif also
Fro paradice to labour and to woo
Were drevyn / for þᵗat vice / it is no drede
For while þat adam fasted as I rede
He was in Paradice / ⁊and whan þat he
Ate of the frute / defended on a . tree /
Anon he was out caste / to wo ⁊and peyne
O glotenye on þe well ought vs pleyne
O wiste a man / how many maladies
Folowen of exces and of glotonyes
He wold be the more mesurable
Of his diete sittyng at his table
Allas þe short throte / / þe tendir mouth
Makith þat East and west North ⁊and south
In erth in eire / in water / / man to swynke
To gete a Glotou : deynte mete ⁊and drynke
Of this mater / / O poule wel canst þou trete
Mete vnto wombe / / ⁊and wombe eke vnto mete
Shal god distroien / / boþe as poule seith
Allas a foule thyng it is be my feith
To sey . this worde / and fowler is þe dede
What man so drynkith ofte / þe white ⁊and rede
That of his throte / he makith his preve
Thrugh thilke cursed suparfluyte
Þe apostle seith / / wepyng full pitously
Þer walkyn many / / of which you told haue I
I sey it nowe wepyng wᵗith pitous voice
Ther been Enemyes of Cristes Croice
Of which þe ende is deth / / wombe is her god
O wombe : o bely : o stynkyng Cod /
Fulfilled of donge / and of Corrupciou
At eyther ende of þe / / fowle is þe soun
Howe grete labour and cost is þe to fynde
Thise Cokes / how þei stampe streyne ⁊and grynde
To tornen substaunce into accident
To fulfill all thy likerous talent
Out of the harde bones knok they
The mary / / For they caste not awey
Þat may goo / þrugh þe golet softe ⁊and swote
Of spicerie / of leef / of barke of Roote
Shall been his sawce I made be delite
To make hy haue ȝhit a newer appetite
But certes he þat haunteth such delites /
Is deed while þat he lyueth in tho vices
A likerous thyng is wyne / / and dronkenes
Is full of stryvyng / / and of wrecchidnes
O dronken man / / disfigured is thy face
Sowre is thy breth / / fowle art þou to enbrace
And þrugh thy drunkyn nose / / semeth þi soun
As þough þou seidest ay Sampsou Sampsou
And ȝhit god woot / Sampsou drank neủer/re wyne
Thow fallest / / as it were a sˢ stiked swyne
Thy tonge is loste / and all thyn honest cure
For drunkenes is verrey sepulture
Of manys witte / and his discreciou
In whom that drynk hath domynacoıı̄un
He can no councell kepe / it is no drede
Now kepe you frōm þe white ⁊and fro þe rede
And namly from the white wyne of lepe
That is to sell in Fisshstrete / or in chepe
Þis wyne of spayne crepith subtelly
And oþer wynes growyng fast by
Of which þer risith such fumosite
Þat whan a man hath dronken draughtes iij
And weneth þat he be at home in Chepe
He is in Spayne right at þe Toun of lepe
Not at Rouchell / ne atte Burdeus Toun
And þen woll þei sey Sampson Sampsou
But herkenyth lordyngꝭes oo þing I you pᵃy
Þat al þe souereyne actes / dare I say
Of victories / / þrugh the olde testament
Þrugh verrey god that is omipotent
Were doon in abstinence / and in pᵃyere
Lokith the bible / and ye mowe it here
Loke Attila the grete Conquerour
Died in his slepe / wᵗith shame ⁊and dishonoᵘur
Bledyng ay at his nose in dronkenes
A Capitayn / shold leue in sobirnes
And ouer all þis / aviseth you right wele
What was cōmmaunded vnto lamuele
Not Samuell / / but lamuell say I
Redith þe bible / and fynde it expsly
Of wyne yevyng / to hem þat haue Iustise /
No more of this / For it may suffise /
And now þat I haue spoken of glotenye
Now woll I yow defende hasardrie
Hasarde is verrey moder of lesyng
And of disceite / ⁊and of cursed forsweryng
Blasphemyng of Crist / manslaughter ⁊and wast also
Of Catell and of tyme and furþer moo
It is reprefe and Contrarie of honour
For to bene holde a Comune hasardoᵘur / /
And euer the higher he is of estate
The more is he holden desolate
Ȝif that a Prynce vse hasardrie /
In all his goủer/renᵃnce and pollicie
He is as bi comune x oppiniou
I holde the lasse / in reputaciou
¶ Stilbon þat was a wise Embassetoᵘur
Was sent to Corinthe in ful grete honoᵘur
Fro lacedomye / to make here alliaunce
And whan he come hy hapned ꝑper/par chaunce ///
That al the grettest that were of þat londe
Pleying at the hasarde he hem Fonde
For which as sone as it myght bee
He yode hym hoome agayn to his Contre
And seide ther woll I not lese my name
Ne I woll not take on me / so grete defame
You for to alie / vnto noon hasardoures
Sendith other wise Embassetoures
For be my treuth / me were leuer die
Then I yow shold to haserdoures allie
For ye that been so glorious in honours
Shull not allie you . with haserdours
As be my will / / ne as bi my trete
This wise Philisophre þus said he
Loke eke / þat to the kyng Demetrius
The kyng of Parche / as þe boke seith vs
Sent hym a paire of dice of gold in scorn
For he had vsed hasardry þer biforn
For which he helde / his glory / ⁊and his renoun
Atte noo value / or reputaciou
Lordes mow fynde oþer man pleye
Honest I nough / to dryve þe day aweie
¶ Now woll I speke of oþes fals ⁊and grete
A worde or two / as olde bokes trete /
Gret sweryng is a thyng abhominable
And fals sweryng is ȝhit more repuable /
The hie god forbade / sweryng att all
Witnes of Mathewe / but in especiall
Of sweryng seith the holy Ieromye
Þou shall swere soth / / þin oþes ⁊and not lie
And swere in doom / and eke in rightwisnes
But Idell sweryng is a Cursidnes
Biholde and see / þat in þe first table
Of high / goddes hestes honourable
How þat þe second hest / of hy is þis
Take not my name / in idell / or a . mys
Loo raþer he forbedith such sweryng
Then homicide / or many a cursed thyng
I sey / as bi ordre thus itt standith
Þis knowen þei : þᵗat his hestes vnþerstandith
Howe that the second hest of god is þat
And furþer oủer/re I woll the tell all platt
Þᵗat vengeaunce / shal not ꝑper/parte frōm his hous
That of his othes is to outrageous
Bi goddes pcious hert / / ⁊and bi his nailes
And bi his bloode / that is in hailes
Viine : is my Chaunce / ⁊and þin synk ⁊and treie
Bi goddes armes / if þou falsly pleie
This dagger shal þrugh out þin hert goo
This fruyte comyth / of þe bicched bones twoo
For sweryng Ire / falsnes homicide
Now for þe loue of Crist / þᵗat for vs dide
Leve yoᵘur oþes / bothe grete and smale
But seres now woll I tell / forth my tale
¶ Thise Riotours thre / of which I telle
Long erst or pⁱrime rong of any belle
Were sett hem in a Taủer/rene / to drynke
And as they sate þei herde a bell Clynke
Bi forn a Corps was caried to his graue ///
That oon of hem gan calle to his knave
Goo bett qd hee and axe redily
What corps / is þᵗat / þat passith forth by
And loke þat þou / report his name wele
Sire qd þis boy / it nedith neủer/re a dele
It was me tolde / or ye cam here ijᵒ houres
He was parde an olde felow of youres
And sodenly he was slayn to nyght
For dronke as he sate vpon his bench vpright
Ther come a pve Thefe / men clepe deth
That in þis Contre : all þe peple sleth
And wᵗith his spere / he smote his hert atwoo
And went his way wᵗithout wordis moo
He hath . a . Mᵗ . slayn in this pestilence
And maister or ye come in his psence
Me thynkith / that it were necessarie
For to bee ware of suche an adủer/resarie
Beth redy for to mete hym eủer/remore
Þis taught me my dame / / I sey no more
By Seynt Marie seide þis Taủer/renere
Þe child seith soth / / for he hath slayn þis yere
Hens oủer/re a myle / wᵗithyn a grete village
Both man ⁊and woman / Child hyne / ⁊and page
I trowe his habitaciou be there
To be avised grete wisdom it were
Er þat he dede aman / / a dishonour
Ya goddes armes qd þis Riotour
Is it such parell wᵗith hym to mete
I shall hym seke bi wey ⁊and eke bi strete
I make avowe : to goddes digne bones
Herkenyth felowes / we been iijᵉ al ones
Lete eche of vs holde vp / his hond til oþ̉er/re
And eche of vs bicome others brother
And we woll sle þis fals Traytoᵘur deth
He shall be slayn / he þat so many sleth
Bi goddes dignyte or it be nyght
To giders / han þise iijᵉ here trouth plight
To leue and die / eche of hem for other
As þough he were / his own born broþer
And vp þei sterte / all þronkyn in þis rage /
And forth þei goon / towardes þat village
Of which þe Taủer/renere had spoke biforn
And many a grisly oth haue þei sworn
And Cristes blissed boþi they to rent
Deth shal be dede / if þᵗat þei now hy hent
And whan þei had gon not fully half a myle
Right as þei wolde haue troden oủer/re a stile
An olde man ⁊and a poore wᵗith hem mette
This olde man full mekely hem grette
And seide þus : now lordes god you see
The proudest / of thise Riotours thre
Annswerd a gayn / / what carle wᵗith sory gᵃce
Whi art þou all for wrapped safe þi face
Whi leuest þou so longe in so grete age
This olde man gan loke in his visage
And seide thus for I can not fynde
Aman þough þᵗat I walked into Inde
Neiþer in Cite / ne in no village /
Þat wold chaunge his youth for myn age
And þ̉er/refor mote I haue myn age stille
As long tyme / as it is goddes wille
