This Chapman took aꝑper/part and previly
He seide hym þus Cousyn it stondith so
That wele I see . to Brugges . woll ye go
God and Seynt Austyn spede you ⁊and gide
I pray you Cousyn / wisely þat ye ride
Gouerneth you also of youre diete
Attemperally and namely in þis hete
Betwix vs two nedith no stᵃunge fare
Farewell Cousyn . god kepe you from care
And if þat any thyng bi day or nyght
Yif it be in my power . and my myght
Þat ye woll comaunde me in any wise
It shal be doon right as ye woll devise
But oo thyng or ye goon yif it may be
I woll pray . you . for to leue me
An . C . Frankes . for . a weke or tweie
For Certen bestes þat I mote beie
To store wᵗith a place / þat is oures
God help me so I wold it were youres
I shall not faile suerly at my day
Not for a . Mᵗ Frankes a myle way
But lete þis þing be secree I you prey
For . ȝhit to nyght þis bestes mote I bey
And fare now well . myn own Cousyn dere
Graunt mcy of yoᵘur Coste ⁊and of youre chere
This noble Marchaunt gentely anoon
Aunswerd a non o . Cousyn myn Daun Iohn
Now sikerly this is a small request
My gold is youres / whan þᵗat you lest
And not only my golde but my chaffare
Take what ye like god shild . þat ye spare
But oo þing is þis . ye know it well I nough
Of Chapmen // þat here money is here plough
We mow encrece while we haue a name
But goldles for to be it is no game
Pay it a yen when it lieth in yoᵘur ease
After my myght ful . fayn . wold I you please
Thise . C . Frankes he fet forth anoon
And previly he toke hem to Daun Iohn
No wight in all þis wordle wist of þis lone
Savyng þis Merchaunt and Daun Iohn alone
Þei drynke and speke and rome a myle or tweie
Till þat Daun Iohn rideth to his abbeye
The morow came ⁊and forth þis M̉er/rechᵃunt rideth
To Flaunders ward / his Prentis wel hym gidith
Till he come into Brugges merily
Now goth þis M̉er/rechᵃnt fast and besily
About his nedis ⁊and bieth and creaunceth /
He noþer . pleieth at þe dise ne daunceth
But as a M̉er/rechaunt shortly for . to tell
He ledith his lif . // and þer I lete hy dwell
The Sonday next þat þe M̉er/rechaunt was gon
To Seynt Denys / Comyn is Daun Iohn
Wᵗith Croun ⁊and berde / al fressh ⁊and newe shave
In all þe hous þ̉er/re nas so litle a knave
Ne no wight els . but he was Fayn
Þat my lord Daun / Iohn was cone agayn
Ands shortly to þe poynt / right for to goon
This faire wife acorded wᵗith Daun Iohn
Þat for . þise . C frankes . he shold all nyght
Haue her in his armes . bolt vp right
And this acorde ꝑper/parfourmed was in dede
In myrth all nyght / a besy lif þei lede
Til it was day þat Daun Iohn went his way
And bade the mayne farewell ⁊and haue good day
For noon of hem . ne no wight in the Toun
Hath of Daun Iohn right no suspeciou
And forth he rideth hoom to his abbeie
Or wheþir hy list no more of hy I seie
This M̉er/rechᵃunt when ended was þe faire
To seynt Denys he gan for to repaire
And wᵗith his wif . he makith fest ⁊and chere
And tellith here þat chaffare is . so dere
Þat nedis most he . make a Cheuysaunce
For he was bounde in a reconysaunce
To pay xx . Mᵗ Scutes anoon .
For which þis M̉er/rechᵃunt is to Paris goon
To borowe of certeyn / frendꝭes þat he hadde
A Certeyn of Frankes . ⁊and som wᵗith hy he ladde
And whan þat he was come into þe Toun
For grete cherisshte and grete affeciou
Vnto Daun Iohn he goth hy first to pleie
Not for . to axe or borowe of hym moneie
But for . to wete and see of his welfare
And for to telle hym of his Chaffare
As Frendꝭes don / whan þei be mett in fere
Daun Iohn hy makith / festꝭes ⁊and mery chere
And he hym tolde a gayn full specially
How he had wele bought and graciously
Thanked be god / al . hole his M̉er/rechaundise
Saue þat he most in al maner . wise .
Maken a cheuisaunce . as for his hest
And þen he shold be in ioy and in rest
Daun Iohn aunswerd c̉er/retes I am Fayn
Þat ye in hele ar . comyn hoom a gayn
And if þat I were riche / as haue I blis
Of . xxᵗⁱ . Mᵗ . scutes . shold ye not mys .
For . ye so kyndely this other day
Lent me golde and as I can or may
I þank you bi god . ⁊and by Sent Iame
But naþeles I toke it vnto oure dame
Your wif at home / þe same gold ageyn
Vpon yoᵘur benche / she woot it well Certeyn
By Certen tokenys þat I can you tell
Now bi youre leve I mow no leng dwell
Oure abbot woll out of þis Toun anoon
And in his Companie nedis most I goon
Gret wele oure dame myn own Nece swete
And fare well dere Cousyn till we mete
¶ This Marchᵃunt which þat was ful ware ⁊and wise
Creaunced hath and paide eke in Parise
To serteyn lombardꝭes redy in here honde
Þe somme of golde ⁊and gate of hem his bonde
And home he goith mery as a Popyngay
For wele he knew he stode in such aray
Þat nedis most he wynne in þat viage
A . Mᵗ . Frankes . aboue all his Costage
His wif full redy met hym at þe gate
As she was wonte of olde vsage algate
And al . þᵗat nyght in myrth and clerly out of dett
Þei toke here disport for ioy þat þei were mett
Whan it was day þis Marchaunt gan embrace
His wife all newe and kist here mouthe ⁊and face
And vp he goth and makith it full tough
No more qd she bi god ye haue I nough
And all wantonly wᵗith hym she pleide
Till at the last this Marchaunt seide
Bi god quod he I am a litle wroth
Wᵗith you my wife al þough it be me loth
And woot ye why bi god as þat I gesse
Þat ye haue made a maner straungnesse
Bi twix me and my Cousyn daun Iohn
Ye shold haue warned me or I had goon
Þat he you had an . C Frankes paide
Bi redy tokyn and holde hym wele apaide
For þat I to hym spake of Cheuysaunce
Me semed so as bi his Countenaunce
But naþeles bi god oure heuen kyng
I thought to axe of hym no thyng
I pray þe wife ne do no more soo
Tell me alwey or . þat I fro the goo
Yif any detours . haue in myn absence
I paide þe þat þrugh thy negligence
I myght hym axe a þing þᵗat he had paide
This wif was not aferde ne afraide
But boldely she saide and þat anoon
Mary I defye þe fals Monk daun Iohn
I kepe not of his tokenes neủer/re a dele
He toke me certeyn gold I wote wele
What evill thedom on his Monkꝭes snowte
For . god it woot I wende wᵗith out doute
Þat he had yeuen it me bi cause of yowe
To doon þ̉er/rewith myn honoᵘur and my prowe
For Cosynage and eke for beal . chere
That he hath had / ful oft tyme here
And sith I se I stonde in this disioynt
I woll aunswere þou shortly to þe poynt
Ye haue mo slakker detours then am I
For I wol pay you wele and redily
Fro day to day / and if so be I faile
I am youre wif / score it vpon my taile
And I shall pay as sone as euer I may
For be my trouth I haue on myn array
And not . on waste bestowed it eủer/rey dele
And for I haue bestowid it so wele
For . yoᵘur honour . for goddes sake I saye
And be not wroth but lete vs laugh ⁊and pleie
Ye shall my ioly body haue to wedde
By god I woll not paie you but a bedde
For . geue it me myn own spouse dere
Turne hedirward and makith bett̉er/re chere
This Marchaunt sawe þer . was noo remedie
And for . to Chide it were but Folie
Sith þat þe þing may not amendid be .
Now wife he seide and I for yeue it the
But bi thy life be no more so large
Kepe bett þi good þis yeue I þe in charge
Thus endith my tale : And god vs sende
Tailyng I nowe vnto oure lifes ende
¶ Here endith the Shipmans tale

l.hi:
And
begynnyth þe ꝓprologe of þe prioresses tale

div.l: ¶ Wele saide bi Corpus dıı̄uns saide oure hoost
Now long mote þou saile bi þe see Cost
Sere gentle maister . Gentle Marynere
God yeue þe Monk a Mˢ . last quade yere
A ha / Felowes beth ware of such a Iape
Þe Monk put in þe manys hood an ape
And in his wifes eke bi seynt Austyn
Draweth no Monkes more into youre In
But nowe passe oủer/re and lete vs loke about
Who shall . now tell first of al this rout
A noþer . tale / and wᵗith þat worde he saide
As Curtesly as it hadde been a mayde
My lady Prioresse bi youre leve
So þat I wiste I shold you not greve
I wolde demen þat ye tellen sholde .
A tale . next yif so were þat ye wolde
Now wolde ye vouch safe my lady dere
Gladly qd she and said as ye shall here
¶ O lord oure lord / þi name howe mvelous
Is in this large vordle I spredde qd she
For not only thy laude Precious
ꝐPer/Parfourmed is . by men of dignite
But Not bi þe mouth of Children bi bounte
Parformed is . for . on/th on þe brest soukyng
Somtyme shewen . þei thyn heryng
¶ Wherfor . and as I best can or . may
Of the and of the white lilly floure
Which þat þe bare . ⁊and is amayde alway
To telle a storie I woll do my labour
Not that I may encresen hir honoᵘur
For r she here silf is honoᵘur and þe rote
Of bounte next her son . and soules bote
¶ O moþir mayde o mayde moþer . fre
O bussh vnbrent brynnyng in moises sight
Þat rauysshedist doun from the deith
Þrugh thyn humbles . þe gost þat in þe light
Of whoes vertue . whan he þin hert light
Conceyued was the faþers sapience
Help me to telle it in thy reuerence
¶ Lady thy bounte thy magnificence
Thy vertue and thy grete humylite
Þer may no tong expres in no science
For somtyme lady or men pray to the
Thou goist biforn of thy benygnite
And getest vs the light of þi praiere
To giden vs vnto thy son so dere
¶ My connyng is so weke / O blisful quene
For to declare thy grete worthynes
That I ne may þe weight out sustene
But as a Childe of Xij monyth old or les
That I can vnneth any worde expres
Right so fare I and þerfor I you prey
Gideth my song þat I shal of you sey
¶ Ther was in Assie a grete Cite
Among Cristen folk a Iewerie
Susteyned bi a lord of þat Contre
For foule vsure and lucre of velanie
Hatefull to Criste and to his Companie
And þrugh þis strete / men myght ride or wende
For it was Fre and open atte eyther ende
¶ A litle scole of Cristen folk þer stode
Doun at þe furþer ende in which þ̉er/re were
Children an hepe . come of Cristen blode
Þat lerned in þat scole yere bi yere
Such man doctryne as men vsed þere
This is to seyn to syngen and to rede
As smale Children doon in here Childhede
¶ Among þis Children was a wedows son
A litle Clergion . vij . yere of age
Þat day bi day to scole was his won
And eke also wher . as he sawe þe Image
Of Cristes moþer . hadde he this vsage
As hym was taught to knele a doun ⁊and seie
His aue Marie as he goth bi the waye
¶ Thus hath þe wedow . here litle son taught
Oure blisfull lady Cristes mother dere
To worship ay and forgete it nought
For sely Childe woll alwey sone lere
But ay when I remembr̉er/re on þis matere
Seynt Nicholas stant euer in my psence
For he so younge to Criste dede reuerence
¶ This litle Childe . his litle book lernyng
As he sate in the scole at his Prymere
Alma redemptoris mat̉er/re herde he syng
As Children lerned here antiphonere
And as he durst he drew hym nere ⁊and nere
And herkenyd ay þe worþes and þe note
Til he the First vers couth all bi roote
¶ Not wist he what þis latyn was to seie
For . he so yong and so tender was of age
But on a day his Felow gan he preie
To expoun hym þis song in his langage
Or . tell hym why þis song was in vsage
Þis praide he hym to constrewe and declare
Full ofyn tymes vpon his kneys bare
¶ His Felowe which þᵗat elder was þen . he
Aunswerd hym þus . þis song I haue herd seie
Was made of oure blisfull lady Fre
Hir . to salue and eke hit for to preie
To been oure help ⁊and socoᵘur when we deie
I can no more expoune in þis matere
I lerne song I can but small gramere
¶ And is þis song made in Reuerence
Of Cristes moþer seide þis Innocent
Now Certes I woll do my diligence
To conne it all or Cristmas be went
Þough þᵗat I for . my pmere shal be shent
And shall be beten thrise in an houre
I woll it conne oure lady for . to honoure
¶ His Felowe taught hym homward puyly
Fro day to day til he couth it bi roote
And þer . he song it ful wele and boldly
Fro worde to worde acordyng wᵗith þe note
Twise a day it passed þrugh his throte
To scolewarde and homward whan he went
On Cristes moþer . sett was his entent
¶ As I haue saide þrugh out þe Iewerie
This litle Childe as he come to and Fro
Full merily wold he syng and crie
O alma Redemptoris mater eủer/remoo
The swetnes his hert perced soo
O Cristes moþer . þat to her to prey
He can not stynte of syngyng bi þe wey
¶ Oure first Foo the Serpent Sathanas
Þat hath in Iewes hert his waspes nest
Vp swall and seide O hebrak peple allas
Is this to you a thyng þat is honest
Þat such a boy shal walke as hym lest
In your . despite / and syng of such sentence
Which is a geyns oure lawes reuerence
¶ Fro þens forth the Iewes . han conspired
Þis Innocent of out of þis wordle to chace
An homicide þerto haue they hired
Þat in an . aley had a preve place
And as þe Childe gan forth bi to pace
Þis cursed Iewe / hy hent ⁊and helde hy fast
And kitte his throte / and in a pit hym cast
¶ I sey þat in a wardrope / þei hym threwe
Where as þise Iewes purgen here entaill
O cursed folk of herodes alle newe
What may yoᵘur evil entent you availl
Morþer woll out / c̉er/reteyn it wol . not faill
And namely þ̉er/re as þe honoᵘur of god shal . sprede
Þe blood out crieth on oure cursed dede
¶ O martir . sendede to virginite
Now maist þᵘ synge ⁊and folow eủer/re in oon
The white lambe . Celestiall qd she
Of which þe grete Euᵃngelist Seynt Iohn
In Phatmos wroot which seieth þat þei þᵗat gon
Biforn þis lombe / and syng a song all newe
That neủer/re flesshly women / they ne knewe /
¶ This pouer wedowe awaited all þat nyght
After here litle Childe / but he come nought
For which as sone / as it was daies light
With face pale of drede and besy thought
She hath at þe scole / ⁊and els where hym sought
Till fynally . sche gan so ferre . aspie
Þat he last seen was in the Iewrie
¶ Wᵗith moþers pite in her . hert enclosed
She goth as she were / out of here mynde /
To eủer/rey place wher she hath supposed
Be liklyhood / hir litle Childe to Fynde /
And eủer/re on Cristes moþer . meke and kynde
She cried . and at þe laste / þus she wrought
Among the cursed Iewes she hym sought
¶ She fraineþ and she pᵃyde pitously
To eủer/rey Iewe þat dwelled in þat place
To tell hir . if here Childe / went outh forth by
They saiden nay / but Ihu of his grace
Yaf in here þought wᵗithyn a a litle space
Þat in / that place / aft̉er/re her son she Cride /
Wher as he was casten / in a pit beside /
¶ O grete god þat ꝑper/parformest thy laude /
Bi mouth of Innocentes / lo her . þi myght
This gemme of Chastite þis Emeraude /
And eke of Martirdom the Ruby bright
Þ̉er/re as he wᵗith throte Coruen / lay vpright
He Alma Redemptoris mat̉er/re gan to synge /
So lowde that all þe place gan to rynge /
¶ The Cristen folk þᵗat þrugh þe strete went
In comen / for to wonþer . on þis thyng
And hastily they for the ꝓprovest sent
He come anon with outen tareyng
And herith Crist þat is of heuen kyng
And eke his moþer / honour of mankynde /
And after that / þe Iewes gan he bynde /
¶ This Childe with pitous lamentacoıı̄un
Vp taken . was syngyng his song alwey
And wᵗith þe honour . of grete ꝓprocessiou
Þei caried hym vnto the next abbey
His moþer . swownyng / bi his bere lay
Vnneth myght þe peple þat was þere
Þis newe Rachell bryngen frōm his bere
¶ Wᵗith turment and wᵗith shamefull deth ecchon
This ꝓprovest doth . þise Iewes for to sterue
Þat of þis morþer . wist and þat anoon
He nolde no such Cursidnesse obserue
Evel . shal . he haue / þᵗat evill woll deserue
Þ̉er/refor wᵗith wilde hors . he dede hem drawe
And after þat he heng hem / bi the lawe //
¶ Vpon . this bere ay lieth þis Innocent
Biforn þe hiest Auter . whil þe mas last
And after that / þe . Abbot wᵗith his . Couent
Sped hem . to bury hym . Full fast
And whan þei . holy wat̉er/re on hym cast
Ȝhit spake . þis Child / whan sprent was þᵉ holy wat̉er/re
And songe . O . alma Redemptoris Mater
¶ This Abbot which þᵗat was an holy man
As Monkes been / or els ought to be
Þis yonge Childe to enquire he . bigan
And seide O dere Childe / I halse the
In vertue of the hooly Trinite
Tel me what is . þi cause for . to syng
Sith þat þi . throte is kit to my semyng
¶ Mi throte . is kut vnto my necke boon
Seide þis Childe / and as bi way of kynde
I sholde haue diede . ya longtyme a goon
But Ihıı̄un Criste as ye in bokes Fynde
Woll þat his glorie last ⁊and be in mynde
And for the worship / of his moþer . dere /
Ȝhit may I synge // O alma lowde ⁊and clere /
¶ This well of mcy . Cristes moþer . swete
I loued alway . as . after my konnyng
And whan þat I my life / shold for lete
To me she come and bade / me for to syng
Þis anteme vereily in my deieng
As ye haue herde / ⁊and whan þᵗat I had song
Me þought she laide agrayn vpon my tong
¶ Wherfor I synge / ⁊and synge I mote Certeyn
In honour of that blisfull maiden . Fre .
Til of my tong / taken is the greyn
And after . þat . this seide she to me
Mi litle Childe now woll I fecche the
When þᵗat þe greyn is fro þi tonge take
Be not agast . I woll the not forsake
¶ This holy Monke . þis abbot hym mene I
His tonge out caught ⁊and toke awey þᵉ greyn
And he yaf vp þe goost ful softly
And whan þis Abbot had þis wonþer . seyn
His salt teres trilled doun as reyn
And gruf he fell al / plat vpon þe ground
And still he lay / as he had leyn bound
¶ The Couent eke lay on the pauement
Wepyng and herying Cristꝭes moþer dere
And after þᵗat þei rise / and forth be went
And toke awey þis Martir . from his bere
And in a Toumbe of marbil . stones clere /
Enclosen . they þis litle body sweete .
Þ̉er/re he is now / god leue vs for . to mete
¶ O yong hewe of lyncoln slayn . also
With cursed Iewes . as it is notable /
For it is but a litle while a goo
Prey eke for . vs // we synful . folk vnstable
That of his mercy god so mciable
On vs his grete mercy multiplie
For the Reuerence of his moþer Marie //
¶ Here endith þe prioresses tale /

l.hi:
And begynnyth
the ꝓprologe of Chaucers tale / of Sere Thopas

div.l: ¶ Whan saide was this myracle : eủer/rey man
As sobre was / that wonþer . was to see
Till þat oure hoost iapen . bigan
And þen . at erst he loken vpon me
And seide þus what man art þou qod he
Þou lokest as þou woldist fynde an hare
For . eủer/re vpon þe ground I se the stare //
¶ Approche nere / and loke vp merily
Now ware you seres / ⁊and lete þis man haue place
He in the waste is shape as well as I
Þis were a popet in / an arme to embrace
For . any woman . small and feire of face /
He semyth Elvissh be his Countenᵃnce
For vnto no wight doth he daliaunce
¶ Sey þᵘ not sumwhat / syn oþ̉er/re folk haue seide
Tell vs a tale of myrth / and that anon
Hoost qd I / ne beith not evill apaide
For oþer tale Certes . can I noon .
But of a ryme I lerned longe agoon
Ȝhit þat is good qd he / þᵗat wol we here /
Som deynte thyng it is me þinkith bi his chere /
¶Her begynnyth Chauncers taleof Sire Thopas //
¶ Listenyth lordes in good entent
And I wolle telle verament
Of myrth and of solas
All of a kyng was faire and gent
In bataill and in turnament
His name was ser Thopas /
I borne he was in Ferre Contre
In Flaundders al by yonde þe see
Att Paperyng in þe place
His faþer was a man full Fre
And lorde he was . of þat Contre
As it was goddes grace
Ser Thopas wax a doughty swayn
White was his face as payn / þe mayn
His lippes rede as rose
His rode was like scarlet in greyn .
And I you / tell in good Certeyn
He had a semly nose /
His here his berd was like safrou
Þat to his girdel . raught a doun
His Shone of Corduane
Of brugges were his hosyn broun
His Robe was of siklatou
That cost many a Iane /
He couth hont at the wilde dere
And ride on haukyng bi the Ryvere
Wᵗith grey Goshauke on hond
Þerto he was a good Archere
Of wrastlyng was þ̉er/re noon his pere
Þ̉er/re any Ram schold stond
Full many a maide bright in boure
They mourne for his Peramoure
When hēm were bett to slepe /
But he was Chaste / ⁊and no lechour
And swete / as is þe bramble flour
Þat breith þe reed hepe
¶ And so bifell vpon a day
For soth as I you tell may
Ser Thopas wold out ride /
He worded vpon his Stede gᵃy
And in his hande a launcegay
A long Swerd bi his side
He pkith þrough a faire Forest
Þer . in was many a wilde best
