oᵘur outrageous trespas and offence

For well we knowen þᵗat youre liberall
gᵃce ⁊and mcy strecchen hem furþer into goodnes : þen doon oure outrageous
giltes and trespace to wickydnes /

all be it þat cursidly or dampnably
we haue agilted agayn youre high lordship

Then Melibe toke hem
vp from the ground full benyngly

and resceyued here obligacōmns and
here bondꝭes bi þ̉er/re oþis and vpon here plaggꝭes ⁊and borowes

and assigned
hem a c̉er/reten day to retourn to his Court

and resceyue the content
and Iuggemente þat Melibe wold cōmmaund to be doon hem by þe
causes aforsaid

whiche thynges ordeyned ; eủer/rey man retoᵘurned to
his hous /

And when þat dame Prudence sawe hire tyme sche
freyned and axed here lord Melibe

what vengaunce he þought
to take on his adủer/resaries

To whom Melibe answerd and seid Certes
qd he I þinke ⁊and pʳpose me fully

to disherite hem of all þᵗat eủer/re Ih þei haue
and for to put hem in exile for eủer/re

Certes qd dame Prudence þᵘ were
a cruell sentence and moche agayn reson

For ye be riche I nowgh and
haue noon mede of oþ̉er/re manys good

and ye myght lyghtly in this wise
gete you an auero9 name

which is a vicio9 þing ⁊and aught to be eschued
of eủer/rey good man

For aft̉er/re þe lawe of þe wordꝭes of þe apostill Couetise
is rote of all harmes /

and þ̉er/refor it were bett̉er/re to you to lese good of yoᵘur
own / þan to take of here good in þis mat̉er/re /

For bett̉er/re it is to lese good
wᵗith worship þan it is to wyn good wᵗith velanye ⁊and shame /

and eủer/rey
man aught to do his diligence and besines to gete hym a good name
⁊and ȝhit shall he not only besy hym in kepyng his good name /

but he
shall also enforce hym to do some thyng by the which he may
renouele his good name

For it is wretyn þat þe olde good loos
or good name of man is sone goon ⁊and passed when it is not newed
and as towchyng as ye sey . ye woll exile yoᵘur adủer/resaries

þᵗat thynkith
me moch agayn reson and out of mesure / considered

þe power þat þei
haue yeue you vpon hem self /

and it is wretyn þat he is worþi to
lose his puylege þat mys vsith þe myght and þe power þᵗat is yeuen
hym

and I sette cace ye myght enioyne hem þᵗat peyne by right ⁊and
by lawe
which I trowe ye mowe not doo

I seye I myght not put
it in execucōmn / ꝑper/parauenture

and þen were it likly to retoᵘurne to the
werre as it was biforn /

and þ̉er/refor if ye woll þat men do you /
obeisaunce ye moste deme more curtesly

þis is to sey ye most yeue
more esy sentence ⁊and Iuggement

For it is wretyn þat he þᵗat most
curteisly cōmmaundith to hym men moste obeye

and þ̉er/refor I pᵃy you
þᵗat in þis necessite ⁊and nede ye caste you to oủer/recome yoᵘur hert

For Senec
seith þᵗat he þᵗat oủer/recomyth his herte oủer/recomyth twies

and Tullius
seith þer is no þing so couenable in a grete lord

as when he is
debonaire ⁊and meke ⁊and appaisith hym lightly /

and I pᵃy you þat ye woll
forbere now to do veniaunce

in such man þat yoᵘur good name /
may be kepte and conʆser/sirued and

þᵗat men may haue cause ⁊and mat̉er/re to
preise you if pite ⁊and mcy /

and þᵗat ye haue not cause to repent you
of þing þᵗat ye done

For Senec / seith he oủer/recomyth in all evill
man þᵗat repentith hym not of his victorie

wherfor I pᵃy you lete
mcy be in yoᵘur herte

to theffect and entent þᵗat god all myghty haue mcy
on you in his laste Iuggement

wᵗithout mcy shall be do to hym þat
hath no mcy of a noþ̉er/re wight

whan Melibe had herd the grete skeles
and resons of dame Prudence and here wise informacōmns ⁊and techyngꝭes

his hert gan enclyne to þe will of his wif consideryng here trewe
entent

enforced hym anoon and assented fully to worche aft̉er/re here
Councell

and þanked god of whom ꝑper/parcedith all v̉er/retue ⁊and all goodnes
þᵗat hym sent a wif of so grete discrecou /

and whan þe day came þᵗat
his adủer/resaries shold appere in his psence /

he spake vnto hem full
goodly and seid in þis wise //

Albe it so þᵗat of yoᵘur pride ⁊and high psumpciōmn
and folie ⁊and of yoᵘur negligence ⁊and vnkunnyng :

ye haue mys born you
and trespased vnto me

ȝhit for as moche as I see and bihold yoᵘur
hymylite and
þᵗat ye been sory and repentaunt of youre giltes

it
constreynith me to do you gᵃce and mcy

wherfor I resceyue to my
gᵃce

and foryeue you vttirly all the offences Iniuries and wrongꝭes þᵗat ye haue
do ageyns me and myne

to þis effect and to þis ende þat god of his high
endles mcy

woll atte þe tyme of oure deiyng foryeue vs oure giltes þᵗat
we haue trespased vnto hym in this wrecched worlde

For doutles if
we be sory and repentaunt of the synnes and giltes which we haue
trespased in þe sight of oure lord god
he is so fre and so mciable

þᵗat he
woll foryeue vs oure giltes

and brynge vs to the blisse þat neủer/re shall
haue ende A M E N

ab.hi: here endith Chauncers tale of Melibe

l.hi: Andbegynnyth þe ꝒProloge of þe monkis tale

div.l: ¶ Whan endid was my tale of Melibe
And of Prudence and here benygnyte
Oure Oost seid . as I am a feithfull man
And by the pcious corpus madrian
I hadde leuer . þen a barell of ale
Þᵗat godleef my wif had herd þis tale
She is no thyng of such pacience
As was Melibeus wif Prudence
By goddꝭes bonys when I bete my knaues
She bryngith me þe grete clobbid staues
And crieth sle the doggis eủer/reychou
And breke of hem boþe bak and boon
And if þat any neighbour of myn
Woll not in Chirch to my wif enclyn
Or . be so hardy to my wif to trespace
Whan she comyth hoom she rampith in my face
And crieth fals coward wreke thy wyf
By Corpus bonys I woll haue thy knyf
And þᵘ shalt haue my distaf ⁊and go spynne
Fro day to nyght right þus she woll begynne
Alas she seith þat eủer/re þat I was shape
To wedde a mylk sop or . a coward ape
Þat woll be oủer/re ladde wᵗith eủer/rey wight
Þou darest not stond be þi . wifes right
This is my life but if I woll fight
And out of þe dore anon I mote me dight
Or els I am but lost / but if that I
Be like a wood lyon / Fool . hardy
I wote well she woll do me slēm somday
Som neighboᵘur of myn ⁊and þen go my way
For I am ꝑper/parilous wᵗith knyff on honde
Albe it þat I dare not hire wᵗithstonde
For she is bigge in armes be my feith
Þat shal he fynde / þᵗat hit mysdoth or seith
But lete vs passe awey from þis matere
My lord þe Monk qd he be mery of chere
For ye shall telle a tale truly
Loo Rouchestr̉er/re stondith here fast by
Ryde forth myn own lord breke not oᵘur game
But be my trouth I know not yoᵘur name
What shall I call you my lord daun Iohn
Or daun Thomᵃs or elles daun Albou
Of what hous by ye be yoᵘur faþir k kyn
I avowe to god þou hast a full feire skyn
It is a gentle pasture þer . thowe goost
Þou art now like a Penᵃnt or a goost
Vpon my feith þou art som officere
Som worþi . sacristen . or . som . Celerere
For be my faþers soule as to my doom
Þou art a grete mast̉er/re when þᵘ art at hoom
No poure Cloisterer . ne no Novis
But a goủer/renour . wily and wys
And þ̉er/rewᵗithall of broıı̄unnes ⁊and of bones
A welfaryng ꝑper/parsone for the nones
I pᵃy to god yeue hym confusiou
That first þe brought in to religiou
Þou woldist haue been a tredefoule aright
Haddest þᵘ as grete loue as þou hast myght
To ꝑper/parfourme thy luste in engendrure
Þᵘ haddest begoten full many a Creature
Alas why werest þou so wide a Cope
God yeue me sorowe but ⁊and I were a Pope
Not only þou but eủer/rey myghty man
Þough he were shore an high vpon his pan
Shold haue a wif : for . all þe worlde is lorn
Religion hath takyn vp all the Corn
Of tredyng ⁊and eke burell men . þe shrympis
Of feble trees þer come wrecchid Impis
This makith þᵗat oure heires be so sklendr̉er/re
And feble þᵗat þei mow not wele engendr̉er/re
This makith þᵗat oure wifes wolde assay
Religious folk for . þei mow better pay
Of venus Paymentꝭes þen mowe we
God wote no lusshborn pay ye
But be not wroth my lord þough þᵗat I pley
Full ofte in game a soth I haue herde sey
This worþi monke toke all in pacience
And seide I woll do all my diligence
As ferre as sownyth to myn honeste
To tell you a tale or two or thre
And if you lust to herkyn hedirward
I woll you sey the lif of Seynt Edward
Or . els first tragedies woll I tell
Of which I haue a hundred in my Cell
Tragedy . is for to say a c̉er/reteyn . storie
As olde bokis maken . memorie
Of hem þat stoden in gret ꝓprosperite
And been . fallen out of high degre
In to myserie and endid wrecchidly
And þei been vercified Cominly
Of six feet / which men clepith exametrou
In prose eke been . edited many oon
And eke in metre in many a sundrie wise
Lo þis declaryng I nough suffise
¶ Now herkenyth if it like you forto here
But first I you beseche in þis matere
Þough I be ordre tell not þise thyngis
Be it of Popes Emꝑper/paroᵘurs of kyngis
Aft̉er/re here ages as men wretyn Fynde
To tell hem some bifor ⁊and sume behynde /
As it now comyth into my remembraunce
Haue me excused of myn ignoraunce
and begynnyth the monkis tale
I woll biwaile in man of tragedie
Þe harm of hem þᵗat stonden in high degre
And fellen so þat þ̉er/re was no remedie
To brynge hem out of here adủer/resite
For c̉er/reteyn when þᵗat fortune list to fle
Þ̉er/re may noman / þᵉ cours of here wᵗithholde
Lete noman trust on blynd ꝓprosperite
Bewar . of þise ensaumples trew ⁊and olde
¶ At lucifer þough he an aungell were
And not a man at hym I woll begynne
For þough Fortune may noon aungell dere
Fro high degre ȝhit fell he for his synne
Doun into hell wher as he ȝhit is Inne
O lucifer brightest of aungelis all
Now art þou Sathanas . þᵗat maist not twynne
Out of miserie in which þou art fall
¶ Lo Adam in the Feld of Damissene
Wᵗith goddꝭes own fyng wrought was he
And not bigoten of manys sꝑper/parme vnclene
And welte all ꝑper/paradis . sauyng oo tre
Hadde neủer/re worldly man so high degre
As Adam till he for mysgoủer/renaunce
Was drevyn out of his high ꝓprosperite
To laboᵘur . and to hell ⁊and to myschaunce
¶ Lo Sampsou which þat was annunciat
By the aungell longe . er his natiuite
And was to god almyghty consecrat
And stode in nobles . while he myght se
Was neủer/re such a noþ̉er/re . as was he
To speke of strenght ⁊and þ̉er/re wᵗith hardynes
But to his wifes told he his secre
Þrough which he slough hy silf for wrecchidnes
¶ Sampsou þis myghty and noble Champiou
Wᵗithout wepon safe his handis twey
He slough and all to rent the lyou
Toward his weddyng walkyng bi þe wey
His fals wif cowth hy so plese and pᵃy
Till she his Councell knew ⁊and she vntrewe
Vnto his Foes his Coucell gan bywrey
And hym forsoke ⁊and toke a noþir newe
¶ CCC Foxes toke Sampsou for Ire
And all here tailes he to gedir bonde
And sette the Foxes tailes all on fire
For he on eủer/rey taile had knyt a bronde
And þei brent all the Cornes in þe londe
And all here Olyues and vines eke
A Mˢ. men he slough eke wᵗith his honde
And had no wepen but an asse Cheke .
¶ When þei were slayn so þrusted hy þᵗat he
Was well nygh lorn / For which he gan to pᵃy
Þat god wold of his peyne haue some pite
And send hym drynke or . els moste he die
And of his assis Cheke þat was . drie
Out of a wang toth anon . þ̉er/re sprang a welle
Of which he dranke I nowgh shortly to seie
Thus halpe hym god / as Iudicu can telle
¶ By verrey force att Gazan on a nyght
Maugre the Philistiens . of that Citee
The gates of the Toun he hath vp plight
And on his bak I caried hem hath he
Hie on an hill / wher . as men myght hem see
O noble o myghty Sampsou leef and dere
Haddest þᵘ not tolde to wymmen þi secre
In all þis wordle had noon be thy pere
¶ This Sampsou neủer/re sither . drank ne wyne
Ne on his heed coom rasour . noon ne shire
By pcepte of the Messanger . dyuyne
For all his strenghtis in his heres were
And fully XXᵗⁱ wynter . yere by . yere
He hadde of Israell / the goủer/renᵃnce
But sone shall he wepe many a tere
For wymen shall hy bryng to myschᵃunce
¶ Vnto his lemman Dalida . he tolde
Þat in his heere all his strenght lay
And falsly to his fomen . she hym solde
And slepyng in here barm vpon a day
She made to clip or shere his heer . away
And made his Foomen . all his crafte aspyen
And when þei hym fond in this array
Þᵉⁱ bonde hym fast / ⁊and put out his eyen
¶ But er his heere were clipped or I shaue
Þ̉er/re was no bonde wᵗith which men myght hy bynde
But nowe is he in psou in a Caue
Wher as þei / made hym at þe querne grynde
O noble Sampsou strengest of mankynde
O whilom Iuge in glorie and in ricchesse
Now maist þou wepe wᵗith þin eyen blynde
Sith þou fro wele art falle into wrecchidnesse
¶ The ende of this Caitif was as I shall seie
His foomen made a feste vpon a day
And made hy as her fool . to forn hem pleie
And this was in a temple of grete aray
But at þe last he made a foule afray
For . he twoo pilers shoke ⁊and made hem fall
Þat doun fell temple ⁊and all and þer it lay
And slough hy silf ⁊and eke his Foomen all
¶ This is to sey the Princes eủer/reychou
And eke thre thousand bodies were þ̉er/re slayn
Wᵗith fallyng of þe grete temple of stoon
Of Sampsou now woll I no more sayn
By ware be þis Ensaumple old ⁊and playn
Þat no man tell his Councell / to his wif
Of which þing he wold haue secre fayn
If þat it touche his lymes or his lif
¶ Of Ercules the soủer/reaign Conquerour .
Syngyn his werkis laude ⁊and high renoun
For in his tyme of strenght he was þᵉ flour
He slough and rafte the skyn fro þe lyou
He of Centaures leide the boost a doun
He arpies slough . he cruell brides felle
The golden apples rafte of þe dragoun
He drowe out of Cerberus / þe hound of helle /
¶ He slough the cruell Tiraunt Bisirus
⁊and made his hors to frete hym . flessh and boon
He slough the Firy Serpent Veninus
Of Achilles two hornes he brake oon
And he slough Cacus in a caue of stoon
He slough þe Geaunt Antheu9 þe stronge .
He slough þe grisly boer . and þat anoon
And bare the heed on his necke longe /
¶ Was neủer/re wight / sith þe wordle bigan
Þat slough so many Monstres as did he
Þrough out þis wide wordle his name ran
What for . his strenght ⁊and for . his high bounte
And eủer/rey Realme went he for to see
He was so strong þᵗat no man myght / hym lette
Atte boþe þe wordles endes as seith Throple
In stede of bondis he a Pilere sette
¶ A lēmman hadde this noble Champiou
Þat hight Dianire as Fressh as may
As as þise Clerkis maken menciou
She had hym sent ashert / Fressh ⁊and gay
Allas þis sherte / allas and wele away
Envenemyd was so subtelly wᵗith all
Þat or þᵗat he had wered it half a day
It made his Flessh frōm his bonys Fall
¶ But naþeles some Clerkis hire excusen
By oon þat hight / Nessus þat it maked
Be as be may / I woll here not accusen
But / on his bak / þᵉ sherte he wered all naked
Till þᵗat his flessh . was for þe venim blaked
And when he sawe noon othir . remedie
In hoote colis he had hym silf raked
For wᵗith no venim deigned hym to die
¶ Thus starf þis myghty worþi Ercules
Loo who may trust on Fortune any throwe
For . hy þᵗat folowed all þis wordle for pees
Or . he were ware / is ofte leide full lowe
Full wis is he þat can hym self knowe
Be ware For . whan þᵗat fortune lust to glose .
Þen waitith she here man to oủer/rethrowe
By suche awey as he wold leest suppose /
¶ The myghty trone the pcious tresor .
The glorious septre . þe riall mageste /
That hadde the kynge Nabugodonosor
With tunge may vnnethe descryued be
He twies wan Ierusalem the Citee
Þe vessell of þe temple he wᵗith hym ladde
Atte Babiloine was his soủer/reaign see
In which his glorie ⁊and his delite he hadde /
¶ The Fairest Children of all þe blood riall
Of Israell he dede gelde anoon
And made eche of hem to be his thrall
Amongis oþer . Danyell was oon
Þat was þe wisest Childe of eủer/reychon
For . he þe dremes of þe kyng expouned
Wher . as in Chaldre Clerk . was þ̉er/re noon .
Þat wiste to what fyn his dremes souned
¶ This proude kyng lete make . a statue of gold
Lxᵗⁱ cubites longe and vij in brede
To which Image . he boþe yong ⁊and olde
Cōmmaunded to loute and haue in drede
Or . in a Furneis full of flames reede
He shall be brent þat woll not obeie
But / neủer/re wolde assent / to þat rede
Danyel ne his Felawes tweie
¶ This kyng of kyngꝭes proud was ⁊and elate
He wende þat god þat sitte in mageste
Ne myght hym not . bereue of his estate
But . sodeynly . he loste his dignite
And like a beest / hym semed for to be
And ete hay . as an oxe ⁊and lay þer . oute
In reyn with . wilde bestis walked he
Till a c̉er/reteyn tyme was comen . aboute
¶ And like an Egles feders . wax his heres
His nailes like a briddes clawes were
Till god releued hym a c̉er/reteyn yeres
And yaf hym witte / ⁊and þan . wᵗith many a tere
He thankid god / and eủer/re his lif in feere
Was he to doon amys or . more trespace
And till þat tyme he leid was in his beere
He knewe þᵗat god was full of myght ⁊and gᵃce
¶ His sone which þat hight Balthasar .
Þat helde þe regne aft̉er/re his faþers day
He bi his Father cowde not be ware
For proude he was of hert / and of aray
And eke an Idolastre was he ay
His high astate assured hym in pride
But fortune cast / hy doun ⁊and þer . he lay
And sodeynly / his regne gan . diuide
¶ A Feste he made vnto his lordꝭes all
Vpon a tyme / and made hem bliþe be
And þen his officers gan he call
Go bryng forth þe vessels qd he .
Which þat my faþ̉er/re in his ꝓprosperite
Out of þe temple of Irlm berafte
And to oure high goddꝭes thanke we
Of honoᵘur þat oure eldres wᵗith vs lafte /
¶ His wif his lordis and his Concubines
Ay drunkyn whils þer appetitis laste
Out of þise noble vessels sundry wynes
And on a wall þis kyng his eyen caste /
And sawe an hand armeles þᵗat wrote full faste
For Fere of which he quoke ⁊and sighed sore
Þis hond þat made Balthasar so agaste
Wroot mane techel . fares / and no more
¶ In all þat londe Magicien was þ̉er/re noon
Þat coude expoune what þis lre ment
But Danyell expouned it anoon
And seid kyng . god þi father sent
Glorie and honoᵘur regne tresour and rent
And he was proud and noþing god dradde
And þ̉er/refor god grete wreche vpon hem sent
And hym berafte þe regne þat / he hadde
¶ He was out cast of manys companie
With assis was his habitaciou
And ete hay as beestꝭes in weet ⁊and drie
Till þat he knewe bi gᵃce and bi resou
Þat god of heuen . hadde domynaciou
Of eủer/rey regne and eủer/rey Creature
And þen had god of hym compassiou
And hym restored his regne / ⁊and his figure
¶ Eke þou þat art his son . art proude also
And knowest all thise thyngis verily
And art rebell / to god / and art / his Foo .
Þᵘ dranke also of his vessels . boldly
Þi wif eke and þi wenches . synfully
Dranke of þe same vessels . sundry winis
And heriest fals goddis . cursidly
Þ̉er/refor to the shape full grete pyne is
¶ This hand was sent frōm god / þᵗat on þe wall
Wrote mane techel fares truste to me
Thy regne is doon / þou werest not / at all
Diuided is þi regne . and it shall be
To Medes and to ꝑper/parces yeuen qd he
And þilk same nyght / þis kyng was slawe
And darius ocupieth his degre
Þough he þ̉er/reto had no right ne lawe
¶ Lordyngꝭes ensaumples . here bi mow ye take
Howe þat in lordship is no sikernes
For whan Fortune woll a man forsake
She berith a wey his regne ⁊and his ricches
And eke his Frendis boþe more and les
For what men hath Frendꝭes þrough Fortune
Mis hap woll make hem Enemyes as I ges
Þis ꝓproủer/rebe is full soth and full cōmmune
¶ Cenobia of Palymerie Quene
As wretyn ꝑper/parciens of here noblesse
So worþi was in armes and so kene
Þat no wight passed here in hardinesse
Ne in lynage / ne in oþir gentilnesse
Of kyngꝭes blood of ꝑper/parce is sche descendid
I seie not þat sche / had moste fairnesse
But of here shap she myght not / be amendid
¶ From hire Childehode I fynde þat she fledde
Office of women / and to wode sche went
And many a wilde hertꝭes blood sche shedde
Wᵗith arowes brood þat she to hym hem sent
She was so swifte / þat she anoon . hem hent
And when . sche was elder . sche wolde kille
Lyons libardis and beres all to rente
And in here armes welde hem at here wille /
¶ She durst wilde bestis dennes seke
And renne into mountayns all þe nyght
And slepe vnder þe busshes ⁊and she coude eke
Wrastle bi verrey force / ⁊and be verre myght
Wᵗith any yonge man . were he neủer/re so wight /
Þer . myght no thyng man in here armes stonde
She kapte here maidenhode frōm eủer/rey wight /
To no man deyned here for . to be bonde /
¶ But at þᵉ laste . hir . Frendꝭes haue here maried
To Onedake a Prince of that Contre
All were it so þat she hem longe taried
And ye shall vndirstond how that he
Had þat such fantasies . as hadde sche
But naþeles when þei were knyt in fere
They lyued in ioy and in felicite
For eche of hem had oþ̉er/re leef and dere /
¶ Safe o / thyng þat sche wold neủer/re assente
Bi no wey þat he shold bi hire lie
But ones / for it was hire playn entent
To haue a Childe / þe worlde to multiplie
And also sone / as þat she myght aspie
Þat sche was not wᵗith Childe wᵗith þat dede
Then wold she suffre hym doo his fantesie
Eftsone and not but ones out of drede /
¶ And if sche were wᵗith Childe at þilke cast
No more sholde he pley thilke game
Till fully xl. daies weren past
Þen wold she ones suffre hy to do þᵉ same
All were þis Onedake wilde or . tame
He gate no more of hir . For þus sche seide
It was to wyves lecherie and shame
In oþ̉er/re case / if þᵗat men wᵗith hem pleyde /
¶ Two sones bi þis Onedake had sche
The which she kept in v̉er/retue and lecture
But nowe vnto oure tale turne we
I sey so worschipfull a Creature
And wis þ̉er/re wᵗith and large wᵗith mesure
So penyble in þe werre ⁊and curteis eke
Ne more laboᵘur myght in werre endure
Was noon þough all þis worlde men shold seke
¶ Hire riche aray ne myght not be tolde
As well in vessell as in here clothyng
Sche was all cladde in perrey ⁊and in golde
And eke sche lefte not for noon huntyng
To haue of sundry tungis full knowyng
Whan þat sche leiser / had ⁊and for to entende
To lerne bokis was all here likyng
How sche in v̉er/retu myght here lif expende
¶ And shortly of þis storie for to trete
So doughty was here husbond ⁊and eke sche
Þat þei conquered many regnes grete
In the Orient wᵗith many a faire Cite
Apꝑper/partenent vnto the mageste
Of Rome ⁊and wᵗith strong hand held hem fast
Ne neủer/re myght here foomen don hem Fle
Ay while þat Onedakes . daies last /
¶ Hire batailles who so lust hem forto rede
Agayn Sapor the kyng and oþir moo
And howe þat all þis ꝓprocesse fell in dede
Whi sche conquered ⁊and what title had þ̉er/reto
And aftir of hir myschef and here woo /
How þᵗat sche was biseged and I take /
Lete hym vnto my maister Petrake go
Þat writith I nough of þis I vndertake
¶ When Onedake was dede sche myghtily
The regnes helde / and wᵗith here ꝓpropre hond
Agayns here foos sche faught full cruelly
Þat þ̉er/re nas kyng ne prince in all þat lond
Þat he was not glad / if he þat gᵃce fond
Þat sche ne wold vpon his londe werreie
To here þei made aliaunce by bonde
To been in pees ⁊and lete her ride and pleie .
¶ The Emꝑper/parour of Rome Claudius
Ne hym biforn the Romayn Galien
Ne durste neủer/re been . so Coragus
Ne noon Ermyn ne noon Egipcien
Ne Surreen . ne noon Arrabien
Wᵗithin the feldes . þᵗat durst wᵗith here fight /
Lest þᵗat sche wold hem . wᵗith here hondꝭes slayn
Or wᵗith hir mayne put hem to Flight
¶ In kyngis habite went here sonys two
As heires of here faþers regnes all
And hermanno and Thimalao .
Hir names were as ꝑper/parciens hem call
Bot ay fortune had in hir . hony gall
Þis myghty Quene may no while endure
Fortune out here regne made here fall
To wrecchidnes and to mysauenture
¶ Aurelyan whan þat þe goủer/renᵃnce
Of Rome cam . in to his handis tweye
He shope vpon þis quene to do veniaunce
And with his legions he toke his weye .
Toward Cenobia ⁊and shortly for to seye .
He made hir fle / and at þe last / her hent
And fettred here / and eke here Children tweye
And wh wan þe londe / ⁊and home to Rome he went
¶ Amongis oþir þingꝭes that he wan
Hir chare þᵗat was wᵗith gold wrought ⁊and perre
This grete Romayn this Aurelyan
Hath wᵗith hym lad / for men shold it see
Biforn his Triumphe . walkith sche
Wᵗith gilte Cheynes on hir nek hangyng .
Crowned was sche / as aft̉er/re hir degre
And full of perre / chargid here clothyng
¶ Allas Fortune sche þat whilom was
Dredfull / to kyngis and to Emꝑper/paroures
Now gawreth all þe peple / on hir allas
And sche þat helmed was in starke shoures
And bi force wan Townes . strong ⁊and Towres
Shall on here heed / were a vitrimite /
And sche þat bare the Ceptre full of Floures
Shall bere a distaf hir coste for to quite
¶ All þough that Nero were vicious
As any Fende þat hath full low a doun
Ȝhit he as tellith vs Swetoneus
This wide wordle had in subiecciou
Boþe East and west North ⁊and Septēmtrioun
Of Rubies Saphers and of Perles white
Were all his cloþis broided vp and doun
For he in gemmes / gretly gan delite
¶ More dilicate more pompous of aray
More Proud was neủer/re Emꝑper/paroᵘur þen hēm
Þat ilke cloth þᵗat he had wered oo day
Aft̉er/re þat tyme / he wolde it neủer/re see
Nettes of gold threde had he gret plente
To Fissh wᵗithin Tibre / when hy lust to pleie
His lustes were as lawe in his degre
For Fortune as Frend hym wold obeie
¶ He Rome brent For his delicasie
The Senatours he slough vpon a day
To here how þᵗat men wolde wepe ⁊and crye
And slough his broþ̉er/re / and bi his Suster . lay
His moþer made he in pitous aray
For he hir wombe slitte to beholde
Wher he cōmceyued was . so weleaway
That he so litle of his moþer tolde /
¶ No teere out of his eyen for þat sight /
Ne came // but seid a fair . woman was sche
Grete wonþ̉er/re is / how þᵗat he coude or . myght
Be domys man . of here deede beaute
The wyne for to bryng hym cōmmaunded he
And dranke anou / noon oþir . woo he made
Whan myght is Ioyned vnto Cruelte
Allas to depe woll the venym wade
¶ In youth a mast̉er/re had this Emꝑper/paroure
To teche hym lecture and curtesie
For of moralite he was þe floure
As in his tyme but if bokes lye
And while þis mast̉er/re had of hy mastrie
He maked hym . so kounyng and so souple
Þat longe tyme it was . or . þat tirannye
Or . any vice . durst in hym vncouple /
¶ This Seneka of which þat I deuyse
Bi cause Nero had of hym such drede .
For he frōm vices . wold hym ay chastise
Discretly as by word ⁊and not by dede
Sir . wold he sey / an Emꝑper/parour mote / nede
By v̉er/retuous . and hate Tirannye
For which in a bath he made hym to blede
On both his armes / till he moste die
¶ This Nero hadde eke of Custemaunce
In youth a geyns his mast̉er/re for to rise
Which aftirward hy þought a gᵉte greuᵃnce
Þ̉er/refor . he made hym deyen in this wise
But naþeles this Seneka the wise
Chese in a bath to die in þis mane
Raþ̉er/re then to haue a noþir turmentrie
And þus hath Nero slayn his mast̉er/re dere /
¶ Now fell it so þat Fortune liste no longer
The high pride of Nero to cherice
For þough he were strong ȝhit was sche streng
Sche þought þus . be god I am to nyce
To sette a man þᵗat is fulfilled of vice
In high degre / and Emꝑper/paroᵘur hym call
By god out of his sete I will hy trice
Whan he leste wenyth / sonest shal he fall
¶ The peple roos vp on hym an oo nyght
For . his defaute / ⁊and whan he it aspied
Out at his dores anoon . he hath hy dight
Allone / ⁊and þ̉er/re as he went / haue been . alyed
He knokked fast / and ay þe more he cried
The Faster . shit þei here dores all
Tho wiste he well / he had hy silf mysgied
And went his wey / no leng durst he call
¶ The peple cried and rombled vp ⁊and doun
That / wᵗith his eres herd he how þei seid
Wher is þis fals Tiraunt þis Nerou
For . feere he . all most / out of his witte bᵃyd
And to his goddis pitously he praid
For socoᵘur / but it myght / not betide
For drede of þis hym þought þt he deid
And ran into a gardyn hym to hide
¶ And in þis gardyn fond he Clerkis tweie
That sate by a Fire grete and rede .
And to þis Clerkis he gan to praie
To sle hym / and gerde of his hede
Þat to his body / whan þᵗat he were dede
Were no despite doon / for his defame
Hy self he slough / he coude no bett̉er/re rede
Of which Fortune lough / ⁊and had a game
Was neủer/re Capitayn . vnder a kyng
Þat regnes moo / put in subiecciou
Ne streng was in felde of all þinge
As in his tyme / ne grett̉er/re of renoun
Ne mor pompous in high psumpciou
Then Olyferne / which fortune ay kiste
So likerously / ⁊and lad hym vp and doun
Till þat his heed was of . er . þᵗat he wiste /
¶ Not only þᵗat this worlde had hym in awe
For lesyng of ricches . or . liberte
But made eủer/rey man reneie his lawe .
Nabugodonosor . was god seid he
Noon oþir god shold honoured be
Ageyns his heste / no wight dare trespace
Saue in Bethulia a stronge Citee
Wher / Eliachim / a pste was of þᵗat place
¶ But take kepe of the deth of Oliferne
Amyddes his hoost / he drunk lay a nyght
Wᵗithin his tent large as is a berne
And ȝhit for al his pompe ⁊and all his myght
Iudith a woman as he lay vpright /
Slepyng / his heed of smote / ⁊and from his tent
Full puyly sche stale / from eủer/rey wight /
And wᵗith his heed vnto hir . Toun sche went /
¶ What nedith it of kynge Antiochus
To tell his high roiall mageste
His high pride / his werkis venemus
For suche a noþ̉er/re was þ̉er/re non as he
Rede which þat he was in Machabee
And rede the pround wordꝭes þᵗat he seid
And why he fell from high ꝓprosperite /
And in an hille how wrecchidly he deid
¶ Fortune hatth so enhaunsed hym in pride
That verely he wende he myght atteyne
Vnto the sterres oon euery side
And in balaunce wey eche mountaigne
And all the flodes of þe see restreyne
And goddis peple had he most in hate
Hem wold he sle / in turment ⁊and in peine
Wenyng þat god ne myght his pⁱride abate /
¶ And for þat Nichanor . and Thimothe
Wᵗith Iewes were venquisshed myghtely
Vnto the Iewes suche an hate had he
Þat he bade greithe his chare full hastily
And swore and said full dispitously
Vnto Irlm he wolde eftsone
To wreke his ire on it full cruelly
But of his pʳpos he was lette full sone /
¶ God for . his manace hym so sore smote
Wᵗith Invysible wounde / ay incurable
Þat in his guttis . it carf so and bote
Þat his peynes were Importable
⁊and c̉er/reteynly þe wrecche was vnresnable
For many a manys guttꝭes did he peyne
But frōm his pʳpos cursed and dampnable
For al . his smert he wold hy not restreyne /
¶ But bade anon . apparaill his ooste
And sodenly or he were of it ware
God daunted all his pride and boste
For . he so sore / fell out of his Chare
Þat it is lymes and his skyn to tare
So þat he neider . myght go ne ride
But in a Chare men about hym bare /
All forbrosed boþe bak and side /
¶ The wreche of god smote hy so cruelly
Þat þrugh his body wicked wormes crepte
And þ̉er/rewᵗithall he stanke so horribly
Þᵗat noon of all his meyne þat hym kepte /
Wheþir þat he woke . or . elles slepte
Ne myght not / þe stynke of hym endure
In þis myschef he wailed ⁊and eke wepte
And knewe god // lord of eủer/rey Creature
¶ To all his hoost and to hym silf also
Full lothsom was þe stynke of his careyne
No man ne myght bere hym to ne Fro
And in þis stynke ⁊and in þis horrible peyne
He starf full wrecchidly in a mountaigne
Thus hath þis Robber . and þis homicide
That many a man made to wepe ⁊and pleyne
Such guerdou as bihouyth vnto pride /
¶ The storie of Alexandre is so comune
Þat eủer/rey wight that hath discreciou
Hath herde somwhat of his Fortune
Þis wilde wordle as in conclusiou
He wan bi strenght or for his high renoun
Þei were glad for peis vnto hym sende
The pride of man ⁊and beste he leide adoun
Wher so he came vnto þe wordlis ende
¶ Comꝑper/parisou myght neủer/re ȝhit be maked
Bitwix hym . and a noþir conquerour .
For all þⁱˢ wordle / for drede of hy hath quaked
He was of knyghthode and of Fredom flour .
Fortune hym made / þe heir . of hir honour .
Safe wyn and women noþing myght aswage
His high entent in armes and laboure
So was he full of . leonyn Corage /
¶ What pris were it to hy þough I you told
Of Darius and of . C . Mˢ . moo
Of kyngꝭes princes dukꝭes ⁊and erles bolde
Which he cōmquered ⁊and brought hem into woo
I sey as ferre as man may ride or goo
Þe wordle was his / what shold I more / deuyse
For þough I tolde you . and wrote eủer/remoo
Of his knyghthode / it myght not suffise /
¶ Xij yeer he regned as seith Machabee
Philippus sone of Macedoyne he was
That First was kynge in grece the Contre
O worþi and noble Alexandre allas
That eủer/re sholde falle suche a caas
Empoisoned of þin own Folk þᵘ were
Thy . sis . fortune / hath turned in to aas
And for . the ne wepte sche neủer/re a teere /
¶ Who shall me yeue teres to compleyne
The deth of Gentilles or of Fraunchise /
Þat all / the wordle welded in his demeyne
And ȝhit hym þought it myght not suffise
So full was his corage / of high emprise
Allas who shall me helpe to endite
Fals Fortune and poysou to despise
The which two // of all þis woo I wite
¶ By wisdom Manhede / ⁊and bi grete laboᵘur
From vnble hode / to roiall mageste
Vp ros he / Iulius the Conquerour .
Þat wan all þe occident / bi lond ⁊and see
Bi strenght of hond / or els by tretee /
And vnto Rome . made hem tributarie
And sith of Rome Emꝑper/paroure was he /
Till þat Fortune / wax his adủer/resarie
¶ O myghty Ceser þat in Thessalie
Ageyns Pompeyus faþ̉er/re þin / in lawe
Þat of þe Orient / had all the Chiualrie
As fer . as þat / þe day / begynnyth to dawe /
Þou þrough þi knyghthode / hast hēm take ⁊and slawe /
Saue a Few folke / þat wᵗith Pompeyus fledde /
Þrough which þou puttest / all þe Orient in awe /
Thanke Fortune . that so w sche spedde //
¶ But now a litle while I woll bewaile
This Pompeyus this noble goủer/renour .
Of Rome which þᵗat fled at his bataile
I seie oon of his men a fals Traytoᵘur
His hede of smote to wynne hym Favoᵘur
Of Iulius / and to hy þe heed he brought
Allas Pompeyus . of orient conqueroᵘur
Þᵗat Fortune . vnto such a fine the brought
¶ To Rome agayn . repairith Iulius
Wᵗith his triumphe / lauriat full hie
But on a tyme / Brutus Cassius
Þat eủer/re had of his high estate envye
Full pvilie had made conspiracye
Ageyns þis Iulius in sotell wise
And cast þe place / in which he shold die
Wᵗith boidekyns as I shall you devise
¶ This Iulius to the . Capitolie wente /
Vpon a day / as he was wont to doon
And in the Capitolie anon hym . hente .
This fals Brutus . and his oþir foon
And stiked hym wᵗith boidekyns anoon
Wᵗith many awounde / ⁊and þus þei leten hym lie
But neủer/re grount he / at no stroke but oon
Or els atte two / but if his storie lie
¶ So manly was this Iulius of herte /
And so well loued his statly honeste
Þat þough his dedly wounde so sore smerte /
His mantell oủer/re his hippes caste / he
For no man . shold see his pvite
And as he lay of deiyng in a traunce
And wist verely / þat dede shold he be
Of honeste / ȝhit hadde he remembᵃunce
¶ Lucan to the this storie I recomende
And to Swetou / and to Valerius also
Þat of the storie wretyn worde ⁊and ende /
How þᵗat to thise grete Conqueroᵘurs two
Fortune was first frend ⁊and sith a . Foo
Noman ne trust vpon Fortunes fauoᵘur long
But haue here in awaite / For eủer/re moo
Witnes of all thise Conquerous strong
¶ The riche Cresus whilom kyng of lide
Of which Cresus . Cirus sore hym dradde
Ȝhit was he caught amyddꝭes all his pride
And to be brent / men to þe fire . hym ladde
But suche arayn doun fro þe wilkon . shadde /
Þat it slough the Fire / ⁊and made hym to escape /
But to be ware / no grace ȝhit hadde hee /
Till fortune on þe galowes made hym gape /
¶ Whan he scaped was / he gan not stente
Forto begynne a newe werre agayn
He wende well for þᵗat Fortune hym sente
Suche hap þᵗat he scaped þrough þe rayn
Þat of his Foes / he myght not be slayn
And eke a sweuen vpon a nyght he mette
Of which he was so proude / ⁊and eke so fayn
Þat in veniaunce he all his herte sette
¶ Vpon a tree he was / as þat hym þought
Wher Iubiter hym wasshe boþe bak ⁊and side
And Phebus eke / a fare towell hym brought /
To drie hym wᵗith and herfor wax his pride
And to his doughter þat stode hym beside
Which þᵗat he knewe . in high science habounde
He bade here tell hym what it signifiede
And sche his dreme right / þus bigan expounde
¶ The tre qd sche / the galous is to mene
And Iubiter betokenyth snowe and rayn
And Phebus wᵗith his towaill so clene
Tho been the sonne stremes for to sayn
Þou shalt anhanged be faþer . Certayn
Reyn shall þe wasshe / and sonne shal þe drie
Þus warned she hy full plat ⁊and full playn
His doughter which þᵗat called was Phanie
¶ And hanged was Cresus . þe proude kyng
His roiall trone myght hym not availe
Tragedies . noon othir . maner thyng
Ne can in syngyng crie ne bewaile
But for þᵗat fortune alday woll assaill
Wᵗith vnware stroke / þᵉ regnes þᵗat be proude /
For . whan men trusten hir . þen wol she faill
And Cover . here bright face wᵗith a cloude
¶ O noble o worþi Petir . glorie of Spayne
Whom Fortune helde / so high in mageste /
Well owth men / þi pitous deth coplayne
Out of þi londe thy broþer . made the Fle /
And aftir atte a Sege . bi . sotelte
Þᵘ were / betraid and led to his tent
Wher . as he / wᵗith his own hand slough the /
Succedyng in þi regne and in þi . rent
¶ The feld of snowe wᵗith þe Egle of blak þ̉er/rein
Caught wᵗith þe lyme rod // coloured as þe glede
He brewith his cursidnes ⁊and all his synne
Þe wicked nest / was werker . of þis nede
Nought . Charles . Olyủer/re . þat toke ay hede
Of trouth ⁊and honour . but of Armorike
Geneloun . Olyủer/ree / corrupt for Mede /
Broughten þis worþi knyght in such a prike
¶ O worþi Petre kyng of Cipre also /
Þat Alexaunder . wan . by high maistrie
Full many an hethyn . wroughtest þou woo
Of which þin own . lieges hadden . Envie
And for noþing but for . thy Chyualrie
Þei in þi bedde haue slayn . þe . bi þe morowe
Þus can Fortune hir while goủer/rene and gie
And out of ioy bryng men to sorowe
¶ Of Melen . grete Barnabo . ⁊and visecounte
God of delite and scourge of lumbardie
Why shold I not / þin Infortune accounte
Sith in estate þou clombyn were so hie
Þi broþers sone / þat was þi double allie
For . he thy nevewe was / and son in lawe
Wᵗithin his psou made the to Die
But why ne howe / not I / þᵗat þou were slawe
¶ Of þe Erle hugelyn / of ꝓproise the langour .
Ther . may no tunge . tellen . for pite
But litle out of pise stondith a tour
In which Toure in pson put was he
And wᵗith hym weren / his litle Children iij
The Eldest scarsly v yeer was of age
Allas Fortune it was grete cruelte
Such briddꝭes for to put / in suche a cage
¶ Dampned was he to die in þat presou
For . Rogger . which þat Bisshop was of pise
Hadde on hym made a . fals suggestiou
Þrough which þe peple gan . vpon hym rise
And putten hym in pson in suche wise .
As ye haue herde ⁊and mete ⁊and drynke he hadde
So small / þat well vnneth it myght suffise
And þ̉er/re wᵗith all was full poure and badde /
¶ And oon a day befell . þat in that houre
When þat his mete wont was to be brought
The Gailer . shitte þe dores of the Toure
He herde it wele / but he spake right nought
And in his herte / anoon ther fil a thoght
That þei for . hungre wolde doon hym dien
Allas qd he allas . þat I was wrought
Þ̉er/rewᵗith the teeres fell doun frōm his eyen
¶ His yonge sone þat . iijd . yeer was of age
Vnto hym seide / Faþir Faþir whi do ye wepe
Whan woll the gailer . bryng oure potage
Is þer no morsell brede / þat ye do kepe
I am so hungry þat I may not slepe
Nowe wold god þat I myght slepe eủer/re
Þen shold not hungre / in my wombe crepe /
Þ̉er/re is no þing but brede / þᵗat me were leủer/re /
¶ Thus day be day þis Childe began to crie
Till in his faþers barme a doun he lay
And seid faþir well faþir . me mote die
And kissed his faþir . and dide þe same day
And whan the wofull faþ̉er/re / did it say
For . wo his armes two / he gan to bite
And said allas Fortune . and wele awey
Þi fals while . my woo all / may I wite /
¶ His Children wende : þᵗat it for . hungre was
Þat he his armes gnowe ⁊and not for . woo
And seide faþer . doo not soo allas
But raþer . ete þe Flessh vpon vs two
Oure flessh ye yaue vs : take it vs fro
And ete I nowgh : right þus to hy þei . seid
And after þᵗat wᵗithin oo day or twoo /
Þei leide hem in his lappe and deid
¶ Hym silf dispeired eke for . hungre starf
Thus endid this myghty Erle of Pise
From high estate / Fortune awey hym carf
Of þis tragedie it ought I now suffise
Who so woll here it in a lenger wise /
Redith þe grete poete of Itaille
Þat hight daunt / for he can it all deuyse
Fro poynt to poynt not oo word wol . he faile
¶ Here endith þe monkis tale /: de casibus virox ~ illustriu

hi.hi:
Here endith þe monkis tale ; de casibus viroy
illustriu and begynnyth þe ꝓprologe of þe Nonnes Prest

div.l: ¶ Ho qd the knyght good ser no more of þis
Þat ye haue seid / is right I now I wis
And mochell more / For . litle heuynes
Is right I nowe For mychil . folk I ges
I sey for . me it is a grete dissease
Wher as men . haue been . in grete welth ⁊and ease
To heren of ther . soden falle allas
And þe contrary is ioy and grete solas
And whan a man hath been in poủer/ree astate
And Clymbeth vp . And wexith Fortunate
And þer . abidith in prosperite /
Such þing is gladsom . as it þinkith me
And of such þingꝭes were goodly for to tell
Ya qd oure Oost be Seynt poules bell
Ye sey right soth . þis monke hath clapped loude
He spake how Fortune . coủer/reed was wᵗith a . cloude
I not neủer/re what // and also tregedie
Right now ye herde // ⁊and ꝑper/parde no remedie
Is it For to be wailen and compleyne
Atte þat is doun / ⁊and eke it is a peyne
As ye haue seid / to heren . of hevynes .
Sir . Monke no more of þis / so god you bles
Yoᵘur . tale annoyeth all this Compenie
Such thing is not worth a butt̉er/re flie .
For þer . in nys chere / disporte ne game
Wherfor ʆser/sir Monke / O daun pers . be þi name /
I pᵃy you hertily / tell vs sumwhat elles
For . sikerly ner . clynkyng of your belles
Þat on youre bridell hong on eủer/rey side
By heuen kyng . þat for vs all dide /
I shold or . þis fallen doun for . slepe /
All þough þe slough had neủer/re been so depe /
Than had youre tale . all be tolde in vayn
For . c̉er/retenly as þat þise Clerkis sayn
Wher . as men may haue noon . audience /
Not helpith it // to tellen his sentence /
And well I wote / þe substaunce is in me
If any þing shall well reported be
Sir . say sumwhat of huntyng I you pᵃy
Nay qd þis Monk . I haue no lust to play
Now lete a noþ̉er/re tell / as I haue tolde /
Þan spake oᵘur . Oost wᵗith rude speche and bolde
And seide vnto þe Nonnes . Preste anoon .
Come heþir . þᵘ prest / come hedir . þou ser . Iohn
Tell vs suche þing as may oure hertꝭes glade /
Be blithe / þough þᵘ ride vpon a iade
What þough þi hors . be bothe Foule ⁊and lene /
If he woll serue þe / recke not a bene
Loke þᵗat þin hert be mery eủer/remoo
Ȝes ser . qd he / ȝes oste so mote I goo /
But I be mery / I wis I woll be blamed
And right anon his tale he hath attamed
And þus he seid vnto vs eủer/reychon
This good Prest / þis goodly man . ʆser/sir Iohn //

Here begynnyth þe Nonnes Prestis
tale of the Cokke ⁊and of the henne
a Powre Wedowe . somdele stopen in age
Was whilom dwellyng in a narowe Cotage
Be side a grove stondyng in a . dale /
This wedowe . of which I tell you my tale
Syn . þilk day þat . sche was laste a wife /
In Pacience ladde a . simple life /
For . litle was here catell and here rente .
By husbondrie of suche . as god here sente /
Sche fonde here silf / ⁊and eke here doughtres two
Thre large sowes had sche and no moo /
Thre kene and eke a shepe / þat hight malle
Full swote was here . boure . and eke hir . halle
In which sche ate full many a sklendre mele
Of poynaunt sause // knew she neủer/re a dele
No deynte morsell passed þrough here throte
Hir . diete was accordyng to here Cote
Replecion ne made . hir neuer . seke
Attempre diete was all hire Phisike /
And excercise and hertly suffisaunce
The goute / letted not here . for . to daunce /
Ne Apoplexie . schente not here heed
No wyne dranke she neủer/re / white ne reed
Hir . borde was ʆser/sirued most wᵗith white ⁊and blak
Milke ⁊and broun brede / in which she fond / no lak
Seynde bacou / and somtyme a negge or tweie
For sche was . as it were a man deie
A / yerde sche had enclosed all aboute /
Wᵗith stikkes . ⁊and wᵗith drie diche wyth oute /
In which sche had a Cok hight Chauntecler .
In all þᵗat Contre / of Crowyng was noon his Peer .
His vois was merier . þen þe mery . Orgoun
On masse daies . that in Chirches . gon
Well sikerer . was his Crowyng in his logge .
Þen is a clok . or in any Abbey an Orlegge /
Bi nature he knewe eche . assencioun
Of the Equinoxiall in thilke Toun
For when degrees / xv . were . ascendid
Þen knewe he . þat it myght not be amendid
His Combe was . redder . þen þe Fyne Corall .
And batelled as it were a Castell wall
His bill was blak / ⁊and as þe geet it shoon
Like asure were his leggis . and his toon
His nailes whitter . þen þe lilly floure
And like the bourned golde / was his coloᵘur /
¶ This gentle Cok had in his goủer/renᵃnce
Vij . hennes for . to doon all his plesᵃunce
Which were his susters . and his ꝑper/paramoᵘurs .
And wondir . like to hym as of Colours
Of which þe fairest hewed on here throte /
Was cleped faire damesell Pertelote /
He Federd here . C . tymes in . a day
And sche hym plesith all þᵗat eủer/re sche may
Curteis sche was discrete and debonaire /
And Compenable / ⁊and bare hir . silf so faire /
Syn þilke day þᵗat sche was vij . nyght olde /
That truly sche hath þe herte in holde
Of Chauntecler . lokyn in eủer/rey lith
He loued here so / þᵗat wele was hy þ̉er/rewᵗith
But suche a ioy was it to here hym synge
And so bifell þat in a dawnynge
As Chauntecler among his wifes all
Sate on his Perche / þᵗat was in the hall
And next hym sate þis faire pertelote
Þis Chauntecler . gan . gronen . in his þrote
As a man þᵗat in his dreme / drecchith sore
And when þat Pertelote / þus herd hy rore
Sche was agaste / and seide herte dere /
What eileth you to grone / in þis manere /
Ye been a very sleper . fy for . schame
And he answerd þus / and said madame
I pᵃy you / þat ye take it not a greef
Bi god me mette / I was in suche myscheef
Right nowe / þᵗat yet myn hert is sore a fright
Now god qd he my . sweuen . dressen a right
And kepe my body . out of foule presou
Me mette . how þat I . romed vp and doun
Wᵗithin oure yerde . wher . as I sawe a beste .
Was like a . hounde / ⁊and wold haue made a reste /
Vpon my body / and haue had me dede
His colour . was bitwen . yelow and rede /
And tipped was his heed taile / ⁊and boþe his eres
Wᵗith blak / vnlike þe remnant of his heres
His snowte was small // wᵗith glowyng eyen tweie
Yhit for his loke for . feer . almoste I deie /
This causede me my . gronynge doutles
¶ Awey qd sche . Fie vpon you hertles
Allas . qd sche . For . bi þat god aboue
Now haue ye lost my hert ⁊and all my loue
I can not loue a coward be my feith
For c̉er/retes what so any woman seith
We all desiren . if it myght be
To haue an husbond hardy . wys . ⁊and Fre
And secre // and no nygard . ne no Fool .
Ne hym þat is agaste of eủer/rey tool .
Ne noon avauntoᵘur / by þat god aboue /
How durst ye for . shame sey to yoᵘur loue
Þat any þing myght make you aferde
Haue ye no manys hert / ⁊and haue a berde /
Allas can ye bene a gaste of sweuenys
No þing but vanite god woot in sweuen . is
Sweuenys been engendred of replecoıı̄uns
And ofte of fume / and of complexions
When humoᵘurs . been to habundant in a wight
Certꝭes þis dreme / which ye haue mette to nyght
Comyth of the grete suꝑper/parfluyte /
Of youre Rede Colora . parde /
Which causith folk to dreme in here dremes
Of arowes and of fire / wᵗith rede lemes
Of rede bestis / þat þei woll hem bite /
Of Contekt ⁊and of waspes . grete and lite /
Right as þe humour . of malencolye .
Causith many a man in slepe to crie
For fere of boles or . of beres blake
Or els blake devels . þat wold hem take
And oþir humoᵘurs . cowde I tell also
Þᵗat worken many a man . in slepe moche woo
But I woll passe as lightly as I can
Lo Caton . which þat was so . wise a man
Seid he not þus . do no force of dremes
Now ʆser/sir . qd sche . when we fle frōm þise bemes
For . goddis loue . as take some laxatif
Vp parell of my soule and of my lif
I councell you þe best I woll not lie
Þat boþe of Colora and of malyncolie
Ye purge you . and for . ye shall not tarie
Þough in this Toun be noon Appoticarie
I shall my silf . to herbes teche you .
Þat shalbe for . yoᵘur . ease / ⁊and for youre prowe
And in oure / yerde þe herbes shall I fynde
The which han of ther . ꝓpropirte by kynde
To purgen you bi nethe : and eke aboue
Sir . forgete not þis for . goddis loue
Ye been full Colerik of Complexiou
Be ware þat þe Son in his assenciou
Ne fynde you not replete / of humoᵘurs hote
And if it do . I dare well leye a grote
Þat ye shall haue a Feuer . tercian
Or . an agewe / which þᵗat may be yoᵘur . ban
A day or . two ye shall haue digestyues
Of wormes . or . ye take yoᵘur laxatifes
Of laureole / Centorie ⁊and Fumetere
Or . els of Eleborn þat growith þere
Of Catapuce . or of gayttris beries
Of herbe Iue . growyng in oᵘur . yerde þ̉er/re is
Pike hem vp / as þei growe . ⁊and ete hem in
Be mery husbond for youre fadir . kyn
Dredith no dreme I can sey you no more /
¶ Madame qd he : gᵃunt mcy of youre lore
But naþeles as towchyng daun Catou
Þat hath of wisdom suche grete renoun
Þough þat he bade / no dremes for to drede
Bi god men mowen . in olde bokes rede
Of many a man . more of Auctorite
Then . euer Caton was . so mote I . the .
Þat all þe reủer/res seyn / of his sentence
And han well founden by experience
Þat dremes been significacions
As well of ioy as of tribulacions
Þat folke enduren . in þis lif psent
Þer nedith to make of þis noon argument
The very ꝓprofe / schewith it in dede
On of þe grettest autoᵘurs . þat men rede
Seith þus . þᵗat whilom two Felowes went
On Pilgremage . in a full good entent
And happed so . þat þei came in a Toun
Wher . þer . was . suche a Congregacioun
Of paple / ⁊and eke so straite of herbergage
Þat þei ne fonde . as mochel . as a Cotage /
In which they myght I logged be
Wherfor þei moste of necessite
As for þat nyght departe Companye
And eche of hem goth to his . Osterie
And toke his loggyng . as it wold falle .
Þat oon . of hem was logged in a stalle .
Ferre in a yerde wᵗith oxen of þe plowe
Þat oþir . man was logged well I nowe
As was his auenture . or . his Fortune
Þat vs goủer/renyth as in Cōmmune
And so bifell þat longe or . it was day
Þis man met in his bed þ̉er/re as he lay
How þᵗat his Felowe gan vpon hym call
And seid allas ferre in an oxes stall
Þis nyght I shalbe mordred þer I . lie
Nowe helpe me dere broþ̉er/re or . I die
In all haste come to me he seide
Þis man out of his slep for . fere abreide
But whan þᵗat he was wakened of his slepe
He turned hym and toke of þis no kepe
Hym þought his dreme but a . vanite
Thus twis in hs slepe dremed he /
And at þe thirde tyme ȝhit his Felowe
Cam as hym þought ⁊and seid I am now slawe .
Biholde my blody woundꝭes . depe and wide
Arise vp erly in the morowe tyde
And at þe westgate of þe toun qd he
A Cartefull of donge þ̉er/re shalte þou see
In which my body is hid full pvily
Þou . thilke Carte aresten . boldely
My golde caused my morþer . soth to seyn
And told hym eủer/rey poynt how he was sleyn
Wᵗith a full pitous face . pale of . hewe
And trustith wele his . dreme . he fond ful . trewe /
For . on the morowe as sone . as it was day
To his Felowes Inne he took his way
And when he come / to this oxes stall
After . his Felowe he bigan to call
The Osteler answerd hym . anoon
And saide Ser . yoᵘur . Felowe is a goon
As sone as day he went out of þe Toun
This man gan falle in grete suspeccioun
Remembryng on his dremes . þat he mette /
And forth he goth no leng wolde he lette /
Vnto þe westgate of the Toun and fonde /
A donge Carte went for to donge londe /
Þat was arrad in the same wise /
As ye haue herd the deed man devise
And wᵗith an herde hert he gan to crie
Vengaunce and Iustice / of þis Felonie
My felowe mordred is þis same nyght
And in þis Cart he lieth gapyng vp right
I crie oute of the Ministres . quod he .
Þat shold kepe . and rule this Cite /
Harrowe allas . here lieth my felowe slayn /
What shold I more / vnto þis tale sayn /
The peple vpsterte . and cast þe Cart to ground
And in þe myddill of the donge they found
The deed man . þat mordered was all newe
O blisfull god þat art so iuste and trewe
Lo how þat þou / biwreist mordre . Alwey
Mordere woll out . þat se we day bi day
Mordere is so lothsom and so Abhominable
To god that is so iuste and resonable
Þat he ne woll not / suffre it heeled be
Þough it abide a yere . two . or . thre
Mordere woll out / þis is my conclusiou
And right anon þe Ministers of þe Toun
Haue hent the Carter . ⁊and so sore hym pyned
And eke the Osteler . so sore engyned
Þat þei beknewe . here wickidnes . anoon
And were . an hanged bi the necke boon
Here mowe men se / þᵗat dremes be to drede .
And Certes in the same book . I rede /
Right in the next chapitre aftir . þis .
I gab not so . haue I ioy or . blis
¶ Two men þᵗat wolde haue passed oủer/re þe see /
For . Certen causes into ferre . Contre /
Yif þat þe wynde . ne had been contᵃrie
That made hem in a Cite for . to tarie
Þat stode full mery vpon an hauen side
But on a day . agayn the evyn . tyde
Þe wynde gan chaunge ⁊and blew as hem lest
Ioly and gladde þei wenten . to here rest
And Caste hem . full erly for to saile
But to þat oo man / fell a grete mvaile /
That oon of hem : in slepyng as he lay
Hym met a wonþ̉er/re dreme / agayn þe day
Hym þought a man stode / bi þe beddꝭes side
And hym cōmmaunded þᵗat he shold abide /
And seid hym þus : if þᵘ to morow wende .
Þou shalt be dreynt my tale is at an ende /
He woke ⁊and tolde his felowe what he mette /
And pᵃide hym his viage for . to lette /
As for þat day : he pᵃid hym to abide .
His felowe þat lay bi his beddis side
Gan . forto laugh : ⁊and scorned hym ful . faste /
No dreme qd he may so . myn hert agaste
That I woll lette for . to do my thyngꝭes .
I set not a strawe by thy dremyngis
For . sweuenes . ben but vanytes and iapes
Men dreme al . day of Foules . and of Apes
And eke of many a mase / ther . with all
Men dreme of þinge þat neủer/re shall fall
But sithe I see / þat þou wolt here abide /
And þus forslewthen . wilfully thy tide /
God woot it rewith me / ⁊and haue good day
And þus he toke his leue / ⁊and went his way
But or . þat he . had half his cours . sailed
Not I not why / ne what myschaunce it ailed
But casually the shippis . botom . rente
And ship and man . vnder . þe water . wente
In . sight of oþir shippis . it beside
Þat wᵗith hem sailed at þe same tide /
And þ̉er/refor . faire ꝐPer/Partelote so dere
Bi . such ensamples olde may ye lere /
Þat no man shalbe to recheles
Of dremes . for I say you doutles .
Þᵗat many a dreme / full sore is for to drede
Lo / in the lif of Seynt kenhelm I rede .
Þat was kenulphus sone þe noble kyng
Of Mertewrik . howe kenhelm . met a þing
A litle or he was mordred on þe day
His morder in his avisiou he say
Hys Norice hym . expouned eủer/rey dele /
His sweuen . ⁊and bad hym . for to he kepe hy wele
From tresou but he was . but vij . yeer olde
And þ̉er/refor . litle tale hath he tolde /
Of any dreme / so holy was his hert
By god I had leủer/re then my shert
Þat ye had herd his legende as haue I
Dame ꝐPer/Partelote I . sey you . trewly
Macrobeus . þat wrote the . Avisiou
In Affrike . of the worþi Cypiou
Affermeth dremes . ⁊and seith þat þei been
Warnyng of þyngꝭes . þᵗat men . aftir seen
And furdirmore I pᵃy you lokith well
In the olde . testament of Danyell
Yif he helde dremes any vanyte .
Rede eke of Ioseph : ⁊and þ̉er/re shalt þou . se
Wher . dremes . ben somtyme / I sey not all
Warnyng of þingꝭes þat shall after . fall
Loke of Egipt the kyng Daun . Pharao
His Baker . and his Boteler . also .
Wheþir . þei ne felt noon effect in dremes
Who so woll seke actes of sondry Remes
May rede of dremes . many a wonþir . þing
Lo Cresus which þat was of lide þe kyng
Met he not þat he sate vpon . a tree .
Which signified he shold an hanged be /
Lo . here Andremacha . Ectores wife .
Þat day þat Ector . shold lese his life
She dremed on þe same nyght biforn
How þat þe life of Ector . shold be lorn
Yif þilke day he went into bataile
She warned hym / but it myght not availe /
He went forthe to Fight naþeles
But he was slayn anon of Achilles
But þilke tale / is all to longe to tell
And eke it is nygh nyght / I may not dwell
Shortly I sey as for . Conclusiou
Þat I shall haue of this Auysiou
Adủer/resite / and shall say Ferthermore /
Þat I ne tell of laxatifs no store /
For . þei ben venemus . I woot it wele /
I hem defie I . loue hem neuer . a . dele /
¶ Now lete vs speke of myrth ⁊and stynt all þis
Madame ꝐPer/Partelote so haue I ioy . or . blis .
Of oo þing god hath sent me large gᵃce
For . whan I se þe beaute . of your . face
Ye been . so scarlet rede . about / þe eyen
It makith all my drede For . to dien /
For . as trewe as is þe gospell / In pⁱrincipio
Mulier . est hominis Confusio /
Madame the sentence of þis latyn is
Woman is manys ioy and his blis
For . whan . I fele a nyght yoᵘur . softe side /
All be it þat I may not / on you . ride
For . þᵗat oure ꝑper/parche is made so narow allas
I am so full of ioy . and of solas
Þat I defie bothe sweuen ⁊and dreme
⁊and wᵗith þᵗat word he flew doun frōm þe beme /
For . it was day . and eke his hennes all
And wᵗith a Chuk . he gan hem . for .to call
For he had founde a corn lay in þe yerde
Riall he was . and was no more a ferde .
He federed ꝐPer/Partelote . mo þen xxᵗⁱ tyme
And trade here eke / as oft or . it were prime
He loked as it were a grym lyou
And on his toes he romed vp ⁊and doun
Hym deyned not to set his feet on grounde /
And chukked whan he had a corn founde
And to hym rennen . þen his wyues all
Thus riall as a prince is in his hall
Leue I this Chauntecler . in his pasture /
And aftir woll I tell his auenture /
¶ Whan þᵗat þe monyth in which þe wordle bigan
Þat hight Marche whan god first maked man
Was complete / and I passed were also /
Sith Marche bigan xxxᵗⁱ daies and two /
Bifell that Chauntecler . in all his pride /
His wyues . vij . walkyng hym be side /
Cast vp his eyen . to þe bright sonne
Þat in the signe of Taurus had ronne .
Xxᵗⁱ degrees ⁊and oon . ⁊and sumwhat more /
He knewe bi kynde and bi noon oþir . lore /
Þᵗat it was pⁱrime / ⁊and krew wᵗith blisfull steuen
The sonne he seid is clomben . vpon heuen
Xl . degrees and oon . and more I wis
Madame ꝐPer/Partelote my wordlis blis .
Herkenyth þis . blisfull briddꝭes . how þei synge
And se the fressh floures how þei . sprynge /
Full is myn herte / of reuell and solas .
But sodenly hy fell a sorowfull caas
¶ For eủer/re the latter . ende / of ioy is wo
God wote þᵗat wordly ioy is sone a goo
And if a Rethor . coude faire endite /
He in a Cronicle safly myght it write /
As for . a soủer/reaigne notabilite /
Now eủer/rey wise man . lete hym herken me /
This storie is as trewe / I . vndirtake //
As is the book of Launcelot de lake /
Þat woman helde in full grete reủer/reence
Now woll I turne a gayn to my sentence
¶ A Colfoxe . full of slie iniquite
Þat in þe grove had woned yeres thre /
Bi high Imaginaciou befor caste /
Þe same nyght þrough out þe hegge braste
Into the yerde / ther Chauntecler . þe faire
Was wonte / and eke his wyues to repaire
And in a bedde of wortis still he lay
Til it was passed vndern of the day
Awaityng his tyme / on Chauntcler . to fall
As gladly doon thise homicides all
Þat in awaite liggen . to morþer men
O fals morderer . liggyng in thy den
O new Scariot O . newe . Guenyloun
Fals dissimuloᵘur / : O . greke Sinoun
Þat broughtest Troye . all vttirly to sorowe /
O . Chauntecler acorsed be the morowe /
Þat þou in to þe yerde flaugh : frōm þe bemes
Þou were full wele warned bi . þi dremes
That þilke day was ꝑper/parlous vnto the
But þᵗat þat / god befor . wote / l most nedꝭes . be
After the oppiniou of Certen . Clerkis
Wᵗithnes of hym þat any ꝑper/parfite / Clerk is
That in scole is grete alt̉er/recaciou
In this mat̉er/re / and grete disputaciou
And hath been of . C . Mˢ . men
But I ne can not bult it to þe bren
As can the holy doctour . Augustyn
Or . Boice / or þe Bisshop Bradwardyn
Whedir . þat goddꝭes worþi fore wittyng
Streyneth me nedly : for . to do a . thyng
Nedly clepe I simple necessite /
Or . els if fre choise be gᵃunted me
To do þat same thyng or . do it nought
Þough god forwote it / or þᵗat gi it was wrought
Or . yif his wetyng streyneth neủer/re a dele /
But bi necessite Condicionele /
I woll not haue to doon in suche matere /
My tale is of the Cok as ye may here /
Þᵗat toke his councell : of his wif wᵗith sorowe /
To walken in þe yerde / vpon the morowe /
Aft̉er/re þat he had mette þe dreme / þᵗat I you tolde /
Wemmens Councell / been full ofte colde /
Wommans councell / brought vs first to wo /
And made Adam . From Paradis . to goo
Þer . as he was full mery / ⁊and well at ese /
But for þᵗat / I not whom I myght displese /
Yif I councell of wommen . wolde blame
Passe oủer/re : for . I seide it in my game /
Rede Auctours . þ̉er/re þei trete of suche matere /
And what þei sey of wommen . ye mowe here /
This been . the Cokkis wordis and not myne .
I can noon harme / on no wōmman devyne
¶ Faire in the sonde to bathe merily
Lieth ꝑper/partelote ⁊and here Susters by
A gayn þe son // ⁊and Chauntecler . so fre /
Sange merier . þen . þe Mermaide in þe see
For . Phisiologus . seith sikerly
How þᵗat þei synge . well / and merily
And so bifell : as þat he caste his eye .
Amonge the wortis on . a buttirflie
He was ware of þe Fox . þᵗat lay full lowe
No thyng ne lust hym . the for to Crowe
But cride anoon . Cok Cok . ⁊and vp he sterte /
As a man þat was . afraid in his herte /
For . naturelly a beste desirith to fle /
From his contᵃrie / yif he may hym see
Þough he noon . arst had it seen wᵗith his eye /
Þis Chauntecler . whan he gan . hym aspie
He wolde haue fled / but þat þᵉ fox anon
Seid gentle ser . allas whedir . woll ye goon
Bi . ye affraid of me / þat am youre frende
Now Certes I were wors . þen . a Fende /
Yif I to you wolde harme or . velanie
I am not come yoᵘur councell for . to spie
But trewly the cause of my comyng
Was only for to herken / how þᵗat ye syng
For trewly ye haue / as mery a steuene /
As any aungell that is in heuene /
Þere wᵗith ye haue in musik more felyng
Then had Boice / or any þᵗat can syng
My lorde yoᵘur . Faþer . god his soule blesse /
And eke yoᵘur moþer . of here gentilnesse /
Han in myn hous been / to me grete ease /
And Certes ʆser/sir . full fayn wold I you please /
But for . men speken . of syngyng : I woll seie
So mote I broke wele myn . eyen . tweie
Saue ye : ne herde I neuer man so synge /
As dede yoᵘur faþir . ones in a mornynge /
Certes it was of hert all þat he songe .
And for to make / his voice / þe more stronge
He wold so peyne hym / þᵗat wᵗith boþe his eyen .
He moste wynke / so loude wold he Crien .
And stonde on his tiptoon . þer . with all
And strecche forth his necke long ⁊and small
And eke he was of suche discrecion
Þat þer . was no man . in no Regiou
Þat hym in songe or wisdom . myght passe /
I haue wele redde / in daun . Burnell þe asse
Amonge his vers . howe þat þer . was a Cok
Þat for . a Prestis sone / yafe hym a knok
Vpon his legge / while he was yonge and nyce /
He made hym for . to lese his benefice /
But c̉er/reteyn . ther . is no Comparisou
Bitwix . the wisdom and discrecoıı̄un /
Of youre faþer / and of his subtilite
Nowe syngith on Ser . for . Seynt Charite /
Lete . se can ye yoᵘur faþer Countrefete /
¶ This Chauntecler . his wyngꝭes gan to bete /
As man þat coude / his treson not aspie
So was he rauysshed wᵗith his Flaterie
Allas ye lordis . many a fals Flaterour .
Is in yoᵘur Court / and many a losengour .
Þat / plesen you well more be my feith
Þen he þat sothfastnes vnto you seith
Redith Ecclesiaste of flaterie /
Beth ware ye lordꝭes . of here trecherie
¶ This Chauntecler . stood high vpon his toes
Strecchyng his . necke / ⁊and held his eyen cloes
And gan to crowe lowde . For the nones
And daun Russhell / þe Fox stert vp at ones
And bi . the gargat . hente Chauntecler .
And on his bak vnto þe wode hym beer .
For yet was þ̉er/re no man . þat hym sewed
O . destanie þat may not . been eschewed
Allas þat Chauntecler . fleigh fro the bemes
Allas þᵗat his wif rought not of his dremes
And on a friday : fell al . this myschaunce
O Venus þat art goddes . of plesaunce /
Syn þat thy ʆser/siruaunt was þis Chauntecler
And in thy ʆser/siruise . dede all his . power .
More for . delite / þen þe wordle to multiplie
Why woldest þou suffre hy / on þis day to die
O . Gaufreed : dere master . soủer/reaigne
Þat whan þe worþi kyng Richard was slayne /
Wᵗith shote compleinest / his deth so sore
Why ne had I now þi science and þi lore
The Friday for to chide / as deden ye /
For . on a Friday sothly slayn was he /
Þen wold I shewe / how þᵗat I coude pleyne /
For Chaunteclers drede ⁊and for . his peyne /
Certes suche Crie and lamentacion .
Was neủer/re of ladies . made / whan Iliou
Was wonne / ⁊and Pirrus wᵗith his . streite swerd
Whan he hadde hent kyng Priam9 bi þe berd
And slayn hym . as seith vs . Eneydos
As maden . all the hennes in the cloos .
Whan þei . had seen of Chauntecler . þe sight
But soủer/reeynly Dame ꝐPer/Partelote shright /
Full ludder . þen dede hastrubaldes wif
Whan þat hire husbond . had lost his lif
And þat þe Romayns . had brent cartage /
She was so full / of turment ⁊and of rage /
That wilfully into the Fire sche sterte /
And brent here silf wᵗith a stedfast herte /
¶ O wofull hennes . right so criden . ye /
As whan þat Nero brent the Cite
Of Rome // Criden . Senatoᵘurs wyues .
For þat here husbondꝭes loste all here lyues
Wᵗithouten gilte / þis Nero hath hem slayn
Now woll I turne vnto my tale agayn .
This sely wedowe / and eke here doughtren two
Herden þise hennes . crie and maken . woo
And out at þe dores stirten they Anoon
And sawe þe fox toward þe grove goon
And bare vpon his bak þe Cok away
And criden out harrowe and wele away
Ha . ha the Fox . and aft̉er/re hym they ran
And eke wᵗith staues many a noþir . man
Ran Coll oure dogge : and Talbot ⁊and Garlond
And Malkyn wᵗith a distaf in here hond
Ran Cowe and Calf / ⁊and eke þe very hoggis
So a ferde for . barkyng of the doggis //
And shoutyng of þe men . and wommen eke
They ronne so : hem þought here hertꝭes breke
Þei yelleden as Fendis doon in hell
Þe doggꝭes criden . as men wold hem quell
The Gees for . fere . flowen . oủer/re the trees
Out of þe hyve cam þe swarm of bees
So hidous was þe noise a bndicite
Certes / Iak strawe . ne his mayne .
Ne made neủer/re shoutes . half so shille
Whan þᵗat þei wold any flemyng kille /
As þilke day was made / vpon þe Fox
Of bras þei broughten bemes ⁊and of box
Of horn ⁊and of boon : in which þei blewe ⁊and pouped
And þ̉er/re with all þei : shriked and þei houped
It semed as þat heuen sholde fall
Now good men I pᵃy you herkenyth all
Lo how Fortune . turnyth sodenly
Þe hope ⁊and þe pride eke of his Enemy
This Cok þᵗat lay . vpon þe Foxes bak
In all / his drede vnto þe Fox . he spak
And seid ser . / yif I were as ye
Yit wold I sey / as wisly god help me
Turnyth a gayn : ye proud Chorles all
A verry pestilence vpon you Fall
Now I am comen / vnto þe wodꝭes side /
Maugre yoᵘur hedis þe Cok shal . here abide /
I woll hym ete / in feith ⁊and þat a noon
Þe Fox answerd in feith it shalbe doon
And as he spake / þat worde all sodeynly
Þe Cok brake from his mouth delyủer/rely
And high vpon a tree / he flowe anoon
⁊and whan þᵉ Fox saw / þe Cok was goon
Allas qd he / O . Chauntecler . allas
I haue qd he to you I doon trespas
In as moche as I haue : made you a ferde /
Whan I you hent / ⁊and /brought out of yoᵘur yerde /
But sith I did it in no wicked entent
Come doun and I shal tell you what I ment
I shall say soth to you : god help me soo
Nay þen qd he / I shrewe vs . bothe two /
And first I shrewe my silf / boþe blode ⁊and bones
Yif þou begile me / oftir tyme then ones
Thou shalt no more þrough thy flaterie
Do me to synge / ⁊and wynke / wᵗith myn . eye /
For he þat wynkith whan he shold see /
All wilfully . god lete hym neuer . the /
Nay qd þe Fox / but god yeve hym myschᵃunce /
That is so vndiscrete of goủer/renaunce /
Þat Ianglith when he / shold hold his pees
Lo which it is . forto be . recheles
And negligent / and trust on flaterie
But ye þat holden þis tale of folie
As of a Fox / or . of a Cok . ⁊and an . hen
Takith the moralite good men
For Seynt poule seith þᵗat al . þᵗat wretyn is
To oure doctrine it is wretyn : I wis
Takith the fruit and lete þe chaf be stille
Now good god yif þat it be thy wille /
As seid my lord god make vs all good men
And brynge vs vnto his blis . AMEN .
¶ Sir Nonnes prest oᵘur hoste seid anoon
Blissed be þi breche . and eủer/rey stoon
Þis was a mery tale of Chauntecler .
But be my trouth if þou were Seculer
Þou woldest been a trede foule a right
For if þou haue corage as þou hast myght /
The were nede : of hennes . as I wene
Ya . moo : then : vij . tymes seuentene
Se which brawnes hath þis gentle prest
So grete a necke / and such a large brest
He lokith as a sꝑper/parhauke / wᵗith his eyen
Hym nedith not his coloᵘur for . to dien . /
Wᵗith brasile / ne wᵗith greyn . of portyngale /
Now ser . faire fall you for . yoᵘur tale /
And aft̉er/re þat : he wᵗith full mery . chere /
Seid vnto þe Nonne / as ye shal . here /

l.hi: Here endith þe tale of þe Nonnes Prest

div.l: Madam ⁊and I durst / I wold you pray
To tell vs a tale in forderyng of oᵘ way
Then myght ye do : vnto vs grete ease /
Gladly qd sche / so þᵗat I myght please /
You and this worthy Company
And bigan here tale / right þus full sobrely //

div.l: (base) Yet praye ich yow that reden that I write

div.l: (base) O lord my soule and eek my body gye

div.l: By þat þe maunciple had his tale ended
The sonne frōm þe south lyne was discended
So lowe þat he was not as to my sight
Degrees xxixᵗⁱ as of hight /
X . of þe Clok it was þo as I gesse
For xj foot or litle more or lesse
My shadowe was at þilke tyme as þere
Of suche feet / as my lenght parted were
In vj feet equall of ꝓproporciou
Þer wᵗith the mones exaltaciou
I mene libra / alwey gan discende /
As we were entringe at a þropes ende
For which oure hoste as he was wont to gie
As in this caas oure Ioly compaignie
Seide in this wise / lordyngꝭes eủer/reychone
Now lackith vs tales no moo then / one
Fulfilled is my sentence and my decre
I trowe we haue herde of eche degre /
Almost / fulfilled is all oure ordynᵃnce
I pᵃy to god so yeue hym right good Chᵃunce
That telleth his tale to vs lustily

For truly me þinkith bi thy chere
Þou sholdist knyt vp wel a grete matere /
Tell vs a fable anon For Cokkis bones
This Parsou answerd all att ones
Þou getest fable none I tolde for me
For poule þᵗat writith vnto Thimothe
Repuyth hem / þat weyueth sothfastnes
And tellen fables and suche wrecchednes
Why shold I saw draf out of my fiste
Whan I may sawe / whete yif þat me liste /
For which I say / yif þat you liste to here /
Moralite / and vertuous mattere /
And þat ye wil yeue me Audience /
I woll Feyn at Cristis reuerence
Do you plesaunce leefful as I can
But trustith wel I am a soþeren man
I can not Ieste rom ram . ruf bi lettr
Ne god woot ryme / hold I but litle bettr
And þ̉er/refor yif you liste I wol . not glose
I wol you tell a mery tale in prose /
To knyt vp al þis feste ⁊and make an ende /
And Ihu For his gᵃce witte me sende
To schew you þe wey in þis viage
Of þilke ꝑper/parfite glorious pilgremage /
That hight Irlm Celestiall
And yif ye vouch safe anon I shall
Begynne vpon my tale for which I pᵃy
Telle yoᵘur avise I canne no bett̉er/re say
But naþeles this meditaciou
I put it ay vnþer Correcciou
Of Clerkis For I am not textuell
I take but þe sentence trustith well
Þ̉er/refor I make a Protestaciou
Þat I wol stonde to correcciou
Vpon þis word / we haue assentid sone
For as it semyth it was for to done
To enden in some v̉er/retuous sentence /

Þat al we to tell his tale hym preie
Oure host had þe wordꝭes for vs all

Sey what ye luste / ⁊and we wol gladly here
And wᵗith þat worde he said in þis mane
Tellith qd he youre meditacion
But hastith you þe sonne wol adoun
Both fructuous and þat in litle space
And to do wel god send you his grace / /
